componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is John, and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha. Thank you. Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter and then open up the call for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our conference call t
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter and then open up the call for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and actual results may differ materially. We refer you to documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx's Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Profitability remains stronger in the quarter, but sales were lower than anticipated, declining 2% during the December quarter. The primary weakness was driven by broadcast and wireless communications end markets. 28-nanometer sales repre
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Profitability remains stronger in the quarter, but sales were lower than anticipated, declining 2% during the December quarter. The primary weakness was driven by broadcast and wireless communications end markets. 28-nanometer sales represented 1 of the bright spots of the quarter with sales increasing nearly 20%, sequentially. All members of this product family grew with Zynq, Virtex and Artix all posting double-digit growth rates.
From an end market perspective, sales to communications customers declined 3% sequentially, with flat wired sales and a decline in wireless sales. Wireless sales were impacted by weaker sales from non-China regions, while our China wireless business increased in line with expectation.
Industrial and aerospace and defense sales increased as expected with strong defense sales offsetting declines in industrial, scientific and medical. Broadcast consumer and automotive sales declined due to weaker broadcast sales which were driven by weak purchasing activity from a couple of large customers. Automotive sales were better than expected as several new Advanced Driver Assistance programs began to ramp.
In terms of linearity, the month of October and November were in line with our expectations, and the month of December progressively weakened. Turns were 44% for the quarter. Gross margin of 69.7% was better than expected as a result of customer and product mix. Total operating expenses were $224 million, including $2 million of amortization-related expenses. This was $6 million lower than our guided resulting in operating income of 32%.
Other income and expense with a net expense of $4 million, better than forecasted, mainly due to higher interest income from our investment portfolio.
Net income for the quarter was $168 million or $0.62 per share, including a $0.02 per diluted share benefit primarily related to the restatement of the R&D tax credit.
Operating cash flow for the September quarter -- excuse me, the December quarter was $291 million before $6 million in CapEx. Strong cash flow during the quarter was positively impacted by a net improvement in working capital led by the timing impact of Accounts Receivable.
Diluted shares for the quarter were 274 million shares. This was a bit higher than forecasted as a result of the higher stock price. There was a 7.8 million share dilutive effect from our convertible note.
We are committed to returning cash to shareholders. During the quarter, we continued to aggressively buyback stock repurchasing 4 million shares for $175 million. We also paid $76 million in quarterly dividends.
For the fiscal year, thus far, we have returned over $700 million to shareholders in the form of repurchase and dividend, $80 million more than we generated in operating cash flow.
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments increased $28 million to approximately $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion.
Inventory dollars decreased by $16 million during the quarter. We plan to continue to reduce inventory dollars in the March quarter.
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the March quarter fiscal year '15. Our backlog heading into the quarter is down sequentially. Although we're forecasting another strong quarter for our 28-nanometer products, we will be facing headwinds from aerospace and defense due to normal seasonality and a program-related timing. We expect both wired and wireless communications to be flat sequentially. Wireless sales will be impacted by the timing of the FDD, LTE deployments. We expect industrial and aerospace and defense segment to decrease for the reasons I mentioned earlier, offsetting flat sales to -- and measurement.
Broadcast, automotive and consumer is expected to be up driven by a rebound in broadcast and continue to advance to driver systems strength in automotive. As a result, we're expecting total sales for the March quarter to be down 2% to 6% sequentially. The midpoint of this guidance is predicated on a churn rate of approximately 61%. Gross margin is expected to be 68% to 69%.
Operating expenses in the March quarter is expected to be approximately $227 million, including $2.5 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles.
Other income and expense for the March quarter is expected to be a net expense of approximately $7 million, and the share count is expected to be approximately 270 million shares.
The tax rate for the March quarter is expected to be approximately 13%. Now I'd like to turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm clearly disappointed with our top line performance both during the December quarter and the guidance for the March quarter. Looking forward into fiscal year 2016, we are planning for a flat to low growth
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm clearly disappointed with our top line performance both during the December quarter and the guidance for the March quarter. Looking forward into fiscal year 2016, we are planning for a flat to low growth environment. The renewed revenue was from our 28-nanometer portfolio will be somewhat offset by uncertainty in the global communication spending and expect decline in key aerospace and defense programs.
And the positive side, Xilinx posted strong profitability in the December quarter, both gross margin and operating margin at 69.7% and 32%, respectively, or better than our expectations, contributing to earnings per share of $0.62.
Our cash flow continues to be healthy and were on a part to return more cash to shareholders in the form of both dividends and buybacks than we will generate in fiscal year '15.
The most significant highlight for the quarter is our new 28-nanometer revenue growth, which exceeded $150 million sequential increase of nearly 20%. We're anticipating 28-nanometer sales to continue to grow and exceed $160 million in the March quarter.
We also achieved several important milestones for our 20-nanometer portfolio. Our Kintex UltraScale devices became the industry's first 20-nanometer FPGA to move into volume production. Based on customer feedback, we continue to believe that we have an estimated 1-year lead over the competition. This technology leadersip is complemented by our Kintex UltraScale family, which is the industry's ASIC class 20-nanometer high-end product offering. The very high end of this family, we began shipping the industry's largest FPGA, which delivers over 4x the capacity of any competitive devices.
Finally, in the area of design software, we launched the SDX development environment. This is the second in the family of software defined -- environment, which we call SDX. This will greatly expand our user base to include broad community of systems and software engineers in both existing in new markets. This environment combines open C+ languages with an initial focus on the growing data center acceleration market.
Despite the top line challenges, I remain confident in Xilinx's strong technology leadership and market position. We're still in early phases of 28-nanometer revenue growth have already delivered the first production ASIC class 20-nanometer products, market expanding new SDX software defined program environment, and soon our 16-nanometer products that include multiprocessing association.
On Investor Day on March 10, we look forward to providing you more details on that our plans. I'd like to turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

componenttext: Moshe, just wanted to get a little more color, if you could, on your statement about, I think you said fiscal '16 being a flat to low growth environment. Can you give us again a little more detail on the puts and takes that lead you to that conclusion?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll be giving more details in March, but fundamentally, growth is driven for us by 28-nanometer, and we see clouds from communications and AND. So when you look at the combination of both of those, then we see as being generally speaking, flat to
componenttext: Well, we'll be giving more details in March, but fundamentally, growth is driven for us by 28-nanometer, and we see clouds from communications and AND. So when you look at the combination of both of those, then we see as being generally speaking, flat to low growth environment for fiscal year '16. That's probably as much as we can say at this point in time.

componenttext: Also on growth, in the past, Moshe, I think you've talked about rolling out some multiple, I believe, it was 2x the semi-industry. We are not seeing that now, and you're certainly setting more moderate expectations for fiscal '16. Should we think about this as a more sort of permanent reset to the longer-term growth potential that the company has? Or do you think this is a sort of soft spot that we will power through and eventually return to more meaningful growth?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The comparison with the rest of the semiconductor industry is a very difficult one to make because it has so many elements, and sometimes there's fast growing application like mobile, so that's not ours. But definitely, we do see things slowing down. I th
componenttext: The comparison with the rest of the semiconductor industry is a very difficult one to make because it has so many elements, and sometimes there's fast growing application like mobile, so that's not ours. But definitely, we do see things slowing down. I think we will shed more light on this in March and also be able to forecast the, more accurately, the period this will continue. But no, this is -- I look at it as not a global statement at this point in time. We'll be in a better position to answer it in March.

componenttext: Yes, I don't think we're making a lot of statement on that, Will. And I think I just like to highlight the headwinds from Aerospace & Defense,which are, in some cases, program related that are causing some of the headwinds for FY '16. And we still have a lot -- a good strong long-term view of our Aerospace & Defense participation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering, if you're looking at your Aerospace & Defense business, how much of this is a result of the Russian sanctions? Do you have visibility on how long these delays might have last? And is there any effect from the strong dollar factoring into ei
componenttext: I'm wondering, if you're looking at your Aerospace & Defense business, how much of this is a result of the Russian sanctions? Do you have visibility on how long these delays might have last? And is there any effect from the strong dollar factoring into either these category or even in the Communications segment?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So from a Russian perspective now, Aerospace & Defense, not really. I mean, we -- some of our communications business and some of our high-performance compute, which is in the other category in particular, that latter statement, we have some impact b
componenttext: Yes. So from a Russian perspective now, Aerospace & Defense, not really. I mean, we -- some of our communications business and some of our high-performance compute, which is in the other category in particular, that latter statement, we have some impact because of the Russian session, and that's been difficult for us to ship certain things into Russia and to get licenses for. So that has had some impact, I would say, but it's been relatively small impact, but it's utility helps, right, in this kind of environment relative to the stronger dollar, since we ship everything in U.S. dollars, we don't have an actual direct hedging affect. But obviously, our customers' customer and our distributor ship in local currencies. And while we have these questions, we haven't got any could answer that says, yes, should impacting our business. I know other businesses that are saying that to me that they're having some issues because effectively relative to the euro, our parts have gotten 20% more expensive over the last year or so. So the undoubtedly, it's going to have an impact to what I would call already a weaker environment in Europe than most other places.

componenttextpreview: My 1 question is in the China base station business, still some big targets for base station deployment among the carriers. Do you expect any other same sort of issues you had last year, so picosecond RF power amps suppliers?
componenttext: My 1 question is in the China base station business, still some big targets for base station deployment among the carriers. Do you expect any other same sort of issues you had last year, so picosecond RF power amps suppliers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, for the power amp perspective, I think there are some of the shortages that are going on, but that's really not the biggest gaining factor to our overall where this business, that's for sure. And I think specifically in China, that's probably 2 chang
componenttext: Yes, for the power amp perspective, I think there are some of the shortages that are going on, but that's really not the biggest gaining factor to our overall where this business, that's for sure. And I think specifically in China, that's probably 2 changes. So what we have been thinking in saying about it. One is the Phase 3 rollout, while it is, we still believe that it's beginning in the springtime, and that's progressing. The pace of that rollout seems to be a little slower than the previous 2 paces were in the past. We've seen a pretty high concentration over 1 quarter, 1.5 quarter of deployment, and that deployment seems to be at least the best that we can tell, maybe less than a little longer to that does base stations out, so a little longer time period. And the second thing, which is also on our mind among the FD is. I think we have articulated that the FD base stations would start to ship and this March quarter and then throughout the remainder of calendar '15. Right now the license is still not broadly -- Our modeling was essentially a 1-year lag from when what TD base station started shipping in volume, which was similar to the 3G deployment, and that really isn't happening right now. So we're kind of unpin the needles and waiting for this licenses to be led so that we can kind of model on when that might start.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned clouds from wireless. So is that really from just Asia? How much of that is non-Asia? And then the magnitude and timing on Europe, and perhaps even India, does that play into your forecast at all for next year?
componenttext: So you mentioned clouds from wireless. So is that really from just Asia? How much of that is non-Asia? And then the magnitude and timing on Europe, and perhaps even India, does that play into your forecast at all for next year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Correct me if I'm wrong, Moshe, I think the clouds around communication broadly, not just wireless. And what we see on the wireless side is weakness in the short term and deployment is going onto North America that has caused us some short-term shipm
componenttext: Yes. Correct me if I'm wrong, Moshe, I think the clouds around communication broadly, not just wireless. And what we see on the wireless side is weakness in the short term and deployment is going onto North America that has caused us some short-term shipment issues. Meaning, this quarter and this past quarter and next quarter, specifically, capital being diverted away from AT&T and Verizon and other places. But probably more prominent, Sprint is having more issues with rollout and so the OEMs that the ship to that supply investment LTE rollout have been cutting back orders because they've not been getting orders from Sprint as best as we can understand. And so that softness in North America is that some part of that, I would say early in the year. And then to your kind of follow through to the question related to Europe and India, our -- in mental model right now, we have not modeled either 1 of this geographies taking significant product at this point in time and probably into next year as well. We're still looking into that phenomena because we've seen those signs of that going in, I would say, growing in a very significant way at this time yet.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the members on 28-nanometer are growing again very rapidly, actually. And now if you look over the past 3 years, we believe that we've been consistently above 60% and it sort of peaked last year, probably at around 70% and it's still going to the 60
componenttext: Well, the members on 28-nanometer are growing again very rapidly, actually. And now if you look over the past 3 years, we believe that we've been consistently above 60% and it sort of peaked last year, probably at around 70% and it's still going to the 60% now. So I don't believe that it's a result of that. What the other thing we're seeing is 28-nanometer now all elements are growing. So the high end, the Virtex side, the Zynq side and the Artix side are growing, too. And in the past, a lot of growth came from the midrange, Kintex, and now it this expense, the breadth and depth of our product portfolio continues to give me confidence in that regard.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: One more thing. If you think about the way we cast the second half of this current fiscal year previously and what we think now, almost all of our shortfalls are around situations that are more demand related over older products than 7 Series, and that wo
componenttext: One more thing. If you think about the way we cast the second half of this current fiscal year previously and what we think now, almost all of our shortfalls are around situations that are more demand related over older products than 7 Series, and that would typically not indicate share loss because no one resigns an older product, right, so it's really around that. Doesn't seem to be around any of leading edge.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the gross margin side, obviously, we told you, the gross margin estimates are for Q4, so you can get that at FY '15. At FY '16, we're obviously not done with our planning at this point in time. We certainly are -- we have been running the company at
componenttext: So on the gross margin side, obviously, we told you, the gross margin estimates are for Q4, so you can get that at FY '15. At FY '16, we're obviously not done with our planning at this point in time. We certainly are -- we have been running the company at 68% to 70% range. That's our goal to do that as well. And so at this point in time, I wouldn't give you a -- certainly, I wouldn't give you a lower number to plan for gross margins. We do think that is our strength of our hand at 28-nanometer. And as good as that profile from a cross perspective us well, but I'll be reasonable about providing that range, at least for now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Vivek, and with regards to taking out the program continued and relationship with -- excellent. We're getting absolutely outstanding support. The design is very challenging design. And as a result, we expect for it to tape-out a couple of months later tha
componenttext: Vivek, and with regards to taking out the program continued and relationship with -- excellent. We're getting absolutely outstanding support. The design is very challenging design. And as a result, we expect for it to tape-out a couple of months later than we had originally expected. So this is we're probably looking at the May timeframe as opposed to the March time frame, which is our latest estimates of that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Carver for John. Just wanted to get a clarification on fiscal '16 wondering as being driven by sort of strong 20-nanometer but also by global comps and add some weakness in aero and defense. But if I look at sort of your sort of 40- and 45-na
componenttext: This is Ryan Carver for John. Just wanted to get a clarification on fiscal '16 wondering as being driven by sort of strong 20-nanometer but also by global comps and add some weakness in aero and defense. But if I look at sort of your sort of 40- and 45-nanometer, shares have been declining year-on-year for the last 4 quarters. And if I think about where 28-nanometer product goes, primarily it's been to the comps end markets. So I guess, how comfortable are you guys in digging the 20-nanometer is going to be able to drive this top performance in fiscal '16 given your commentary about your comps in aero and defense -- north half of your revenue next year -- I think you're 28-nanometer declines?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So 28-nanometer is a very broad product offering, and there's lots of element to it. The different component, different family that are targeted at specific different applications. It addresses all of the markets we're in. Absolutely all of them and
componenttext: Sure. So 28-nanometer is a very broad product offering, and there's lots of element to it. The different component, different family that are targeted at specific different applications. It addresses all of the markets we're in. Absolutely all of them and is an expansion play into additional areas. It would be correct to say that in the last year of production was driven by wireless comps, but it's not that's the only market that it has addressed. And if you look at the early shipments, they won't necessarily into comps at all, and they were in ASIC simulation. They were actually into some consumer market and all of this continue. What is happening is as the family of products has rolled out and has been extremely successful, more and more are moving into significant production and growth that you see now back to over 150 was actually driven by growth on the Virtex front, growth on the Zynq front and growth of the Artix front, and those addressed numerous markets not only comps. So it's broad, it's growing significantly, it's the fastest-growing product we've ever seen, and we're very confident that if you look at the numbers, then improved from $100 million to $380 million. If you look at our projection of over $160 million, it will come in at about $580 million for the year. We expect significant growth beyond that. So that is growing rapidly, and it's going to be the most successful and broadest portfolios we have. Having said that, when you look at 4G and 45, we continue to see strength. And on the 45, which is the low end product offering, the spot product offering, whereas we believe that 40-nanometer is no more or less peaking for us this point in time. In terms of market share on the 40, 45, it doesn't necessarily shrunk. It's sort of gone up and down over the past year, I would say. And that's our evaluation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ryan, if I just point it up a little bit. One of the biggest growth areas for this year and in the future is industrial, our industrial business as well as automotive. And those are both primarily driven by growth in our 45-nanometer in our Zynq prod
componenttext: Yes, Ryan, if I just point it up a little bit. One of the biggest growth areas for this year and in the future is industrial, our industrial business as well as automotive. And those are both primarily driven by growth in our 45-nanometer in our Zynq product families. And so if you think about the momentum that in those end markets have been clear over the last year or so, and the momentum we believe is going to continue, it is transitioning from other products into these new or higher ASPs, where we are getting a tremendous amount of benefit. And then also even in the wireless space, there's transition going on away from other products, Virtex 5s and 6s into the 7 Series and to big product products going into the wireless function, so we're going to see more growth in the 28-nanometer area, even in the comp thing. So comp is not totally here.

Yes, we already shipped quite a bit at the tail end of last fiscal year and the beginning of this fiscal year into the high-definition -- excuse me, the 4k, 2k UltraScale definition television. We also's are beginning to ship into old that technology-based elevation as well, and we do expect to be in the television business longer than some of our previous generations where we're looking for the initial of HDN get paid out rather quickly. We seem to have quite a bit of activity going on across all the current manufacturers for that business. So that is a good opportunity for us, yes.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, just want a clarification on the FinFET comment you made. Is this an issue emanating from the difficulty in the -- you're having? Or is it having from the Xilinx side? And just a quick follow-up. What's the timing from tape-out to when we should ex
componenttext: Moshe, just want a clarification on the FinFET comment you made. Is this an issue emanating from the difficulty in the -- you're having? Or is it having from the Xilinx side? And just a quick follow-up. What's the timing from tape-out to when we should expect production volume?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there are no issues with -- they've had numerous design already. They've given us full support. The design, whenever you encounter a new generation of products, tends to unearth progress that you do not anticipate. And as a result, the closing of
componenttext: Okay. So there are no issues with -- they've had numerous design already. They've given us full support. The design, whenever you encounter a new generation of products, tends to unearth progress that you do not anticipate. And as a result, the closing of all of the issues are taking a little longer, plus the challenges related to the signing for FinFET transistors are more significant. So it's not a TSMC challenge or issue at all. It's just our ability to finish the design with their support. After -- if you look at our business, typically, what sort of happens is tape it out, you get that back after a few months, you go through a lengthy evaluation cycle and then you move it into production, which point in time, it takes 2 to 3 years until it reaches high-volume production. So it sort of depends. So it sort of depends, if you look at 28-nanometer, we reached $100 million production, I think, 3 years after we taped out the product.

componenttext: Yes. From a spending profile, it certainly not going to -- were update you more on what we think about FY '16 there. It's causing us a little bit of headwind and we've been able to manage it through a variety of different techniques and decisions that we made. So I'm not too worried about any sort of bigger ramp and spending coming on right. And relative to capital allocation, again, it is based on a lot of factors, including what our plans for excess cash would be beyond returning to shareholders. But our primary situation is to continue to think about dividend first and pay for that and the share repurchases opportunistic as what I would -- what vicinity visibility I had today for the future? I don't think we would be changing that policy.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, Blayne, the short-term issues on the wireless business really is not as much China as is the rest of the world for us, and some of the system that's going on. What I can tell you is what we believe our customers are saying. And since we have the
componenttext: Yes. So, Blayne, the short-term issues on the wireless business really is not as much China as is the rest of the world for us, and some of the system that's going on. What I can tell you is what we believe our customers are saying. And since we have the lion's sharing among the share of companies in support of the -- rollout, that has been something that has supplanted relative to our expectations for this quarter, and we believe that leads to the forecast for Q4 as well. The China aspect, we actually had China grow as we anticipated, so that wasn't necessarily the short-term issue. But we are -- we did also, I believe, signal, we were a lot more bullish on wireless of the growth in China because the Phase 3 rollout in March. And while we're not seeing declines there, we are seeing the same relative acceleration of growth in China that we had originally set. So it's not like wireless business is going away, it's just that is that increasing to the point that we had set. With respect to FY '16, I think Moshe was trying to characterize the cloud overall communications. Meaning, a global rough spot for global spending, not specifically targeting some geography in wireless. So we're not really going to give guidance right now in our wireless for FY '16 we'll do that in March.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, more of philosophical question. I'm just looking at the business over the last 3 years and based on your guidance for fiscal '16, on average, there isn't a whole lot of growth here. I think in fiscal '10, you grew, I mean, a couple of years ago, yo
componenttext: Moshe, more of philosophical question. I'm just looking at the business over the last 3 years and based on your guidance for fiscal '16, on average, there isn't a whole lot of growth here. I think in fiscal '10, you grew, I mean, a couple of years ago, you grew about 10% in fiscal '14. But outside of that -- so my question is, obviously, R&D is running at fairly high. OpEx is running close to 40%. As the leader, I'm wondering, does is still make sense to chase of the Moore's Law? I mean,'s the part of the business that going to continue to invest -- Moore's Law? The question is, what would make sense to kind of slowed down a little bit in the kind of bringing the OpEx number down?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, so that's a good philosophical question, which is, we could spend hours debating. But that may give you my 2-minute response here. You're right in pointing out if you look back that the growth has not been sustained. So for Xilinx, it was -- grew to
componenttext: Okay, so that's a good philosophical question, which is, we could spend hours debating. But that may give you my 2-minute response here. You're right in pointing out if you look back that the growth has not been sustained. So for Xilinx, it was -- grew to $1.8 billion, was at $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion for several years then took a jump to the $2.4-ish billion level and has been at that point for more years than we believe would stay there, and that clearly is disappointing. Having said that, we do believe that this is a business as the semiconductor industry is maturing, being at the leading edge enables us to capture a larger Sam. And in order to do that, we are investing. In order to exploit that and provide those solution. Now the first node where this was possible in a big way, we believe, is 28-nanometer. And we do see and we will understand that it's incumbent upon us to show the proof. We do see in quite few cases more ASICS going away and customers transitioning into FPGAs and to a lesser degree, but nonetheless, happening, too. Some of the traditional ASSPs provider can no longer keep up that provides an opportunity for us. And Artix do that, we need to have both different product and a big investment in the software enablement, to enable us to capture those markets. We're making those investments now and we believe that the return is still ahead of us. And an example would be the Zynq product line, which enables us to participate in a bigger way in automotive, a market where we only had a very French participation in the past. So I can't argue with your numbers, right. The numbers are what the numbers are. But I fervently believe that the opportunity is still ahead of us to capture these markets, and we'll give you more insights into that and the March timeframe. Excellent question and thank you for asking it.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on 28, 20 nanometer. On 28, where we are in the cycle now versus 20-nanometer peaks? And for 20-nanometer down the road, do you expect that this a similar ramp it is somehow the same?
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on 28, 20 nanometer. On 28, where we are in the cycle now versus 20-nanometer peaks? And for 20-nanometer down the road, do you expect that this a similar ramp it is somehow the same?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 28, our position has evolved and actually think it's going to peak later than we originally expected and to last longer than we had originally expected. Potentially, with a slightly smarter peak, but actually similar area under the curve, so yes. And w
componenttext: So 28, our position has evolved and actually think it's going to peak later than we originally expected and to last longer than we had originally expected. Potentially, with a slightly smarter peak, but actually similar area under the curve, so yes. And we're still years away from that peak. And we're seeing a lot of markets that are addressed by our products just starting out to move into production, and probably have another 2 or 3 years before they move into production so -- which generates the peak is still years away. 20-nanometer, the way we look at it is 20 and 16 together are -- should be equivalent to Kintex in terms of the capabilities, and that's because they're coming very close together in terms of introduction. And so if you -- there's a previous question that I managed to confuse everyone with my response, but it took 3 years to reach $100 million on 28-nanometer, and that's a quarterly number. And our expectation is if you look the combination of 20 and 16, and if you can set up ship them back to start at the same time, then you should hopefully reach the same number with the same level of success at that point in time. Now we'll see if that sort of happens, and it will. But if you look at currency alone, it won't match what Kintex has done. If you look at 16 alone, it won't match what 28 has done. The expectation is, between the 2 of them, we should come close to what 28 has done, more or less similar timeframe.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is John, and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha. Thank you. Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our conference ca
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and actual results may differ materially. We refer you to documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Profitability remained strong during the quarter, but sales were lower than anticipated, declining 2% during the December quarter. The primary weakness was driven by broadcast and wireless communications end markets. 28-nanometer sales re
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Profitability remained strong during the quarter, but sales were lower than anticipated, declining 2% during the December quarter. The primary weakness was driven by broadcast and wireless communications end markets. 28-nanometer sales represented 1 of the bright spots of the quarter with sales increasing nearly 20%, sequentially. All members of this product family grew with Zynq, Virtex and Artix all posting double-digit growth rates.
From an end market perspective, sales to communications customers declined 3% sequentially with flat wired sales and a decline in wireless sales. Wireless sales were impacted by weaker sales from non-China regions, while our China wireless business increased in line with expectations.
Industrial and aerospace and defense sales increased as expected with strong defense sales offsetting declines in industrial, scientific and medical. Broadcast, consumer and automotive sales declined due to weaker broadcast sales, which were driven by weak purchasing activity from a couple of large customers. Automotive sales were better than expected as several new Advanced Driver Assistance programs began to ramp.
In terms of linearity, the month of October and November were in line with our expectations, and the month of December progressively weakened. Turns were 44% for the quarter. Gross margin of 69.7% was better than expected as a result of customer and product mix. Total operating expenses were $224 million, including $2 million of amortization-related expenses. This was $6 million lower than our guided -- than guided, resulting in operating income of 32%. Other income and expense was a net expense of $4 million, better than forecasted, mainly due to higher interest income from our investment portfolio.
Net income for the quarter was $168 million or $0.62 per share, including a $0.02 per diluted share benefit primarily related to the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Operating cash flow for the September quarter -- excuse me, the December quarter was $291 million before $6 million in CapEx. Strong cash flow during the quarter was positively impacted by a net improvement in working capital led by the timing impact of accounts receivable.
Diluted shares for the quarter were 274 million shares. This was a bit higher than forecasted as result of the higher stock price. There was a 7.8 million share dilutive effect from our convertible note.
We are committed to returning cash to shareholders. During the quarter, we continued to aggressively buy back stock, repurchasing 4 million shares for $175 million. We also paid $76 million in quarterly dividends. For the fiscal year, thus far, we have returned over $700 million to shareholders in the form of repurchase and dividend, $80 million more than we generated in operating cash flow.
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments increased $28 million to approximately $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed rate debt resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion.  Inventory dollars decreased by $16 million during the quarter. We plan to continue to reduce inventory dollars in the March quarter.
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the March quarter fiscal year '15. Our backlog heading into the quarter is down sequentially. Although we are forecasting another strong quarter for our 28-nanometer products, we will be facing headwinds from aerospace and defense due to normal seasonality and a program-related timing. We expect both wired and wireless communications to be flat sequentially. Wireless sales will be impacted by the timing of the FDD LTE deployments. We expect industrial and aerospace and defense segment to decrease for the reasons I mentioned earlier, offsetting flat sales to ISM and test, measurement.
Broadcast, automotive and consumer is expected to be up driven by a rebound in broadcast and continued Advanced Driver Assistance strength in automotive. As a result, we're expecting total sales for the March quarter to be down 2% to 6% sequentially. The midpoint of this guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 51%. Gross margin is expected to be 68% to 69%. Operating expenses in the March quarter is expected to be approximately $227 million, including $2.5 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. Other income and expense for the March quarter is expected to be a net expense of approximately $7 million, and the share count is expected to be approximately 270 million shares. The tax rate for the March quarter is expected to be approximately 13%.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm clearly disappointed with our top line performance both during the December quarter and the guidance for the March quarter. Looking forward into fiscal year 2016, we are planning for a flat to low growth
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm clearly disappointed with our top line performance both during the December quarter and the guidance for the March quarter. Looking forward into fiscal year 2016, we are planning for a flat to low growth environment. The renewed revenue growth from our 28-nanometer portfolio will be somewhat offset by uncertainty in global communication spending and expected declines in key aerospace and defense programs.
On the positive side, Xilinx posted strong profitability in the December quarter. Both gross margin and operating margin at 69.7% and 32%, respectively, were better than our expectations, contributing to earnings per share of $0.62. Our cash flow continues to be healthy, and we're on a path to return more cash to shareholders in the form of both dividends and buybacks than we will generate in fiscal year '15.
The most significant highlight for the quarter is our new 28-nanometer revenue growth, which exceeded $150 million sequential increase of nearly 20%. We're anticipating 28-nanometer sales to continue to grow and exceed $160 million in the March quarter.
We also achieved several important milestones for our 20-nanometer portfolio. Our Kintex UltraScale devices became the industry's first 20-nanometer FPGAs to move into volume production. Based on customer feedback, we continue to believe that we have an estimated 1-year lead over the competition. This technology leadership is complemented by our Virtex UltraScale family, which is the industry's ASIC-class 20-nanometer high-end product offering. At the very high end of this family, we began shipping the industry's largest FPGA, which delivers over 4x the capacity of any competitive devices.
Finally, in the area of design software, we launched the SDAccel development environment. This is the second in a family of software defined development environment, which we call SDx. This will greatly expand our user base to include a broad community of systems and software engineers in both existing and new markets. This environment combines OpenCL, C and C++ languages with an initial focus on the growing data center acceleration market.
Despite the top line challenges, I remain confident in Xilinx's strong technology leadership and market position. We're still in early phases of 28-nanometer revenue growth, have already delivered the first production ASIC-class 20-nanometer products, our market-expanding new SDx software defined programming environment and soon, our 16-nanometer products that include multi-processing associates. At our Investor Day on March 10, we look forward to providing you more details outlining our plans.
Like to turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ross Seymore of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I just wanted to get a little more color, if you could, on your statement about -- I think you said fiscal '16 being a flat to low growth environment. Can you give us again a little more detail on the puts and takes that lead you to that conclusion
componenttext: Moshe, I just wanted to get a little more color, if you could, on your statement about -- I think you said fiscal '16 being a flat to low growth environment. Can you give us again a little more detail on the puts and takes that lead you to that conclusion?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll be giving more details in March, but fundamentally, growth is driven for us by 28-nanometer, and we see clouds from communications and A&D. And so when you look at the combination of both of those, then we see it as being a, generally speaking
componenttext: Well, we'll be giving more details in March, but fundamentally, growth is driven for us by 28-nanometer, and we see clouds from communications and A&D. And so when you look at the combination of both of those, then we see it as being a, generally speaking, flat to low growth environment for fiscal year '16. That's probably as much as we can say at this point in time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Also on growth, in the past, Moshe, I think you've talked about growing at some multiple. I believe, it was 2x the semi-industry. We're not seeing that now and you're certainly setting more moderate expectations for fiscal '16. Should we think about this as a more sort of permanent reset to the longer-term growth potential that the company has? Or do you think this is a sort of soft spot that we will power through eventually and return to more meaningful growth?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The comparison with the rest of the semiconductor industry is a very difficult one to make because it has so many elements, and sometimes there's fast growing applications like mobile, so that's not ours. But definitely, we do see things slowing down. I t
componenttext: The comparison with the rest of the semiconductor industry is a very difficult one to make because it has so many elements, and sometimes there's fast growing applications like mobile, so that's not ours. But definitely, we do see things slowing down. I think we will shed more light on this in March and also be able to forecast the -- more accurately the period that this will continue. But no, this is -- I would look at it as not a global statement at this point in time. We'll be in a better position to answer it in March.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we're making a long-term statement on that, Will. And I think I'd just like to highlight the headwinds from aerospace and defense, which are, in some cases, program related that are causing some of the headwinds for FY '16, and we still
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we're making a long-term statement on that, Will. And I think I'd just like to highlight the headwinds from aerospace and defense, which are, in some cases, program related that are causing some of the headwinds for FY '16, and we still have a lot -- a good, strong long-term view of our aerospace and defense participation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Gauna from JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Gauna from JMP Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering, as you look at your aerospace and defense business, how much of this is a result of the Russian sanctions? Do you have visibility on how long these delays might last? And is there any effect from the strong dollar factoring into either this
componenttext: I'm wondering, as you look at your aerospace and defense business, how much of this is a result of the Russian sanctions? Do you have visibility on how long these delays might last? And is there any effect from the strong dollar factoring into either this category or even in the communications segment?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So from a Russia perspective, no. In aerospace and defense, not really. I mean, we -- some of our communications business and some of our high-performance compute, which is in the other category, in particular, that latter statement, we've had some i
componenttext: Yes. So from a Russia perspective, no. In aerospace and defense, not really. I mean, we -- some of our communications business and some of our high-performance compute, which is in the other category, in particular, that latter statement, we've had some impact because of the Russian sanctions, and that's been difficult for us to ship certain things into Russia and to get licenses for. So that has had some impact, but I would say it's been relatively small impact. But it's certainly anything helps, right, in this kind of environment, so we've had some impact from that. Relative to the stronger dollar, since we ship everything in U.S. dollars, we don't have an actual direct hedging effect, but obviously, our customers' customer and our distributor does ship in local currencies. And while -- when we've asked those questions, we haven't gotten any answer that says, "Yes, it's really impacting our business." I know of other businesses that are saying that to me that they're having some issues because effectively, relative to the euro, our parts have gotten 20% more expensive over the last year or so. So undoubtedly, it's going to have an impact to what I would call already a weaker environment in Europe than most other places.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Ing from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. My one question is in the China base station business, still some big targets for base station deployments this year among the carriers. Do you expect any other same sort of bomb kit issues you had last year, supply constraints in RF power amps by th
componenttext: Yes. My one question is in the China base station business, still some big targets for base station deployments this year among the carriers. Do you expect any other same sort of bomb kit issues you had last year, supply constraints in RF power amps by the suppliers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the -- from the power amp perspective, I think there are still some of the shortages that are going on, but that's really not the biggest gating factor to our overall wireless business. That's for sure. And I think what's specifically going on in
componenttext: Yes, so the -- from the power amp perspective, I think there are still some of the shortages that are going on, but that's really not the biggest gating factor to our overall wireless business. That's for sure. And I think what's specifically going on in China, there's probably 2 changes to what we have been thinking and saying about it. One is the Phase 3 rollout. While it is -- we still believe that it's beginning in the springtime and that's progressing, the pace of that rollout seems to be a little slower than the previous 2 phases were in the past. We've seen a pretty high concentration over 1 quarter, 1.5 quarters of deployment, and that deployment seems to be, at least the best as we can tell, maybe lasting a little longer to get those base stations out, so a little bit longer time period. And the second thing, which is also looming on our minds, is around the FD licenses. I think we had articulated that the FD base stations would start to ship in this March quarter and then throughout the remainder of calendar '15. Right now the licenses still are not broadly let, and our modeling was essentially a 1-year lag from when the TD base station started shipping in volume, which was similar to the 3G deployment. And that really isn't happening right now. So we're kind of on pins and needles here waiting for those licenses to be let, so we can kind of model when that might start.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher Rolland from FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher Rolland from FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned clouds from wireless. So is that really from just Asia? How much of that is non-Asia? And then the magnitude and timing on Europe and perhaps, even India, does that play into your forecast at all for next year?
componenttext: So you mentioned clouds from wireless. So is that really from just Asia? How much of that is non-Asia? And then the magnitude and timing on Europe and perhaps, even India, does that play into your forecast at all for next year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I -- correct me if I'm wrong here, Moshe, but I think the clouds are on communications broadly, not just wireless. And what we see on the wireless side is weakness in the short term in deployments going in North America that has caused us some sho
componenttext: Yes, so I -- correct me if I'm wrong here, Moshe, but I think the clouds are on communications broadly, not just wireless. And what we see on the wireless side is weakness in the short term in deployments going in North America that has caused us some short-term shipment issues, meaning this quarter and this past quarter and next quarter, specifically capital being diverted away from AT&T and Verizon and other places. But probably more prominent, Sprint is having more issues with rollouts, and so the OEMs that we ship to that supply the Sprint LTE rollout have been cutting back orders because they've not been getting orders from Sprint as best as we can understand. And so that softness in North America is -- some part of that, I would say, early in the year. And then to your kind of a follow-through to the question related to Europe and India, our -- in our mental model right now we have not modeled either one of those geographies taking significant product at this point in time and probably into next year as well. We're still looking into that phenomena because we see no signs of that going in -- I would say, growing in a very significant way at this time yet.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Danely of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Danely of Citigroup.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, looking to your confidence that this is purely a demand problem versus some share loss.
componenttext: I guess, looking to your confidence that this is purely a demand problem versus some share loss.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the numbers on 28-nanometer are growing again very rapidly actually. And if you look over the past 3 years, we believe that we've been consistently above 60%, and it sort of peaked last year probably at around 70%, and it's still well into the 60s n
componenttext: Well, the numbers on 28-nanometer are growing again very rapidly actually. And if you look over the past 3 years, we believe that we've been consistently above 60%, and it sort of peaked last year probably at around 70%, and it's still well into the 60s now. So I don't believe that it's a result of that. What the other thing we're seeing is 28-nanometer now all elements of it are growing, so the high end, the Virtex side, the Zynq side and the Artix side, are growing, too. And in the past, a lot of growth came from the mid-range Kintex, and now as this expands, the breadth and depth of our product portfolio continues to give me confidence in that regard.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just -- one more thing. If you think about the way we weigh cast the second half of this current fiscal year previously and where we think now, almost all of our shortfalls are around situations that are more demand related over older products th
componenttext: And I'll just -- one more thing. If you think about the way we weigh cast the second half of this current fiscal year previously and where we think now, almost all of our shortfalls are around situations that are more demand related over older products than 7 Series, and that would typically not indicate share loss because no one redesigns an older product, right? So it's really around that. Doesn't seem to be around any of the leading edge.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I actually had a clarification on a question. On the clarification, maybe if you could also give us some more color on how we should think about gross margins given the weakness in the mix. Is it better to think gross margins could be, say, 67%, 68% than
componenttext: I actually had a clarification on a question. On the clarification, maybe if you could also give us some more color on how we should think about gross margins given the weakness in the mix. Is it better to think gross margins could be, say, 67%, 68% than the 69%, 70%? And then, Moshe, for my question, if you could just give us the status of your 16-nanometer FinFET engagement with the TSMC, what is the status there? And do you expect to get products out on time this year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the gross margin side, obviously, we told you what the gross margin estimates are for Q4, so you can get at FY '15. At FY '16, we're obviously not done with our planning at this point in time. We certainly are -- we have been running the company at
componenttext: So on the gross margin side, obviously, we told you what the gross margin estimates are for Q4, so you can get at FY '15. At FY '16, we're obviously not done with our planning at this point in time. We certainly are -- we have been running the company at 68% to 70% range. That's our goal, to do that as well, and so at this point in time, I wouldn't give you a -- certainly, I wouldn't give you a lower number to plan for gross margins. We do think that with the strength of our hand at 28-nanometer and as good as that profile is for us from a cost perspective as well, I'm feeling reasonable about providing that range at least for now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Vivek, and with regards to taking out, the program continues and the relationship with TSMC is excellent. We're getting absolutely outstanding support. The design is a very challenging design, and as a result, we expect for it to tape out a couple of mont
componenttext: Vivek, and with regards to taking out, the program continues and the relationship with TSMC is excellent. We're getting absolutely outstanding support. The design is a very challenging design, and as a result, we expect for it to tape out a couple of months later than we had originally expected. So this is -- we're probably looking at the May time frame as opposed to the March time frame, which was our latest estimate for that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Carver in for John. Just wanted to get a clarification. You gave some color on fiscal '16 as being driven by sort of a strong 20-nanometer but offset by global comms and some weakness in aero and defense. But if I look at sort of your 40- and
componenttext: This is Ryan Carver in for John. Just wanted to get a clarification. You gave some color on fiscal '16 as being driven by sort of a strong 20-nanometer but offset by global comms and some weakness in aero and defense. But if I look at sort of your 40- and 45-nanometer business, I mean, share has been declining year-on-year for the last 4 quarters. And if I think about sort of where 28-nanometer product goes, primarily it's been into the comms end market. So I guess, how comfortable are you guys in thinking the 28-nanometer is going to be able to drive this outperformance in fiscal '16 given your commentary about your comms and aero and defense sort of equating to probably north of half of your revenue for the year next year and then continued 40-nanometer declines?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So 28-nanometer is a very broad and deep product offering, and there is lots of elements to it. And there are different components, different families that are targeted at specific different applications. It addresses all of the markets we're in, ab
componenttext: Sure. So 28-nanometer is a very broad and deep product offering, and there is lots of elements to it. And there are different components, different families that are targeted at specific different applications. It addresses all of the markets we're in, absolutely all of them and is an expansion play into additional areas. It would be correct to say that in the last year of production was driven by wireless comms, but it's not that, that's the only market that it has addressed. And if you look at the early shipments, they weren't necessarily into comms at all. They were in ASIC emulation. They were actually into some consumer markets, and all of these continue. What is happening is as the family of products has rolled out and has been extremely successful, more and more are moving into significant production and growth that you see now back to over $150 million, was actually driven by growth on the Virtex front, growth on the Zynq front and growth on the Artix front. And those addressed numerous markets, not only comms. So it's broad. It's growing significantly. It's the fastest growing product we've ever seen, and we're very confident that if you look at the numbers when it grew from $100 million to $380 million, if you look at our projection of over $160 million, it'll come in at about $580 million for the year. We expect significant growth beyond that. So that is growing rapidly, and it's going to be the most successful and broadest portfolio we have. Having said that, when you look at 40 and 45, we continue to see strength. And on the 45, which is the low-end product offering, the Spartan product offering, whereas we believe that 40-nanometer is more or less peaking for us at this point in time. In terms of market share on 40, 45, it hasn't necessarily shrunk. It's sort of gone up and down over the past year, I would say, and that's our valuation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ryan, if I'd just point out a little bit. Just one of our bigger growth areas for this year and in the future is industrial, our industrial business as well as automotive, and those are both primarily driven by growth in our 45-nanometer and in our Z
componenttext: Yes. Ryan, if I'd just point out a little bit. Just one of our bigger growth areas for this year and in the future is industrial, our industrial business as well as automotive, and those are both primarily driven by growth in our 45-nanometer and in our Zynq product families. And so if you think about the momentum that in those end markets have been clear over the last year or so and those -- that momentum, we believe, is going to continue, it is transitioning from older products into these newer higher-valued products at higher ASPs, where we are getting a tremendous amount of benefit. And then also, even within the wireless space, there's a transitioning going on away from older products, Virtex-5s and 6s into the 7 Series and to big Zynq products going into the wireless function. And so we're going to see more growth in the 28-nanometer area even in the comms thing. So don't write off comms totally here.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Back when HDTVs were ramping, there was demand for FPGAs into TVs and also in broadcasting, which helped your consumer business. Do you expect a similar trend to happen with the rise of 4K TVs? And do you see any interest they have also on OEMs? And what
componenttext: Back when HDTVs were ramping, there was demand for FPGAs into TVs and also in broadcasting, which helped your consumer business. Do you expect a similar trend to happen with the rise of 4K TVs? And do you see any interest they have also on OEMs? And what would be the timing on that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tristan, this is Jon. Yes, we have actually already shipped quite a bit at the tail end of last fiscal year and the beginning of this fiscal year into the high-definition -- or excuse me, the 4K2K or ultra-high-definition television. We also are begi
componenttext:
Yes. Tristan, this is Jon. Yes, we have actually already shipped quite a bit at the tail end of last fiscal year and the beginning of this fiscal year into the high-definition -- or excuse me, the 4K2K or ultra-high-definition television. We also are beginning to ship into OLED-technology-based televisions as well, and we do expect to be in the television business longer than some of our previous generations where we were in for the initial of HD and the initial
[Audio Gap]
And then got phased out rather quickly. We seem to have quite a bit of activity going on across all the current manufacturers for that business. So that is a good opportunity for us, yes.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava from BMO Capital.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I just had a clarification on the FinFET comment you made. Is this an issue emanating from the difficulty, in you're opinion, TSMC having? Or is it coming from the Xilinx side? And just a quick follow-up. What's the timing from tape-out to when we
componenttext: Moshe, I just had a clarification on the FinFET comment you made. Is this an issue emanating from the difficulty, in you're opinion, TSMC having? Or is it coming from the Xilinx side? And just a quick follow-up. What's the timing from tape-out to when we should expect production volume?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there are no issues with TSMC. They've had numerous tape-outs already. They're giving us full support. The design, whenever you encounter a new generation of product, tends to unearth problems that you did not anticipate, and as a result, the clo
componenttext: Okay. So there are no issues with TSMC. They've had numerous tape-outs already. They're giving us full support. The design, whenever you encounter a new generation of product, tends to unearth problems that you did not anticipate, and as a result, the closing of all of these issues was taking a little longer, plus the challenges related to design for FinFET transistors are more significant. So it's not a TSMC challenge or issue at all. It's just our ability to finish the design with their support. After -- if you look at our business, typically, what sort of happens is tape it out. You get it back after a few months. You go through a lengthy evaluation cycle, and then you move it into production, which, point in time, it takes 2 to 3 years until it reaches high-volume production. So it sort of depends. If you look at 28-nanometer, we reached $100 million of production, I think, 3 years after we taped out the product.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I wanted to ask a longer-term question, to the extent you can comment today ahead of the Analyst Day, that would be very helpful color. Just I don't know if there's any change longer term on how you're thinking ab
componenttext: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I wanted to ask a longer-term question, to the extent you can comment today ahead of the Analyst Day, that would be very helpful color. Just I don't know if there's any change longer term on how you're thinking about OpEx profile of the company as we transition to [indiscernible] environment or in the capital allocation profile of the company as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. From a spending profile, certainly not going to -- we'll update you more -- a lot more about what we think about FY '16 there. But Moshe's comments around next year's flat -- positioning the company from a flat to low growth environment, we're certai
componenttext: Yes. From a spending profile, certainly not going to -- we'll update you more -- a lot more about what we think about FY '16 there. But Moshe's comments around next year's flat -- positioning the company from a flat to low growth environment, we're certainly very aware of what that means, and we are working towards spending goals to match that top process. But from a longer-term perspective, R&D intensity as we have these nodes go more rapidly closer together until maybe we can get to 10-nanometer, it is causing us a little bit of headwind. But we've been able to manage it through a variety of different techniques and decisions that we made, so I'm not too worried about any sort of bigger ramp in spending coming on right. And relative to capital allocation, again, it's -- it is based on a lot of factors, including what our plans for excess cash would be beyond returning to shareholders. But our primary situation is to continue to think about dividend first and pay for that and then the share repurchase as opportunistic. As what I -- what visibility I have today about the future, I don't think we'll be changing that policy.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
