headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to the wireless segment with  the margin guidance will be down 4 quarters in a row. So you talked about some end market issues, but I'm not aware of other companies seeing these declines. So I was just curious, as you look back, did
componenttext: I just want to go back to the wireless segment with  the margin guidance will be down 4 quarters in a row. So you talked about some end market issues, but I'm not aware of other companies seeing these declines. So I was just curious, as you look back, did you -- what's really causing this? Did you see ASIC replacements? Is there a mix shift to the midrange? And than in that fiscal '16 guidance, you talked about uncertain outlook. How much are you expecting this business to come back for you within that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Blayne, the short-term issues on the wireless business, really, is not as much China has been -- the rest of the world for us, and some are the softnesses that's going on. All I can do is tell you what we believe our customers are saying. And sinc
componenttext: Yes. So Blayne, the short-term issues on the wireless business, really, is not as much China has been -- the rest of the world for us, and some are the softnesses that's going on. All I can do is tell you what we believe our customers are saying. And since we have the lion's share of the share among, PLD companies in support of the Sprint rollout, that has been something that had disappointed relative to our expectations for this quarter, and we believe that bleeds into the forecast for Q4 as well. The China aspect, we actually had China grow as we anticipated, so that wasn't necessarily the short-term issue. But we are -- we did also, I believe, signal we were a lot more bullish on wireless growth in China because of Phase 3 rollout in March. And while we're not seeing declines there, we aren't seeing the same relative acceleration of growth in China that we had originally said. So it's not like our wireless business is going away. It's just that it's not increasing to the point that we had said. With respect to FY '16, I think Moshe was trying to characterize the cloud overall in communications, meaning a global rough spot for global spending, not specifically targeting some geography in wireless. So we're not really going to give a guidance right now on our thoughts on wireless for FY '16. We'll do that on March.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri of CLSA Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri of CLSA Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, more a philosophical question. I'm just looking at the business over the last 3 years, and based on your guidance for fiscal '16, on average, there isn't a whole lot of growth here. I think in fiscal '10, you grew -- I mean, a couple of years ago,
componenttext: Moshe, more a philosophical question. I'm just looking at the business over the last 3 years, and based on your guidance for fiscal '16, on average, there isn't a whole lot of growth here. I think in fiscal '10, you grew -- I mean, a couple of years ago, you grew about 10% fiscal '14. But outside of that -- so my question is, obviously, R&D is running at -- fairly high. OpEx is running close to 40%. As the leader, I am wondering does it still make sense to chase of the Moore's Law. I mean, is it part of the business that you have to continue to invest in Moore's Law? And my question is why wouldn't it make sense to kind of slow it down a little bit and kind of bringing that OpEx number down.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that's a great philosophical question, which is -- we could spend hours debating, but let me give you my 2-minute response here. You're right in pointing out, if you look back, that the growth has not been sustained. So for Xilinx, it was -- grew
componenttext: Okay. So that's a great philosophical question, which is -- we could spend hours debating, but let me give you my 2-minute response here. You're right in pointing out, if you look back, that the growth has not been sustained. So for Xilinx, it was -- grew to $1.8 billion, was at $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion for several years, then took a jump to the $2.4-ish billion level and has been at that point for more years than we believed it would stay there. And that clearly is disappointing. Having said that, we do believe that this is a business -- as the semiconductor industry is maturing, being at the leading edge enables us to capture a larger SAM. And in order to do that, we're investing, in order to exploit that and provide those solutions. Now the first node where this was possible in a big way, we believe, is 28-nanometer, and we do see and we will -- we understand that it's incumbent upon us to show the proof. We do see in quite a few cases more ASICs going away and customers transitioning into FPGAs and to a lesser degree, but nonetheless, this is happening, too. Some of the traditional ASSP provider can no longer keep up, and that provides an opportunity for us. In order to do that, we need to have both different product and a big investment in the software enablement to enable us to capture those markets. We're making those investments now and we believe that the return is still ahead of us. And an example would be the Zynq product line, which enables us to participate in a bigger way in automotive, a market where we only had a very fringed participation in the past. So I can't argue with your numbers, right? The numbers are what the numbers are. But I fervently believe that the opportunity is still ahead of us to capture these markets, and we'll give you more insights into that in the March time frame. But excellent question and thank you for asking it.

componenttext: Moshe, I just wanted to throw in another question on the communications discussion. In terms of that end market, you historically haven't provided longer-term guidance, and now you're giving us a little bit more of an outlook from a longer-term perspective. And I'm wondering if some of that is driven by what you're seeing in addition to these clouds around the design environment. Has anything changed in the design environment from your big customers that -- globally that sell into the service providers as it relates to FPGAs, would you say? Or do you think that once you get by fiscal 2016 that you can still think about some of the CAGR growth rates that you guys have discussed historically around the various communications markets?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we believe there is opportunities for growth in both wired communications and wireless communications. We will try to size those. Wired, in particular, has been frustrating for us. For several years now we've predicted growth, projected growth, and it
componenttext: So we believe there is opportunities for growth in both wired communications and wireless communications. We will try to size those. Wired, in particular, has been frustrating for us. For several years now we've predicted growth, projected growth, and it hasn't happened. Even the 28-nanometer on the wired side, it's taking longer for those very significant designs to translate into revenue. Nonetheless, the opportunity is there, and the wired market is not going away. But we'll give you a deeper and more accurate response in March.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think from a design environment -- so I think, as Moshe said earlier, that we are seeing ASICs being replaced. We are participating in the aggregation that's going on as there's continued consolidation in the infrastructure business. We are still seeing
componenttext: I think from a design environment -- so I think, as Moshe said earlier, that we are seeing ASICs being replaced. We are participating in the aggregation that's going on as there's continued consolidation in the infrastructure business. We are still seeing lots of opportunities for us out there.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And things like the SDx environments, both design environments, which specifically targeted to enable us to address those markets more smoothly than we -- and more efficiently than we have in the past. So yes, there is a need to provide somewhat of a
componenttext: Yes. And things like the SDx environments, both design environments, which specifically targeted to enable us to address those markets more smoothly than we -- and more efficiently than we have in the past. So yes, there is a need to provide somewhat of a different approach in order to expand the population of the designers we address, and that includes communications but is not only limited to communications.

componenttext: You talked about a slow growth environment, but you've also got the third highest gross margins in semis after Linear and PMC-Sierra. So have you thought about going after some new volume applications, perhaps, with some price elasticity?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well -- so Ian, yes, we definitely have a posture here that it's about operating profit dollars with respect to that. So it's not like, if a deal doesn't look like 69.7% to us, we won't bid on it. We won't go after it. That's not the case at all. We
componenttext: Yes, well -- so Ian, yes, we definitely have a posture here that it's about operating profit dollars with respect to that. So it's not like, if a deal doesn't look like 69.7% to us, we won't bid on it. We won't go after it. That's not the case at all. We certainly think about this is a portfolio and opportunity. The issue becomes what -- when are those that still make sense that an FPGA is the answer because, obviously, bidding at a negative 20% for some single-function capability doesn't really add any value to shareholders. Also, we did do that. But we absolutely have looked at broadening applications within our existing markets, and we've made -- certainly done some of that as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on 28- and 20-nanometer. On 28, where would you say we are in the cycle now versus where 28-nanometer peaks? And for 20-nanometer down the road, do you expect that as a similar shape of ramp versus 28 or somehow distinct?
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on 28- and 20-nanometer. On 28, where would you say we are in the cycle now versus where 28-nanometer peaks? And for 20-nanometer down the road, do you expect that as a similar shape of ramp versus 28 or somehow distinct?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 28, our position has evolved, and we actually think it's going to peak later than we had originally expected and to last longer than it had originally expected, potentially with a slightly smaller peak but actually similar area under the curve, so -- a
componenttext: So 28, our position has evolved, and we actually think it's going to peak later than we had originally expected and to last longer than it had originally expected, potentially with a slightly smaller peak but actually similar area under the curve, so -- and we're still years away from that peak. And we're seeing a lot of markets that are addressed by our products just starting now to move into production and probably have another 2 or 3 years before they move into production of accumulation of -- which generates the peak, is still years away. 20-nanometer, the way we look at it is 20 and 16 together are -- should be equivalent to 28 in terms of their capabilities, and that's because they're coming very close together in terms of introduction. And so if you -- there's a previous question that I managed to confuse everyone with my response, but it took 3 years to reach $100 million on 28-nanometer, and that's a quarterly number. And our expectation is if you look the combination of 20 and 16 and if you could sort of shift them back to start at the same time, then you should hopefully reach the same number in -- with the same level of success at that point in time. Now we'll see if that sort of happens and it will. But if you look at 20 alone, it won't match what 28 has done. And if you look at 16 alone, it won't match what 28 has done. The expectation is that between the 2 of them should come close to what 28 has done in a more or less similar time frame.

componenttext: This is Sanjay for Romit Shah. Moshe, one question. You indicated your frustration with the wired segment, and I was wondering if you could drill down a bit deeper. Which specific segments in wired, you think, have disappointed you? And when you talk to these customers, just wondering what's the take on it. componenttext: Well, I think we'll give you more context in March. But fundamentally, this is a multi-year challenge we have run into, and it's sort of -- it's just for several years, that is the one segment that we have continuously projected growth. We have the design wins, and they're taking longer to move into production. And when they move into production, they yield less than we had expected them to. So we'll try to break it down by category. I would say that you're right in pointing out that it's not fair to tar everyone with the same brush. It's a very broad market with several subsegments, so we'll highlight which ones are moving faster and which ones appear to be stalled. But I don't have that information with me now.

componenttext: I just had one clarification. The -- if I listen to the Cisco call, their business in the wireline kind of segment were surprisingly strong in the U.S., and even the European business wasn't that weak. I was wondering whether this is a phenomenon of one company doing relatively better than the other one. So is this a generalization that you can see across your customer base?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't -- I haven't really studied anything Cisco had said in the short run here, David. But I know Cisco sells in a lot of different applications, not necessarily all wired communications. They're in broadcast, in cable and in equipment and as you
componenttext: Yes. I don't -- I haven't really studied anything Cisco had said in the short run here, David. But I know Cisco sells in a lot of different applications, not necessarily all wired communications. They're in broadcast, in cable and in equipment and as you know that we said we had lower-than-expected performance in that area in this last quarter. And so sometimes it is application specific or sub-application specific or not. And I'm certainly not trying to pile on Cisco negatively either on wired or broadcast. We had weakness in other customers as well. We've had geographic weakness from a European perspective as well. So we are -- it's often as not what the entire company is doing. It's more about the industry, and sometimes it's about our specific applications in the industry. So I think all we can do is point out to where we play and where we fit. It's hard for us -- had for me to comment on what I think about Cisco's strength or weakness in any geography.

And so our overall new products numbers were down a little bit, and we have stated that our 28-nanometer was up substantially, negligibly, obviously, by actual subtraction that the 40, 45 was down. Within that, it was a broadcast related and some communications. The low end, as Moshe talked about, continues to do quite well, and that was doing well. So it was really the high end, and it was related to the communications segment and broadcast. So it really ties nicely to the overall disappointment, if you will, because of that and that another way to -- for us describe that to you would be there were some older products that are either going through transition or there's slow demand by their end markets depending on which customer and which situation that were driving that.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is John, and I will be your conference operator. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha. Thank you. Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our conference ca
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the December quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and actual results may differ materially. We refer you to documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Profitability remained strong during the quarter, but sales were lower than anticipated, declining 2% during the December quarter. The primary weakness was driven by broadcast and wireless communications end markets. 28-nanometer sales re
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Profitability remained strong during the quarter, but sales were lower than anticipated, declining 2% during the December quarter. The primary weakness was driven by broadcast and wireless communications end markets. 28-nanometer sales represented 1 of the bright spots of the quarter with sales increasing nearly 20%, sequentially. All members of this product family grew with Zynq, Virtex and Artix all posting double-digit growth rates.
From an end market perspective, sales to communications customers declined 3% sequentially with flat wired sales and a decline in wireless sales. Wireless sales were impacted by weaker sales from non-China regions, while our China wireless business increased in line with expectations.
Industrial and aerospace and defense sales increased as expected with strong defense sales offsetting declines in industrial, scientific and medical. Broadcast, consumer and automotive sales declined due to weaker broadcast sales, which were driven by weak purchasing activity from a couple of large customers. Automotive sales were better than expected as several new Advanced Driver Assistance programs began to ramp.
In terms of linearity, the month of October and November were in line with our expectations, and the month of December progressively weakened. Turns were 44% for the quarter. Gross margin of 69.7% was better than expected as a result of customer and product mix. Total operating expenses were $224 million, including $2 million of amortization-related expenses. This was $6 million lower than our guided -- than guided, resulting in operating income of 32%. Other income and expense was a net expense of $4 million better than forecasted, mainly due to higher interest income from our investment portfolio.
Net income for the quarter was $168 million or $0.62 per share, including a $0.02 per diluted share benefit primarily related to the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit. Operating cash flow for the September quarter -- excuse me, the December quarter was $291 million before $6 million in CapEx. Strong cash flow during the quarter was positively impacted by a net improvement in working capital led by the timing impact of accounts receivable.
Diluted shares for the quarter were 274 million shares. This was a bit higher than forecasted as a result of the higher stock price. There was a 7.8 million share dilutive effect from our convertible note.
We are committed to returning cash to shareholders. During the quarter, we continued to aggressively buy back stock, repurchasing 4 million shares for $175 million. We also paid $76 million in quarterly dividends. For the fiscal year, thus far, we have returned over $700 million to shareholders in the form of repurchase and dividend, $80 million more than we generated in operating cash flow.
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments increased $28 million to approximately $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed rate debt resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion. Inventory dollars decreased by $16 million during the quarter. We plan to continue to reduce inventory dollars in the March quarter.
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the March quarter of fiscal year '15. Our backlog heading into the quarter is down sequentially. Although we are forecasting another strong quarter for our 28-nanometer products, we will be facing headwinds from aerospace and defense due to normal seasonality and a program-related timing. We expect both wired and wireless communications to be flat sequentially. Wireless sales will be impacted by the timing of the FDD LTE deployments. We expect industrial and aerospace and defense segment to decrease for the reasons I mentioned earlier, offsetting flat sales to ISM and test to measurement.
Broadcast, automotive and consumer is expected to be up driven by a rebound in broadcast and continued Advanced Driver Assistance strength in automotive. As a result, we're expecting total sales for the March quarter to be down 2% to 6% sequentially. The midpoint of this guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 51%. Gross margin is expected to be 68% to 69%. Operating expenses in the March quarter is expected to be approximately $227 million, including $2.5 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. Other income and expense for the March quarter is expected to be a net expense of approximately $7 million, and the share count is expected to be approximately 270 million shares. The tax rate for the March quarter is expected to be approximately 13%.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm clearly disappointed with our top line performance both during the December quarter and the guidance for the March quarter. Looking forward into fiscal year 2016, we are planning for a flat-to-low growth
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. I'm clearly disappointed with our top line performance both during the December quarter and the guidance for the March quarter. Looking forward into fiscal year 2016, we are planning for a flat-to-low growth environment. The renewed revenue growth from our 28-nanometer portfolio will be somewhat offset by uncertainty in global communication spending and expected declines in key aerospace and defense programs.
On the positive side, Xilinx posted strong profitability in the December quarter. Both gross margin and operating margin at 69.7% and 32%, respectively, were better than our expectations, contributing to earnings per share of $0.62. Our cash flow continues to be healthy, and we're on a path to return more cash to shareholders in the form of both dividends and buybacks than we will generate in fiscal year '15.
The most significant highlight for the quarter is our new 28-nanometer revenue growth, which exceeded $150 million sequential increase of nearly 20%. We're anticipating 28-nanometer sales to continue to grow and exceed $160 million in the March quarter.
We also achieved several important milestones for our 20-nanometer portfolio. Our Kintex UltraScale devices became the industry's first 20-nanometer FPGAs to move into volume production. Based on customer feedback, we continue to believe that we have an estimated 1-year lead over the competition. This technology leadership is complemented by our Virtex UltraScale family, which is the industry's ASIC-class, 20-nanometer, high-end product offering. At the very high end of this family, we began shipping the industry's largest FPGA, which delivers over 4x the capacity of any competitive devices.
Finally, in the area of design software, we launched the SDAccel development environment. This is the second in a family of software defined development environment, which we call SDx. This will greatly expand our user base to include a broad community of systems and software engineers in both existing and new markets. This environment combines OpenCL, C and C++ languages with an initial focus on the growing data center acceleration market.
Despite the top line challenges, I remain confident in Xilinx's strong technology leadership and market position. We're still in early phases of 28-nanometer revenue growth, have already delivered the first production ASIC-class 20-nanometer products, our market-expanding new SDx software defined programming environments and soon, our 16-nanometer products that include multi-processing associates. [ph] At our Investor Day on March 10, we look forward to providing you more details outlining our plans.
Like to turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

componenttext: Moshe, I just wanted to get a little more color, if you could, on your statement about -- I think you said fiscal '16 being a flat-to-low growth environment. Can you give us again a little more detail on the puts and takes that lead you to that conclusion?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll be giving more details in March, but fundamentally, growth is driven for us by 28-nanometer, and we see clouds from communications and A&D. And so when you look at the combination of both of those, then we see it as being a, generally speaking
componenttext: Well, we'll be giving more details in March, but fundamentally, growth is driven for us by 28-nanometer, and we see clouds from communications and A&D. And so when you look at the combination of both of those, then we see it as being a, generally speaking, flat-to-low growth environment for fiscal year '16. That's probably as much as we can say at this point in time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Also on growth, in the past, Moshe, I think you've talked about growing at some multiple. I believe, it was 2x the semi-industry. We're not seeing that now and you're certainly setting more moderate expectations for fiscal '16. Should we think about this
componenttext: Also on growth, in the past, Moshe, I think you've talked about growing at some multiple. I believe, it was 2x the semi-industry. We're not seeing that now and you're certainly setting more moderate expectations for fiscal '16. Should we think about this as a more sort of permanent reset to the longer-term growth potential that the company has? Or do you think this is a sort of soft spot that we will power through eventually and return to more meaningful growth?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The comparison with the rest of the semiconductor industry is a very difficult one to make because it has so many elements, and sometimes there's fast growing applications like mobile, so that's not ours. But definitely, we do see things slowing down. I t
componenttext: The comparison with the rest of the semiconductor industry is a very difficult one to make because it has so many elements, and sometimes there's fast growing applications like mobile, so that's not ours. But definitely, we do see things slowing down. I think we will shed more light on this in March and also be able to forecast the -- more accurately the period that this will continue. But no, this is -- I would look at it as not a global statement at this point in time. We'll be in a better position to answer it in March.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we're making a long-term statement on that, Will. And I think I'd just like to highlight the headwinds from aerospace and defense, which are, in some cases, program related that are causing some of the headwinds for FY '16, and we still
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we're making a long-term statement on that, Will. And I think I'd just like to highlight the headwinds from aerospace and defense, which are, in some cases, program related that are causing some of the headwinds for FY '16, and we still have a lot -- a good, strong long-term view of our aerospace and defense participation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Gauna from JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Gauna from JMP Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering, as you look at your Aerospace and Defense business, how much of this is a result of the Russian sanctions? Do you have visibility on how long these delays might last? And is there any effect from the strong dollar factoring into either this
componenttext: I'm wondering, as you look at your Aerospace and Defense business, how much of this is a result of the Russian sanctions? Do you have visibility on how long these delays might last? And is there any effect from the strong dollar factoring into either this category or even in the Communications segment?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So from a Russia perspective, no. In Aerospace and Defense, not really. I mean, we -- some of our Communications business and some of our high-performance compute, which is in the other category, in particular, that latter statement, we've had some i
componenttext: Yes. So from a Russia perspective, no. In Aerospace and Defense, not really. I mean, we -- some of our Communications business and some of our high-performance compute, which is in the other category, in particular, that latter statement, we've had some impact because of the Russian sanctions, and that's been difficult for us to ship certain things into Russia and to get licenses for. So that has had some impact, but I would say it's been relatively small impact. But it's certainly anything helps, right, in this kind of environment, so we've had some impact from that. Relative to the stronger dollar, since we ship everything in U.S. dollars, we don't have an actual direct hedging effect, but obviously, our customers' customer and our distributor does ship in local currencies. And while when we've asked those questions, we haven't gotten any answer that says, "Yes, it's really impacting our business." I know of other businesses that are saying that to me that they're having some issues because effectively, relative to the euro, our parts have gotten 20% more expensive over the last year or so. So undoubtedly, it's going to have an impact to what I would call already a weaker environment in Europe than most other places.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Ing from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. My one question is in the China Base Station business, still some big targets for base station deployments this year among the carriers. Do you expect any other same sort of bomb kit issues you had last year, supply constraints in RF power amps by th
componenttext: Yes. My one question is in the China Base Station business, still some big targets for base station deployments this year among the carriers. Do you expect any other same sort of bomb kit issues you had last year, supply constraints in RF power amps by the suppliers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the -- from the power amp perspective, I think there are still some of the shortages that are going on, but that's really not the biggest gating factor to our overall wireless business. That's for sure. And I think what's specifically going on in
componenttext: Yes, so the -- from the power amp perspective, I think there are still some of the shortages that are going on, but that's really not the biggest gating factor to our overall wireless business. That's for sure. And I think what's specifically going on in China, there's probably 2 changes to what we have been thinking and saying about it. One is the Phase 3 rollout. While it is -- we still believe that it's beginning in the springtime and that's progressing, the pace of that rollout seems to be a little slower than the previous 2 phases were in the past. We've seen a pretty high concentration over 1 quarter, 1.5 quarters of deployment, and that deployment seems to be, at least the best as we can tell, maybe lasting a little longer to get those base stations out, so a little bit longer time period. And the second thing, which is also looming on our minds, is around the FD licenses. I think we had articulated that the FD base stations would start to ship in this March quarter and then throughout the remainder of calendar '15. Right now the licenses still are not broadly let, and our modeling was essentially a 1-year lag from when the TD base station started shipping in volume, which was similar to the 3G deployment. And that really isn't happening right now. So we're kind of on pins and needles here waiting for those licenses to be let, so we can kind of model when that might start.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher Rolland from FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher Rolland from FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned clouds from wireless. So is that really from just Asia? How much of that is non-Asia? And then the magnitude and timing on Europe and perhaps, even India, does that play into your forecast at all for next year?
componenttext: So you mentioned clouds from wireless. So is that really from just Asia? How much of that is non-Asia? And then the magnitude and timing on Europe and perhaps, even India, does that play into your forecast at all for next year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I -- correct me if I'm wrong here, Moshe, but I think the clouds are on communications broadly, not just wireless. And what we see on the wireless side is weakness in the short term in deployments going on in North America that has caused us some
componenttext: Yes, so I -- correct me if I'm wrong here, Moshe, but I think the clouds are on communications broadly, not just wireless. And what we see on the wireless side is weakness in the short term in deployments going on in North America that has caused us some short-term shipment issues, meaning this quarter and this past quarter and next quarter, specifically capital being diverted away from AT&T and Verizon and other places. But probably more prominent, Sprint is having more issues with rollouts, and so the OEMs that we ship to that supply the Sprint LTE rollout have been cutting back orders because they've not been getting orders from Sprint as best as we can understand. And so that softness in North America is -- some part of that, I would say, early in the year. And then to your kind of a follow-through to the question related to Europe and India, our -- in our mental model right now we have not modeled either one of those geographies taking significant product at this point in time and probably into next year as well. We're still looking into that phenomena because we see no signs of that going in -- I would say, growing in a very significant way at this time yet.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Danely of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Danely of Citigroup.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, looking to your confidence that this is purely a demand problem versus some share loss.
componenttext: I guess, looking to your confidence that this is purely a demand problem versus some share loss.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the numbers on 28-nanometer are growing again very rapidly actually. And if you look over the past 3 years, we believe that we've been consistently above 60%, and it sort of peaked last year probably at around 70%, and it's still well into the 60s n
componenttext: Well, the numbers on 28-nanometer are growing again very rapidly actually. And if you look over the past 3 years, we believe that we've been consistently above 60%, and it sort of peaked last year probably at around 70%, and it's still well into the 60s now. So I don't believe that it's a result of that. What the other thing we're seeing is 28-nanometer now all elements of it are growing, so the high end, the Virtex side, the Zynq side and the Artix side, are growing, too. And in the past, a lot of growth came from the mid-range Kintex, and now as this expands, the breadth and depth of our product portfolio continues to give me confidence in that regard.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just -- one more thing. If you think about the way we weigh cast the second half of this current fiscal year previously and where we think now, almost all of our shortfalls are around situations that are more demand-related over older products th
componenttext: And I'll just -- one more thing. If you think about the way we weigh cast the second half of this current fiscal year previously and where we think now, almost all of our shortfalls are around situations that are more demand-related over older products than 7 Series, and that would typically not indicate share loss because no one redesigns an older product, right? So it's really around that. Doesn't seem to be around any of the leading edge.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vivek Arya of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I actually had a clarification on a question. On the clarification, maybe if you could also give us some more color on how we should think about gross margins given the weakness in the mix. Is it better to think gross margins could be, say, 67%, 68% than
componenttext: I actually had a clarification on a question. On the clarification, maybe if you could also give us some more color on how we should think about gross margins given the weakness in the mix. Is it better to think gross margins could be, say, 67%, 68% than the 69%, 70%? And then, Moshe, for my question, if you could just give us the status of your 16-nanometer FinFET engagement with the TSMC, what is the status there? And do you expect to get products out on time this year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the gross margin side, obviously, we told you what the gross margin estimates are for Q4, so you can get at FY '15. At FY '16, we're obviously not done with our planning at this point in time. We certainly are -- we have been running the company at
componenttext: So on the gross margin side, obviously, we told you what the gross margin estimates are for Q4, so you can get at FY '15. At FY '16, we're obviously not done with our planning at this point in time. We certainly are -- we have been running the company at 68% to 70% range. That's our goal, to do that as well, and so at this point in time, I wouldn't give you a -- I certainly wouldn't give you a lower number to plan for gross margins. We do think that with the strength of our hand at 28-nanometer and as good as that profile is for us from a cost perspective as well, I'm feeling reasonable about providing that range, at least for now.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Vivek, and with regards to taking out, the program continues and the relationship with TSMC is excellent. We're getting absolutely outstanding support. The design is a very challenging design, and as a result, we expect for it to tape out a couple of mont
componenttext: Vivek, and with regards to taking out, the program continues and the relationship with TSMC is excellent. We're getting absolutely outstanding support. The design is a very challenging design, and as a result, we expect for it to tape out a couple of months later than we had originally expected. So this is -- we're probably looking at the May time frame as opposed to the March time frame, which was our latest estimate for that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Carver in for John. Just wanted to get a clarification. You gave some color on the fiscal '16 as being driven by sort of strong 20-nanometer but offset by Global Comms and some weakness in Aero and Defense. But if I look at sort of your 40- a
componenttext: This is Ryan Carver in for John. Just wanted to get a clarification. You gave some color on the fiscal '16 as being driven by sort of strong 20-nanometer but offset by Global Comms and some weakness in Aero and Defense. But if I look at sort of your 40- and 45-nanometer business, I mean, share has been declining year-on-year for the last 4 quarters. And if I think about sort of where a 28-nanometer product goes, primarily it's been into the Comms end market. So I guess, how comfortable are you guys in thinking the 28-nanometer is going to be able to drive this outperformance in fiscal '16 given your commentary about Comms and Aero and Defense sort of equating to probably north of 1/2 of your revenue for the year next year and then continued 40-nanometer declines?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So 28-nanometer is a very broad and deep product offering, and there is lots of elements to it. And there are different components, different families that are targeted at specific different applications. It addresses all of the markets we're in, ab
componenttext: Sure. So 28-nanometer is a very broad and deep product offering, and there is lots of elements to it. And there are different components, different families that are targeted at specific different applications. It addresses all of the markets we're in, absolutely all of them and is an expansion play into additional areas. It would be correct to say that in the last year of production was driven by wireless comms, but it's not that, that's the only market that it has addressed. And if you look at the early shipments, they weren't necessarily into comms at all. They were in ASIC emulation. They were actually into some consumer markets, and all of these continue. What is happening is as the family of products has rolled out and has been extremely successful, more and more are moving into significant production and growth that you see now back to over $150 million, was actually driven by growth on the Virtex front, growth on the Zynq front and growth on the Artix front. And those addressed numerous markets, not only comms. So it's broad. It's growing significantly. It's the fastest growing product we've ever seen, and we're very confident that if you look at the numbers when it grew from $100 million to $380 million, if you look at our projection of over $160 million, it'll come in at about $580 million for the year. We expect significant growth beyond that. So that is growing rapidly, and it's going to be the most successful and broadest portfolio we have. Having said that, when you look at 40 and 45, we continue to see strength. And on the 45, which is the low-end product offering, the Spartan product offering, whereas we believe that 40-nanometer is more or less peaking for us at this point in time. In terms of market share on 40, 45, it hasn't necessarily shrunk. It's sort of gone up and down over the past year, I would say, and that's our valuation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ryan, if I'd just point out a little bit.  I mean it's one of our bigger growth areas for this year and in the future is Industrial, Our Industrial business as well as Automotive, and those are both primarily driven by growth in our 45-nanometer and
componenttext: Yes. Ryan, if I'd just point out a little bit.  I mean it's one of our bigger growth areas for this year and in the future is Industrial, Our Industrial business as well as Automotive, and those are both primarily driven by growth in our 45-nanometer and in our Zynq product families. And so if you think about the momentum that in those end markets that have been clear over the last year or so and those -- that momentum, we believe, is going to continue, it is transitioning from older products into these newer, higher-valued products at higher ASPs, where we are getting a tremendous amount of benefit. And then also, even within the wireless space, there's a transition going on away from older products, Virtex-5s and 6s into the 7 Series and to big Zynq products going into the wireless function. And so we're going to see more growth in the 28-nanometer area even in the comms thing. So don't write off comms totally here.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Back when HDTVs were ramping, there was demand for FPGAs into TVs and also in broadcasting, which helped your Consumer business. Do you expect a similar trend to happen with the rise of 4K TVs? And do you see any interest they have also on OEMs? And what
componenttext: Back when HDTVs were ramping, there was demand for FPGAs into TVs and also in broadcasting, which helped your Consumer business. Do you expect a similar trend to happen with the rise of 4K TVs? And do you see any interest they have also on OEMs? And what would be the timing on that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tristan, this is Jon. Yes, we have actually already shipped quite a bit at the tail end of last fiscal year and the beginning of this fiscal year into the high-definition -- or excuse me, the 4K2K or ultra-high-definition television. We also are begi
componenttext:
Yes. Tristan, this is Jon. Yes, we have actually already shipped quite a bit at the tail end of last fiscal year and the beginning of this fiscal year into the high-definition -- or excuse me, the 4K2K or ultra-high-definition television. We also are beginning to ship into OLED-technology-based televisions as well, and we do expect to be in the television business longer than some of our previous generations where we were in for the initial of HD and the initial
[Audio Gap]
and then got phased out rather quickly. We seem to have quite a bit of activity going on across all the current manufacturers for that business. So that is a good opportunity for us, yes.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava from BMO Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava from BMO Capital.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I just had a clarification on the FinFET comment you made. Is this an issue emanating from the difficulty, in your opinion, TSMC having? Or is it coming from the Xilinx side? And just a quick follow-up. What's the timing from tape-out to when we sh
componenttext: Moshe, I just had a clarification on the FinFET comment you made. Is this an issue emanating from the difficulty, in your opinion, TSMC having? Or is it coming from the Xilinx side? And just a quick follow-up. What's the timing from tape-out to when we should expect production volume?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there are no issues with TSMC. They've had numerous tape-outs already. They're giving us full support. The design, whenever you encounter a new generation of product, tends to unearth problems that you did not anticipate, and as a result, the clo
componenttext: Okay. So there are no issues with TSMC. They've had numerous tape-outs already. They're giving us full support. The design, whenever you encounter a new generation of product, tends to unearth problems that you did not anticipate, and as a result, the closing of all of these issues was taking a little longer, plus the challenges related to design for FinFET transistors are more significant. So it's not a TSMC challenge or issue at all. It's just our ability to finish the design with their support. After -- if you look at our business, typically, what sort of happens is tape it out. You get it back after a few months. You go through a lengthy evaluation cycle, and then you move it into production, which point in time, it takes 2 to 3 years until it reaches high-volume production. So it sort of depends. If you look at 28-nanometer, we reached $100 million of production, I think, 3 years after we taped out the product.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015

componenttext: You mean the -- a quarterly run rate of $100 million?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jim Covello of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jim Covello of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I wanted to ask a longer-term question, to the extent you can comment today ahead of the Analyst Day. That would be very helpful color. Just want to know if there's any change longer term on how you're thinking ab
componenttext: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I wanted to ask a longer-term question, to the extent you can comment today ahead of the Analyst Day. That would be very helpful color. Just want to know if there's any change longer term on how you're thinking about OpEx profile of the company as we transition to slower growth environment or in the capital allocation profile of the company as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. From a spending profile, certainly not going to -- we'll update you more -- a lot more about what we think about FY '16 there. But Moshe's comments around next year's flat -- positioning the company from a flat-to-low growth environment, we're certai
componenttext: Yes. From a spending profile, certainly not going to -- we'll update you more -- a lot more about what we think about FY '16 there. But Moshe's comments around next year's flat -- positioning the company from a flat-to-low growth environment, we're certainly very aware of what that means, and we are working towards spending goals to match that thought process. But from a longer-term perspective, R&D intensity as we have these nodes go more rapidly closer together until maybe we can get to 10-nanometer, it is causing us a little bit of headwind. But we've been able to manage it through a variety of different techniques and decisions that we made, so I'm not too worried about any sort of a bigger ramp in spending coming on. And relative to capital allocation, again, it's -- it is based on a lot of factors, including what our plans for excess cash would be beyond returning it to shareholders. But our primary situation is to continue to think about dividend first and pay for that and then the share repurchase as opportunistic. As what I -- what visibility I have today about the future, I don't think we'll be changing that policy.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis of Barclays.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to the Wireless segment with  the margin guidance will be down 4 quarters in a row. So you talked about some end market issues, but I'm not aware of other companies seeing these declines. So I was just curious, as you look back, did
componenttext: I just want to go back to the Wireless segment with  the margin guidance will be down 4 quarters in a row. So you talked about some end market issues, but I'm not aware of other companies seeing these declines. So I was just curious, as you look back, did you -- what's really causing this? Did you see ASIC replacements? Is there a mix shift to the midrange? And then in that fiscal '16 guidance, you talked about uncertain outlook. How much are you expecting this business to come back for you within that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Blayne, the short-term issues on the Wireless business, really, is not as much China as it's been -- is the rest of the world for us, and some of the softnesses that's gone on. All I can do is tell you what we believe our customers are saying. And
componenttext: Yes. So Blayne, the short-term issues on the Wireless business, really, is not as much China as it's been -- is the rest of the world for us, and some of the softnesses that's gone on. All I can do is tell you what we believe our customers are saying. And since we have the lion's share of the share among PLD companies in support of the Sprint rollout, that has been something that has disappointed relative to our expectations for this quarter, and we believe that bleeds into the forecast for Q4, as well. The China aspect, we actually had China grow as we anticipated, so that wasn't necessarily the short-term issue. But we are -- we did also, I believe, signal we were a lot more bullish on wireless growth in China because of Phase 3 rollout in March. And while we're not seeing declines there, we aren't seeing the same relative acceleration of growth in China that we had originally said. So it's not like our wireless business is going away. It's just that it's not increasing to the point that we had said. With respect to FY '16, I think Moshe was trying to characterize the cloud overall in communications, meaning a global rough spot for global spending, not specifically targeting some geography in wireless. So we're not really going to give a guidance right now on our thoughts on wireless for FY '16. We'll do that in March.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri of CLSA Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri of CLSA Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, more a philosophical question. I'm just looking at the business over the last 3 years, and based on your guidance for fiscal '16, on average, there isn't a whole lot of growth here. I think in fiscal '10, you grew -- I mean, a couple of years ago,
componenttext: Moshe, more a philosophical question. I'm just looking at the business over the last 3 years, and based on your guidance for fiscal '16, on average, there isn't a whole lot of growth here. I think in fiscal '10, you grew -- I mean, a couple of years ago, you grew about 10% fiscal '14. But outside of that -- so my question is, obviously, R&D is running at -- fairly high. OpEx is running close to 40%. As the leader, I am wondering does it still make sense to chase the Moore's Law? I mean, is it part of the business that you have to continue to invest in Moore's Law? And my question is why wouldn't it make sense to kind of slow it down a little bit and kind of bringing that OpEx number down?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that's a great philosophical question, which is -- we could spend hours debating, but let me give you my 2-minute response here. You're right in pointing out, if you look back, that the growth has not been sustained. So for Xilinx, it was -- grew
componenttext: Okay. So that's a great philosophical question, which is -- we could spend hours debating, but let me give you my 2-minute response here. You're right in pointing out, if you look back, that the growth has not been sustained. So for Xilinx, it was -- grew to $1.8 billion, was at $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion for several years, then took a jump to the $2.4-ish billion level and has been at that point for more years than we believed it would stay there. And that clearly is disappointing. Having said that, we do believe that this is a business -- as the semiconductor industry is maturing, being at the leading edge enables us to capture a larger SAM. And in order to do that, we're investing, in order to exploit that and provide those solutions. Now the first node where this was possible in a big way, we believe, is 28-nanometer, and we do see and we will -- we understand that it's incumbent upon us to show the proof. We do see in quite a few cases more ASICs going away and customers transitioning into FPGAs and to a lesser degree, but nonetheless, this is happening, too, some of the traditional ASSP providers can no longer keep up, and that provides an opportunity for us. In order to do that, we need to have both different products and a big investment in the software enablement to enable us to capture those markets. We're making those investments now and we believe that the return is still ahead of us. And an example would be the Zynq product line, which enables us to participate in a bigger way in automotive, a market where we only had a very fringed participation in the past. So I can't argue with your numbers, right? The numbers are what the numbers are. But I fervently believe that the opportunity is still ahead of us to capture these markets, and we'll give you more insights into that in the March time frame. But excellent question and thank you for asking it.

componenttext: So we believe there is opportunities for growth in both wired communications and wireless communications. We will try to size those. Wired, in particular, has been frustrating for us. For several years now we've predicted growth, projected growth, and it hasn't happened. Even the 28-nanometer on the wired side, it's taking longer for those very significant designs to translate into revenue. Nonetheless, the opportunity is there, and the wired market is not going away. But we'll give you a deeper and more accurate response in March.

componenttext: Yes, well -- so Ian, yes, we definitely have a posture here that it's about operating profit dollars with respect to that. So it's not like, if a deal doesn't look like 69.7% to us, we won't bid on it. We won't go after it. That's not the case at all. We certainly think about this is a portfolio and opportunity. The issue becomes what -- when are those that still make sense that an FPGA is the right answer because, obviously, bidding at a negative 20% for some single-function capability doesn't really add any value to the shareholders. Also, we don't do that. But we absolutely have looked at broadening applications within our existing markets, and we've made -- certainly done some of that, as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on 28- and 20-nanometer. On 28, where would you say we are in the cycle now versus where 28-nanometer peaks? And for 20-nanometer down the road, do you expect that to have a similar shape of ramp versus 28 or somehow distinct?
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on 28- and 20-nanometer. On 28, where would you say we are in the cycle now versus where 28-nanometer peaks? And for 20-nanometer down the road, do you expect that to have a similar shape of ramp versus 28 or somehow distinct?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 28, our position has evolved, and we actually think it's going to peak later than we had originally expected and to last longer than it had originally expected, potentially with a slightly smaller peak but actually similar area under the curve, so -- a
componenttext: So 28, our position has evolved, and we actually think it's going to peak later than we had originally expected and to last longer than it had originally expected, potentially with a slightly smaller peak but actually similar area under the curve, so -- and we're still years away from that peak. And we're seeing a lot of markets that are addressed by our products just starting now to move into production and probably have another 2 or 3 years before they move into production so the accumulation of -- which generates the peak, is still years away. 20-nanometer, the way we look at it is 20 and 16 together are -- should be equivalent to 28 in terms of their capabilities, and that's because they're coming very close together in terms of introduction. And so if you -- there's a previous question that I managed to confuse everyone with my response, but it took 3 years to reach $100 million on 28-nanometer, and that's a quarterly number. And our expectation is if you look the combination of 20 and 16 and if you could sort of shift them back to start at the same time, then you should hopefully reach the same number in -- with the same level of success at that point in time. Now we'll see if that sort of happens and it will. But if you look at 20 alone, it won't match what 28 has done. And if you look at 16 alone, it won't match what 28 has done. The expectation is that between the 2 of them should come close to what 28 has done in a more or less similar time frame.

componenttext: Well, I think we'll give you more context in March. But fundamentally, this is a multi-year challenge we have run into, and it's sort of -- it's just for several years, that is the one segment that we have continuously projected growth. We have the design wins, and they're taking longer to move into production. And when they move into production, they yield less than we had expected them to. So we'll try to break it down by category. I would say that you're right in pointing out that it's not fair to tar everyone with the same brush. It's a very broad market with several subsegments, so we'll highlight which ones are moving faster and which ones appear to be stalled. But I don't have that information with me now.

componenttext: I just had one clarification. The -- if I listen to the Cisco call, their business in the Wireline kind of segment were surprisingly strong in the U.S., and even their European business wasn't that weak. I was wondering whether this is a phenomenon of one company doing relatively better than the other one. So is this a generalization that you can see across your customer base?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't -- I haven't really studied anything Cisco has said in the short run here, David. But I know Cisco sells in a lot of different applications, not necessarily all wired communications. They're in broadcaster, in cable head and equipment and as
componenttext: Yes. I don't -- I haven't really studied anything Cisco has said in the short run here, David. But I know Cisco sells in a lot of different applications, not necessarily all wired communications. They're in broadcaster, in cable head and equipment and as you noted we said we had lower-than-expected performance in that area in this last quarter. And so sometimes it is application-specific or sub-application specific or not. And I'm certainly not trying to pile on Cisco negatively either on wired or broadcast. We had weakness in other customers as well. We've had geographic weakness from a European perspective as well. So we are -- it's often -- it's not what the entire company is doing. It's more about the industry, and sometimes it's about our specific applications in the industry. So I think all we can do is point out to where we play and where we fit. It's hard for us -- had for me to comment on what I think about Cisco's strength or weakness in any geography.

componenttext: Yes, so our new product category is made up of 28-nanometer and then our 40, 45, so the -- that -- those 2 generations of technologies. headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me our Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We'll provide a financial and business review of the March quarter and then open the call for questions. Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we
componenttext: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me our Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We'll provide a financial and business review of the March quarter and then open the call for questions. Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company.  We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website. Let me now turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Fiscal 2015 was another strong year of profitability for the company with operating income up 31.8%, the highest in 4 years. Industrial and aerospace and defense category increased 7% for the year, representing a record 39% of total sales
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Fiscal 2015 was another strong year of profitability for the company with operating income up 31.8%, the highest in 4 years. Industrial and aerospace and defense category increased 7% for the year, representing a record 39% of total sales. The communication segment declined 5% impacted by lower than expected CapEx spend in many of sub-applications. The broadcast consumer and automotive category decreased 2%, however the automotive subsegment grew significantly, increasing 30% during the year. For the company as a whole, fiscal year sales were $2.4 billion, flat with the prior year. Gross margin was a record 70% for the fiscal year, benefiting from end market mix, as well as continued cost reduction in margin expansion initiatives across our product platform portfolio. In fiscal year 2015, we returned over 120% of our operating cash flow to shareholders, which represents about 40% of our revenues. This consisted of a record $306 million in dividend payout and a stock repurchase of 15.3 million shares for $650 million. The March quarter of fiscal 2015 marked the 10th consecutive year of dividend increases for the company, putting Xilinx in a very elite group of technology companies. 
Cash flow per share has increased at a compound annual rate of 14% in the past 10 years, driven by a combination of gross margin expansion, disciplined expense control, working capital management and share repurchase. 
Turning now to a discussion of the March quarter. Xilinx sales were $567 million, down 4% sequentially and within our guidance. 28-nanometer sales exceeded $160 million as forecasted. Sales from communications and data center declined 7% sequentially and were weaker than anticipated. Wired communication was approximately flat as expected while wireless sales decreased double digits. The weakness in the wireless segment was primarily due to continued softness in North America and a weakening in China LTE business. Industrial and aerospace and defense business also decreased although not as much as anticipated during the quarter. Expected declines from defense were partially offset by better-than-expected business from both industrial scientific medical, as well as test and measurements. 
Lastly, broadcast consumer and automotive was better-than-expected with automotive achieving a record quarter while broadcast was flat and consumer was down. Gross margin was 69.9% for the quarter, better-than-anticipated, primarily as a result of product and customer mix, although we continue to be focused on driving improvements and profitability. Combined R&D and SG&A expense were $211 million, significantly lower than forecasted, primarily as a result of lower stock-based compensation expense in addition to continued cost efforts. 
Operating income was $159 million, including amortization of $2.4 million and a $24 million restructuring charge or $0.08 per diluted share. The restructuring charge reflect the impact of streamlining certain internal organizations, as well as the impact of a transition from sales reps to a direct sales model for certain customers. Other income was $1 million, higher than guided primarily due to an $8 million gain or $0.03 per diluted share from the sale of land. Net income for the quarter was $135 million or $0.50 per diluted share. Operating cash flow for the March quarter was $166 million before $6 million in CapEx, during the quarter. Diluted shares for the quarter were $270 million, slightly less than forecasted and down 25 million shares from the same quarter a year ago. There was a  $5.7 million share dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions related to the dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.xilinx.com. We repurchased 4.4 million shares for $175 million during the quarter and paid $70 million in dividends. 
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments were flat sequentially at $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed rate debt, resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion. Inventory dollars at Xilinx decreased by $16[ph] million sequentially but days increased to 136. 
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the June quarter of fiscal year '16. Our backlog heading into the quarter is up sequentially. Both wired and wireless communications as expected to decline. Wired communication remains sluggish although data center will likely increase. Wireless will be impacted by slowing China LTE build in the near-term. We expect industrial and aerospace and defense segment to be down, driven primarily by continued expected decreases from A&D. Lastly, we expect broadcast consumer and automotive to be approximately flat. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be flat to down 4% sequentially. And the midpoint of this guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 47%. The lower turns rate is primarily due to a couple of large customers being more fully booked to expectation and a regional distributor transition. Gross margin is expected to be approximately 69% to 70%. Operating expenses for the June quarter is expected to be approximately $210 million, including $2 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. The Q1 fiscal '16 operating expense level will be at its lowest level for the year due to lower tape-out activity and timing of expenses to ramp up headcount post-restructuring. The headcount additions will largely be driven by hiring in the sales force into a lesser degree in R&D. 
For the full year, we are lowering our spending forecast as follows: R&D is expected to be between $530 million and $540 million; SG&A will be between $340 million and $360 million; amortization of intangibles will be approximately $8 million; other income and expense for the June quarter will be a net expense of $12 million, due to lower interest income and anticipated hedging losses. For the full year, other interest and expense will be a net expense of approximately $33 million. The share count is expected to be approximately 266 million shares. The tax rate for the June quarter is expected to be approximately 13%. Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. We are very pleased with the strength of our 28-nanometer products, which exceeded $160 million. As expected, we continue to expand the breadth of 28-nanometer sales contribution. The strength of our Virtex7
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. We are very pleased with the strength of our 28-nanometer products, which exceeded $160 million. As expected, we continue to expand the breadth of 28-nanometer sales contribution. The strength of our Virtex7 high end family and Zynq all programmable SoC was a particular highlight, driving 28-nanometer sales growth in wired comm, industrial and automotive applications. To fiscal year 2015, 28-nanometer revenue reached $580 million, driven by broad-based growth from all end markets and each of the 4 28-nanometer product families. 28-nanometer product generation continues to be the most successful node in history and we believe will have longest life of any node. As we discussed in our Investor Day last month, we are targeting [indiscernible] sales to grow approximately 30% in fiscal year 2016. 
Gross margin performance was another significant highlight for both the fourth quarter and the year. Gross margin increased 69.9% in the quarter, significantly better than forecasted and a record 70.2% for fiscal year 2015. Proven formula for successful execution established the 28-nanometer continues to yield excellent results for 20-nanometer with the UltraScale family. Leveraging our world-class partnership with TSMC, the undisputed leader in the foundry industry, are now delivering the industry's first and only 20-nanometer FPGAs volume production. Based on key customer feedback, we are more than 1 year ahead of the competition in terms of product advancement and quality. Additionally, we're shipping the industry only high-performance ASIC class 20-nanometer high-end product offering with Virtex UltraScale. Finally, with our second generation of 3D IC technology, we're shipping the industry's largest device, delivering more than 4x density of competitive devices. We're currently shipping 20-nanometer parts to approximately 100 discrete customers, demonstrating the broad-based acceptance of this family. This past quarter, sales from our 20-nanometer node were $5 million and we expect these sales to double the June quarter. 
The 60-nanometer node, we launched the UltraScale Plus family of FPGAs, 3D ICs and Zynq MP SoCs, combining embedded memory, 3D on 3D and multiprocessing SoC technology. Consistent level, the UltraScale Plus family provides 2x to 5x greater system-level performance per watt, significantly more systems integration and intelligence and the highest level of security and safety. We continue to anticipate the first tape out of our 16-nanometer FinFET  Plus process to be this quarter. During the March quarter, we also strengthened our family of SDx software defined development environment and the launch of the SDx SoC product. This environment enables a much larger software and systems development community to program SoCs and MP SoCs. Target high-growth opportunities, areas such as data center acceleration, software-defined networking, embedded vision and the industrial Internet of Things. Despite the near-term revenue growth challenges, I continue to be confident in our strategy to resume top line growth. Additionally, we're driving increased efficiencies in our operating model to improve productivity and appropriately align spending levels with the fiscal year '16 sales outlook we've previously provided. I now turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.
