componenttext: That's helpful, Moshe. And specifically your comments around China. To what extent do you think is a pause in vacation build-out in China versus perhaps too much inventory with some of the equipment guys that we need to bring there. I just wanted to get a sense of how much of this do you think there's a real pause in demand versus perhaps a realignment of kind of inventory within the supply chain?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, this is Jon. Let me take that 1, so it's always a little of both, right, meaning in general, the Chinese manufacturers try to get ahead of the awards as much as they can. But when there is following demand man situation like we have now or a delay,
componenttext: John, this is Jon. Let me take that 1, so it's always a little of both, right, meaning in general, the Chinese manufacturers try to get ahead of the awards as much as they can. But when there is following demand man situation like we have now or a delay, I would say, particularly from an FD ramp perspective, it is really more about that pause. And when the RAM starts to build a little more precipitously. We did think all along that our communications business, wireless specifically, would build throughout the year. So that part, while it maybe starting off a little weaker than we anticipated, it isn't really radically scary as much at this point in time. They're just -- China is just going through an overall CapEx modification and the FD stuff is going to happen. It's just going to happen Starter a little bit slower but we do think we've accommodated that in our full year forecast.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: To maybe to just continue that discussion. I understand China impact on wireless. I'm just curious why the wired business is not growing? When Broadcom reported yesterday, they thought the data center demand or the wired business demand, they see picking
componenttext: To maybe to just continue that discussion. I understand China impact on wireless. I'm just curious why the wired business is not growing? When Broadcom reported yesterday, they thought the data center demand or the wired business demand, they see picking up. So I'm curious is this just lumpiness or it's just a timing of different projects? What will drive wired demand for you?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we were very pleased with our 28-nanometer growth in the quarter, so new products are growing, including data center this quarter. So we had good contribution from the new product category. It's really some of the older stuff that wasn't quite as stron
componenttext: So we were very pleased with our 28-nanometer growth in the quarter, so new products are growing, including data center this quarter. So we had good contribution from the new product category. It's really some of the older stuff that wasn't quite as strong as we had anticipated in some of the sub-applications. So I would say, we saw some -- I don't really know the details of all the subsegments that Broadcom ran but we did see strength in these new products. So as those build throughout the year, meaning the new programs and some of the customer differences, I think, we'll see good growth in the wired market from new products continue throughout the year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very helpful, Jon. And then as my follow up, I'm curious what your views are on this potential combination of Intel and Altera. Is that -- if not were to happen, is that a net positive or neutral or does it present any kind of risk for you? And if that co
componenttext: Very helpful, Jon. And then as my follow up, I'm curious what your views are on this potential combination of Intel and Altera. Is that -- if not were to happen, is that a net positive or neutral or does it present any kind of risk for you? And if that combination does happen, would you also need to take any steps towards consolidation?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, the 15 minutes of saying for the programmable world, I'm sort of surprised that this was a third question. First. and from our perspective, regardless of whether that        happens or doesn't happens, whether it's a rumor or whether it's true
componenttext: Okay. Well, the 15 minutes of saying for the programmable world, I'm sort of surprised that this was a third question. First. and from our perspective, regardless of whether that        happens or doesn't happens, whether it's a rumor or whether it's true or not, we're very confident and the reason that we're very confident is that we continue to distance ourselves from the competition and we believe we are poised to now deliver a 3-peat. We've won 128-nanometer. We believe we have huge leadership at 20-nanometer and we are very confident in our position at 16-nanometer. We have leadership with our ASIC class tools and also the new tools, the software defined environment are huge enablers for business expansion. This rumor thus come to call us and this acquisition will happen, we believe that will be a  net positive for us because it will give us a the additional significant advantage of being the only vendor with this very service oriented business, with the total focus, the best foundry, strategic relationship with ARM, leadership on the road map and generally, continuity of operation. So whether it happens or not, we don't know but our position is very strong and we are very confident in where we are and we believe that this gap between us and the competition will just grow going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Covello from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Covello from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I know you discussed a little bit on the China dynamic and the communications market. Maybe you could also comment on why you're seeing North America I know you mentioned the softness in the March quarter and it m
componenttext: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I know you discussed a little bit on the China dynamic and the communications market. Maybe you could also comment on why you're seeing North America I know you mentioned the softness in the March quarter and it maybe does the stabilization in June. [indiscernible] on North America and maybe Europe and some of the other geographies, as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gabriela. North America continues to be weak for us. I think we've had a couple of quarters of relatively weak transitions or weak revenue there. One of the bigger expansions that have gone on over the last year or so has been the Sprint deployment
componenttext: Sure, Gabriela. North America continues to be weak for us. I think we've had a couple of quarters of relatively weak transitions or weak revenue there. One of the bigger expansions that have gone on over the last year or so has been the Sprint deployment and they plug down substantially eager there seems to be some CapEx spend financing things going on here and there, and that's been slower for us on a relative basis to help how strong we are to the ultimate OEM who won those contracts. We don't -- best as what we can tell, we don't think this is some sort of permanent thing. Some of us are getting things worked out as we talk to our customers in that particular area. Largely, the AT&T and Verizon businesses is add-ons and capacity extensions. Nothing significant going on there quite frankly in terms of the CapEx spend. It's really around Sprint and T-Mobile, and we're well-positioned there. But it is definitely, decelerated over the last couple of quarters but we do not expect that to continue for the full year. Europe, while there has been some sales into Europe, It's still a little early and we don't have, I would say clear view. We're counting on a big percentage of that business to come in until maybe very late in the fiscal year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up if I may, could you help us think through the implication, plus the Alcatel Lucent Nokia merger and maybe any context you can provide based on what happened in 2006 which I think the last time we saw customer consolidation?
componenttext: And as a follow-up if I may, could you help us think through the implication, plus the Alcatel Lucent Nokia merger and maybe any context you can provide based on what happened in 2006 which I think the last time we saw customer consolidation?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So wireless generally is the market where, as you point out, has been consolidated for some period of time and we fundamentally believe that the -- or at least, I believe that the catalyst for all of this is the emergence of the very strong players in Chi
componenttext: So wireless generally is the market where, as you point out, has been consolidated for some period of time and we fundamentally believe that the -- or at least, I believe that the catalyst for all of this is the emergence of the very strong players in China government and that is forcing the non-Chinese players to bulk up and strengthen up and from our perspective, both of these companies are significant customers of ours and as they merge, if they come out strengthen, that should improve our business and we think that this will provide them with a better market position to compete against the other players who have been pulling ahead recently. So given our market position which means 2 players and the potential for growth with both of them, I think, as they merge, it will provide a growth path for us going forward, assuming the combined player will emerge stronger as indeed they should. There does tend to be a little bit of confusion when it starts because these are 2 very large, very diverse companies with geographic footprints in different spaces and I do believe at least as they're doing the merger, there will be a little bit of a hiatus, but then it will-- as the merger is completed they will probably have renewed growth going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess first, Moshe, 1 on your side and still of that kind of comment infrastructure side of things. From as close as I can check, whether it was the end of market or Xilinx specifically, that 3 quarters in a row of tough top results, can you talk a litt
componenttext: I guess first, Moshe, 1 on your side and still of that kind of comment infrastructure side of things. From as close as I can check, whether it was the end of market or Xilinx specifically, that 3 quarters in a row of tough top results, can you talk a little bit about what gives you the confidence that we're going to see a snap back in the back half of the year, especially on the wireline side where I believe, on the last conference call, you talk about being relatively puzzled as to why design wins weren't turning into revenue for Xilinx?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the reason we're confident that this needs to reverse is some point some other is mismatch between the infrastructure requirements to the drivers which is basically a lot of this is driven by consumer and business demand. We think that on the wire side
componenttext: So the reason we're confident that this needs to reverse is some point some other is mismatch between the infrastructure requirements to the drivers which is basically a lot of this is driven by consumer and business demand. We think that on the wire side, that time is approaching and that our very strong product portfolio will enable us to capture that as it happens. There is an incessant need for an investment in the infrastructure and I think it has been shortchanged for too long. So you are right in pointing out that we've been disappointed and that this has taken longer. Actually, we have predicted this before but at this point, what we're seeing is a lot of the designs that we reap at the high end of the 28-nanometer are now moving to production and those got delayed roughly by a year vis-a-vis, our initial expectations. So between the market demands and the design wins we have at 28-nanometer, where you do have visibility in them now moving and hence, we made the comment on the growth of our Virtex7 product offering, those products are now starting to move into production and we expect that to be a portion of this snap back. And then of course, on the wireless side, there are elements, which we expect, as Jon elaborated on, we expect China to have that need and it's only a question of when and that needs to start happening soon on the wireless infrastructure too.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess as  my quick follow up, 1 for you, Jon, on the OpEx side, great job controlling those expenses in the a quarter and the guide good. From your description of what's going on in lowering the full year by about 3%, it sounds like there's an aspect of
componenttext: I guess as  my quick follow up, 1 for you, Jon, on the OpEx side, great job controlling those expenses in the a quarter and the guide good. From your description of what's going on in lowering the full year by about 3%, it sounds like there's an aspect of tightening the belt overall and then also some timing issues on OpEx. Are you expecting us to exit this year at the same sort of OpEx level that we would have before and therefore fiscal '17 would kind of be the same as we would have thought before? Or is this truly a cut in OpEx levels longer term?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the whole origin of the restructuring in the first place was around driving efficiency and getting more focused in areas, particularly in the sales area to accelerate our wins at customers. And that was really the genesis for doing it. And we sat
componenttext: Yes. So the whole origin of the restructuring in the first place was around driving efficiency and getting more focused in areas, particularly in the sales area to accelerate our wins at customers. And that was really the genesis for doing it. And we sat there in the March timeframe and Investor Day obviously we knew we were doing restructuring but we never comment in advance on that for a variety of reasons. And the guide that we gave in March, there were certainly some things that weren't decided yet until our restructuring efforts even out early in March. As we've got through to really dissecting the sales organization and changing the focus away from reps to direct selling, this is where we've garner the biggest part of the dollar drop in the change in our guide since March. So it's really reflective of us figuring out how to put the right resources in the right places and sometimes that means you actually spend less when you have the right resources and that's the primary driver of what the reduction -- the net reduction that we have going on. Now your question around the exit rate, as I said in my remarks, the first quarter is particularly low and that's because we have a ramp headcount backup. I do think that the second quarter, we have a lot of more tape outs going on and that bounces around throughout the rest of the year and our exit rate at of Q4 will suggest some tick up and would suggest that some tick up in FY '17 but -- by the way, we're not there, so I'm not signaling that we're going to have a tick up in FY '17. So it will look like the Q1's low and then Q2, Q3, Q4 will be more flattish throughout the year but we certainly aren't making a statement yet about FY '17 spending.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

TheStreet doesn't get it that there is a serious opportunity for PLDs in the data center and I think Altera has quantified it as $1 billion in 2020. So any parts around that would be very helpful.

componenttext: Well, it's a rumor and the prices are a rumor and whether it's happening or not happening is a rumor too. We're delighted with the attention this gets and we think that obviously, there's potential for growth. With regards to prices and all of that, it shows the perceived value of programmable logic, which I'm a big lever in. So I'm delighted with that general trend. Hopefully, the entire world would see the light.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as we said in Investor Day, there will be some residual shipments into some of these major programs at the very beginning of the fiscal year '16 but at a much diminished rate. By the time we get to through the first half of our fiscal year which i
componenttext: Yes, so as we said in Investor Day, there will be some residual shipments into some of these major programs at the very beginning of the fiscal year '16 but at a much diminished rate. By the time we get to through the first half of our fiscal year which is at the end of September, I would say a great deal that will be away and the biggest piece of it will be in June. So I would say, by the end of June it's largely gone, with some residual going on in the following quarters.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: First, just a housekeeping 1. You reset guidance on OpEx. I just want to confirm you're keeping the gross margin guidance that you've offered previously for the full year?

componenttext: Yes, we are.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the more substantial question I had is in the press release you talked and I think at the Analyst Day, you talked about this, as well, these new software development tools that are targeted at data center and SDN and industrial IoT, I'm wo
componenttext: Great. And then the more substantial question I had is in the press release you talked and I think at the Analyst Day, you talked about this, as well, these new software development tools that are targeted at data center and SDN and industrial IoT, I'm wondering if you could help us understand whether that's expected to accelerate your growth through perhaps share gains versus Altera or is it versus some of the other, maybe the other SoC vendors or is it to grow the market. Any color on the expected effect from these tools be helpful?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the expected -- let me post the challenge that we have and if you look at our product, they, in numerous applications, enable our customers to achieve very attractive parameters in terms of performance per watt or price performance per watt. In other w
componenttext: So the expected -- let me post the challenge that we have and if you look at our product, they, in numerous applications, enable our customers to achieve very attractive parameters in terms of performance per watt or price performance per watt. In other words, they can achieve a -- they can implement differentiated highly competitive system. In order to do that, they need to go through a design cycle, which requires a certain set of skills and in order to increase the population or universe of users of our product, what we have done is we've developed these tools. These tools tend to be somewhat application-specific or it's not 1 size fits all. They tend to have different targets but once you use these tools, you can enable usage by a broader fit of customers and in particular, engineers with more of the software background and there are a lot more software engineers than hardware engineers. And the reason we are doing it is in order to expand the fan and the intention here is to provide an alternative -- an attractive alternative ASSP standard product. So that's what this is. This is some expansion and this enables us to do target markets, which today are service by ASSPs because the engineers at some of these companies and data center is very good example, typically do not have hardware design skills and we're developing these tools to facilitate that expansion.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri from CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Srini Pajjuri from CLSA.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Ryan Goodman in for Srini. So I had a another question on China LTE. We have the FDD licensing now behind us but it seems like the near-term trends are still softening a bit. So I'm just trying to understand how much visibility you have here. We all
componenttext: It's Ryan Goodman in for Srini. So I had a another question on China LTE. We have the FDD licensing now behind us but it seems like the near-term trends are still softening a bit. So I'm just trying to understand how much visibility you have here. We all know it's all going to happen at some point  but are you starting some FDD orders coming in for the back half of the year or if not, just what are your expectations there? And then also, are you seeing any impact from potential tower sharing going on in China at this point?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Ryan, the China FD on the China LTE is we've already seen builds going on by the OEMs and we get more of our information through the OEMs than anywhere else. So there are already have been some builds and some shipment on the FD. So this is more of
componenttext: Sure. Ryan, the China FD on the China LTE is we've already seen builds going on by the OEMs and we get more of our information through the OEMs than anywhere else. So there are already have been some builds and some shipment on the FD. So this is more of a timing issue as best as we can tell and what our customers are telling us versus their changing their longer-term forecast for us, they don't. There's certainly no orders booked for the second half of the year at this point in time because our lead times are generally pretty short, so there's not a whole lot of emphasis on the part of the OEMs to commit through a PO early even though they do provide us some guidance on forecast and we don't see an overall lower number than we had anticipated maybe even in early March. So really is more of a temporary slowness best as we can tell as anything else. On the tower sharing now, we really haven't seen any impact whatsoever of the tower sharing. It doesn't even come up in our conversations. The issue there is really more about new towers, not all towers, so that's really not a factor.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just different question on the cash side. So cash return was great this year, you forgot the history of it, it's been pretty consistent. Just any thoughts on where, I don't know if you have a formal target on it for the coming year o
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just different question on the cash side. So cash return was great this year, you forgot the history of it, it's been pretty consistent. Just any thoughts on where, I don't know if you have a formal target on it for the coming year or maybe an idea of how you're thinking about of the year versus operating cash flow?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We don't have a formal target but if we look at the history over the last 10 years, we returned 100% of our operating cash. We did 120% last year. We've increased our dividend for the 10th year in a row. We will continue a share repurchase program on
componenttext: Yes. We don't have a formal target but if we look at the history over the last 10 years, we returned 100% of our operating cash. We did 120% last year. We've increased our dividend for the 10th year in a row. We will continue a share repurchase program on an opportunistic level and we have stated as long as we don't have an acquisition target or something that is using any of the excess cash. At a bigger level, we will return cash to shareholders, so I think you can count on us continuing to do that but again, I'm not going to make a commitment on a percentage.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ian Ing from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. question, can you talk about any sort of price increases you think your international distributor customers are seeing, whether it's based on currency or pricing more to reflect value and would there be any impact on demand or is demand pretty inelas
componenttext: Yes. question, can you talk about any sort of price increases you think your international distributor customers are seeing, whether it's based on currency or pricing more to reflect value and would there be any impact on demand or is demand pretty inelastic?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not really seeing anything that's significant in the price increase area. I was concerned on the second part of your question about the demand impact particularly at smaller customers and we've seen -- we had strong channel sales in this last q
componenttext: Yes, we're not really seeing anything that's significant in the price increase area. I was concerned on the second part of your question about the demand impact particularly at smaller customers and we've seen -- we had strong channel sales in this last quarter and we are forecasting strong channel sales again, including European, which I assume is the biggest source of your question, including on the European side. So it's really not at this point has been a big of a deal as value was fearful of but because well, we had maybe a soft quarter a quarter or 2 ago, things have come back pretty nicely.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then do you have any thoughts on the trends on the size of the FPGA design community? Is it still going and is it largely driven by Zynq? Do you have any sort of metrics to support that, whether it's design kits shipped or design kits installed
componenttext: Great. And then do you have any thoughts on the trends on the size of the FPGA design community? Is it still going and is it largely driven by Zynq? Do you have any sort of metrics to support that, whether it's design kits shipped or design kits installed?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the Zynq product offering was a breakthrough offering. It was the generally the last part of the rollout and as such, there was a large number of design wins. Now those design wins, which were targeted at somewhat slower moving markets like industri
componenttext: Well, the Zynq product offering was a breakthrough offering. It was the generally the last part of the rollout and as such, there was a large number of design wins. Now those design wins, which were targeted at somewhat slower moving markets like industrial and automotive, those design wins are moving to production. So it's a unique product. The number of design wins is phenomenal. We are learning because of it, nature in some cases it takes longer. It's also a more sophisticated product hence, it takes a little longer to do. It requires both software and hardware. It has a high-performance embedded processor system. The number of design wins is just huge and the overall magnitude of the design win value on Zynq is very encouraging. It's very significant and now, it is finally starting to grow a very healthy clip. So until last year, it was relatively negligible in terms of the portion of revenue but now it's growing at a fast rate and as these applications in automotive, wireless and aero and industrial control is starting to hit production.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think also specific on design kits and our design board environment. In terms of numbers of kits and boards, I mean, it's just totally swamped in terms of numbers, all previous FPGA boards, because of the nature of the cost and the price point  that man
componenttext: I think also specific on design kits and our design board environment. In terms of numbers of kits and boards, I mean, it's just totally swamped in terms of numbers, all previous FPGA boards, because of the nature of the cost and the price point  that many of these applications are going after, more of the $700 million versus the $800 or $900 kind of ASP and so both our distributor and Xilinx has a number of inexpensive boards and kits and those numbers -- the numbers of those tath have been shipped out over the last couple of years are just really phenomenal. So we really think we are seeding the industry really well with this capabilities.

componenttext: Yes, so Joe, we really haven't had any, I would say, any lead time increase on a broad perspective. There was a class of products that we have had a little bit of lead time increase but I wouldn't say it's going to be that material of an impact to anything or logistics. So I don't think that's been a particularly, if there's anything there that concern anybody from a logistic supply perspective. What was the second part of your question again?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Cycle time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The cycle time. No, we see no push out or lengthening of cycle time. We're getting all the way because we order when we order then there's no -- nothing going on there either for us.
componenttext: The cycle time. No, we see no push out or lengthening of cycle time. We're getting all the way because we order when we order then there's no -- nothing going on there either for us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then we also heard about possible consolidation in your distributor network. Could you elaborate there if that's true?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then we also heard about possible consolidation in your distributor network. Could you elaborate there if that's true?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, not really. It was a rough network where we terminated a variety of reps. In Japan, we are transitioning. We have a number of reps in Japan and the nature of that business is a little different than the rest of the world and we are transitioning one o
componenttext: No, not really. It was a rough network where we terminated a variety of reps. In Japan, we are transitioning. We have a number of reps in Japan and the nature of that business is a little different than the rest of the world and we are transitioning one of the reps to -- into our other rep network. That's the only really transition that we have --  excuse me, distributor in China, not rep, distributor in China. 1 distributor moving into our other distributors in terms of the business but nothing other than those 2 things. So reps in the U.S. and Europe. Generally, we're transitioning to direct sales. And then in Japan, there's a distributor that we're terminating and moving that business to other distributors that we already have.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Gauna from JMP Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Gauna from JMP Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I know you've already touched on this twice but coming back to the implications of a potential Intel-Altera merger and Altera's optimism around data center acceleration through the massively parallel architectures of programmable logic. I'm just wo
componenttext: Moshe, I know you've already touched on this twice but coming back to the implications of a potential Intel-Altera merger and Altera's optimism around data center acceleration through the massively parallel architectures of programmable logic. I'm just wondering are you in fact involved, I know you are heavily exposed to the data center but are you involved in using the FPGA architecture to accelerate workload? Is this tens of million, hundreds of millions of opportunity for you? And then if you think about what's obviously happening with co-packaged FPGA and CPUs, how far in the future does it make sense in the workload acceleration sense to think about convergence wherein the processing and the FPGA are a single die?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. There's a lot of questions there. So we think there is an opportunity there, that's why we have the SD XL product model which now we are releasing to our customers. And we strongly believe that, that together with a stronger focus on this market sho
componenttext: Okay. There's a lot of questions there. So we think there is an opportunity there, that's why we have the SD XL product model which now we are releasing to our customers. And we strongly believe that, that together with a stronger focus on this market should enable us to reap the benefits of it. We think it's a significant market. There is -- whether it it's tens of millions or several hundreds of millions of dollars, we think it's going to take time to grow to those larger numbers and it take quite a long time and we are committed to having the best solution with regards to acceleration which addresses those markets, and whether it's x86-based or ARM-based or approach, then we're going to pursue solutions for that market. So now, I think we're well positioned and the key to our leadership is now in the software which enables achieving or getting at that acceleration in the most efficient way. And that's how we view it. It's a big market but maybe not quite as huge in the short-term as maybe others have positioned it.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then just to clarify on that, obviously, you said it will take some time but from a convergence sense, is this one of those situations where the nature of the architectures and the workloads mean that for the foreseeable future, we can think of
componenttext: Okay, and then just to clarify on that, obviously, you said it will take some time but from a convergence sense, is this one of those situations where the nature of the architectures and the workloads mean that for the foreseeable future, we can think of it as a co-loaded -- co-located FPGA and processing solution or are there clear benefits to convergence where we think about single die FPGA and CPU being really important in terms of accelerating that market?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, think of die helps but comes at a cost and the cost that you get typically is flexibility. The nature of these applications is they're very, very fragmented and everyone of them tends to have a different payload and actually, that payload is dynamic
componenttext: Well, think of die helps but comes at a cost and the cost that you get typically is flexibility. The nature of these applications is they're very, very fragmented and everyone of them tends to have a different payload and actually, that payload is dynamic so if you're using it to accelerate some sort of algorithm, the algorithm that you're accelerating changes all the time. And so if you do too much integration and you tend to have a very inflexible solution, you might end up losing, right? So when we talk to the customers and these tend to be a different class of companies. And their approach as they want to retain as much control over there acceleration path and they rather not give that to anyone else. And if you look at the way their approach has been typically, they do not buy from the traditional server companies. They actually build their own and they try to come up with a very specific solution, which is the most valuable for them. So there is a case to be made for integration but what you lose when you do the integration is a lot of the flexibility, which is inherently important for this market. And so I would say it's gray. In some cases it might go towards integration and others, actually having a separate solution and being able to maintain the flexibility there is a huge benefit.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttextpreview: We have not seen a pause as a result of whatever's been in this paper and their stated position on this. Moshe was only, I think, talking in general about when 2 companies get together, what can happen in terms of how their organizations melt altogether.
componenttext: We have not seen a pause as a result of whatever's been in this paper and their stated position on this. Moshe was only, I think, talking in general about when 2 companies get together, what can happen in terms of how their organizations melt altogether. At this point in time, as best as we can tell, this is not going to be consummated at the earliest later this calendar year, maybe in next calendar year. We're not seeing any sort of pause with our business with either company at this point in time.

componenttext: As best as we can tell, this is more about CapEx China macro. I mean, I don't want to say macro but China related CapEx spend in the pace that they're getting funded internally to do things and I don't know what else. Some of it there's always the politics between the FD standard and the TD standard and it's hard to tell whether that's still causing delays in FD as a result of TD being -- trying to be more dominant but I do know that I'm qualified to comment on whether how much of that is true or not.

componenttext: So this was a topic which is very sensitive. We have the capacity. You can tell by our track record that we do this very, very cautiously. The nature of our business is much of that it has a unique element to it. So doing acquisitions for acquisitions sake is not for us. So the answer is we could do it. We know how to do it. At this point, if you look at where we are and what we've done, it's primarily been technology acquisitions as opposed to acquiring other companies that had a totally different business model and modus operandi.

Good afternoon. My name is Lisa, and I will be your conference operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Xilinx Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha. Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We'll provide a financial and business review of the March quarter and then we'll open the call for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our conference call tod
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We'll provide a financial and business review of the March quarter and then we'll open the call for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Jon Olson.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Fiscal 2015 was another strong year of profitability for the company with operating income up 31.8%, the highest in 4 years. Industrial and aerospace and defense category increased 7% for the year, representing a record 39% of total sales
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Fiscal 2015 was another strong year of profitability for the company with operating income up 31.8%, the highest in 4 years. Industrial and aerospace and defense category increased 7% for the year, representing a record 39% of total sales. The communication segment declined 5% impacted by lower-than-expected CapEx spend in many of our sub-applications. The broadcast, consumer and automotive category decreased 2%. However, the automotive subsegment grew significantly, increasing 30% during the year. For the company as a whole, fiscal year sales were $2.4 billion, flat with the prior year. Gross margin was a record 70% for the fiscal year, benefiting from end market mix, as well as continued cost reduction and margin expansion initiatives across our product platform portfolio. In fiscal year 2015, we returned over 120% of our operating cash flow to shareholders, which represents about 40% of our revenues. This consisted of a record $306 million in dividend payout and a stock repurchase of 15.3 million shares for $650 million. The March quarter of fiscal 2015 marked the 10th consecutive year of dividend increases for the company, putting Xilinx in a very elite group of technology companies.
Cash flow per share has increased at a compound annual rate of 14% in the past 10 years, driven by a combination of gross margin expansion, disciplined expense controls, working capital management and share repurchase.
Turning now to a discussion of the March quarter. Xilinx sales were $567 million, down 4% sequentially and within our guidance. 28-nanometer sales exceeded $160 million as forecasted. Sales from communications and data center declined 7% sequentially and were weaker than anticipated. Wired communication was approximately flat as expected while wireless sales decreased double digits. The weakness in the wireless segment was primarily due to continued softness in North America and a weakening in China LTE business. Industrial and aerospace and defense business also decreased, although not as much as anticipated during the quarter. Expected declines from defense were partially offset by better-than-expected business from both industrial, scientific and medical, as well as test and measurement.
Lastly, broadcast, consumer and automotive was better than expected with automotive achieving a record quarter, while broadcast was flat and consumer was down. Gross margin was 69.9% for the quarter, better than anticipated primarily as a result of product and customer mix, although we continue to be focused on driving improvements in profitability. Combined R&D and SG&A expense were $211 million, significantly lower than forecasted primarily as a result of lower stock-based compensation expense in addition to continued cost efforts.
Operating income was $159 million, including amortization of $2.4 million and a $24 million restructuring charge or $0.08 per diluted share. The restructuring charge reflects the impact of streamlining certain internal organizations, as well as the impact of a transition from sales reps to a direct sales model for certain customers. Other income was $1 million, higher than guided primarily due to an $8 million gain or $0.03 per diluted share from the sale of land.
Net income for the quarter was $135 million or $0.50 per diluted share. Operating cash flow for the March quarter was $166 million before $6 million in CapEx during the quarter. Diluted shares for the quarter were 270 million, slightly less than forecasted and down 25 million shares from the same quarter a year ago. There was a 5.7 million share dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions related to the dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.xilinx.com. We repurchased 4.4 million shares for $175 million during the quarter and paid $70 million in dividends.
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments were flat sequentially at $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt, resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion. Inventory dollars at Xilinx decreased by $15 million sequentially, but days increased to 136.
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the June quarter of fiscal year '16. Our backlog heading into the quarter is up sequentially. Both wired and wireless communications are expected to decline. Wired communication remains sluggish, although data center will likely increase. Wireless will be impacted by slowing China LTE build in the near term. We expect the industrial and aerospace and defense segment to be down, driven primarily by continued expected decreases from A&D. Lastly, we expect broadcast, consumer and automotive to be approximately flat. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be flat to down 4% sequentially. And the midpoint of this guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 47%. The lower turns rate is primarily due to a couple of large customers being more fully booked to expectations and a regional distributor transition.
Gross margin is expected to be approximately 69% to 70%. Operating expenses for the June quarter are expected to be approximately $210 million, including $2 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. The Q1 fiscal '16 operating expense level will be at its lowest level for the year due to lower tape-out activity and timing of expenses to ramp up headcount post-restructuring. The headcount additions will be largely driven by hiring in the sales force and to a lesser degree in R&D.
For the full year, we are lowering our spending forecast as follows: R&D is expected to be between $530 million and $540 million; SG&A will be between $340 million and $360 million; amortization of intangibles will be approximately $8 million; other income and expense for the June quarter will be a net expense of $12 million, due to lower interest income and anticipated hedging losses. For the full year, other interest and expense will be a net expense of approximately $33 million. The share count is expected to be approximately 266 million shares. The tax rate for the June quarter is expected to be approximately 13%.
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. We are very pleased with the strength of our 28-nanometer products which exceeded $160 million. As expected, we continue to expand the breadth of 28-nanometer sales contribution. The strength of our Virtex-7
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. We are very pleased with the strength of our 28-nanometer products which exceeded $160 million. As expected, we continue to expand the breadth of 28-nanometer sales contribution. The strength of our Virtex-7 high-end family and Zynq all programmable SoC was a particular highlight, driving 28-nanometer sales growth in wired comms, industrial and automotive applications. For the fiscal year 2015, 28-nanometer revenue reached $580 million, driven by broad-based growth from all end markets and each of the 4 28-nanometer product families. 28-nanometer product generation continues to be the most successful node in history, and we believe will have the longest life of any node. As we discussed at our Investor Day last month, we are targeting [indiscernible] sales to grow approximately 30% in fiscal year 2016.
Gross margin performance was another significant highlight for both fourth quarter and the year. Gross margin increased to 69.9% in the quarter, significantly better than forecasted and a record 70.2% for fiscal year 2015. Proven formula for successful execution established at 28-nanometer continues to yield excellent results for 20-nanometer with the UltraScale family. Leveraging our world-class partnership with TSMC, the undisputed leader in the foundry industry, we're now delivering the industry's first and only 20-nanometer FPGA volume production. Based on key customer feedback, we are more than 1 year ahead of the competition in terms of product robustness and quality. Additionally, we're shipping the industry's only high-performance ASIC class 20-nanometer high-end product offering with Virtex UltraScale. Finally, with our second generation of 3D IC technology, we're shipping the industry's largest device, delivering more than 4x the density of competitive devices. We're currently shipping 20-nanometer parts to approximately 100 discrete customers, demonstrating the broad-based acceptance of this family. This past quarter, sales from our 20-nanometer node were $5 million, and we expect these sales to double in the June quarter.
The 16-nanometer node, we launched the UltraScale+ family of FPGAs, 3D ICs and Zynq MPSoCs, combining embedded memory, 3D-on-3D and multiprocessing SoC technologies. Optimized at the system level, the UltraScale+ family provides 2 to 5x greater system level performance per watt, significantly more systems integration and intelligence, and the highest level of security and safety. We continue to anticipate the first tape-out of our 16-nanometer FinFET+ process to be this quarter.
During the March quarter, we also strengthened our family of SDx software-defined development environment with the launch of the SDSoC product. This environment enables a much larger software and systems development community to program our Zynq SoCs and MPSoCs, target high-growth opportunities, areas such as data center acceleration, software-defined networking, embedded vision and the industrial Internet of Things. Despite the near-term revenue growth challenges, I continue to be confident in our strategy to resume top line growth. Additionally, we are driving increased efficiencies in our operating model to improve productivity and appropriately align spending levels with the fiscal year '16 sales outlook we've previously provided.
We now turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

componenttext: So John, that continues to be our target. And it obviously will start from a low point if we hit our range, but we expect to see it grow during the year. And we are confident that as the communications business starts to recover, that will be one of the numerous drivers of the growth, together with all of the technology elements that I referred to before.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Moshe. And then specifically on your comments around China. To what extent do you think this is a pause in base station build-out in China versus perhaps too much inventory with some of the equipment guys that we need to burn through. I'm
componenttext: That's helpful, Moshe. And then specifically on your comments around China. To what extent do you think this is a pause in base station build-out in China versus perhaps too much inventory with some of the equipment guys that we need to burn through. I'm just trying to get a sense of how much of this do you think is a real pause in demand versus perhaps a realignment of kind of inventory within the supply chain?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, this is Jon. Let me -- I'm just going to take that one. So it's always a little of both, right? Meaning, in general, the Chinese manufacturers try to get ahead of the awards as much as they can, but when there is a falling demand situation like
componenttext: Yes, John, this is Jon. Let me -- I'm just going to take that one. So it's always a little of both, right? Meaning, in general, the Chinese manufacturers try to get ahead of the awards as much as they can, but when there is a falling demand situation like we have now or a delay, I would say, particularly from an FD ramp perspective, it is really more about that pause and when the ramp starts to build a little more precipitously. We did think all along that our communications business, wireless specifically, would build throughout the year. So that part, while it may be starting off a little weaker than we anticipated, it isn't really radically scaring us much at this point in time. They're just -- China is just going through some overall CapEx modifications. And the FD stuff is going to happen. It's just going to happen -- start a little bit slower, but we do think we've accommodated that in our full year forecast.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we were very pleased with our 28-nanometer growth in the quarter. So new products are growing, including data center this quarter. So we had good contribution from the new product category. It's really some of the older stuff that wasn't quite as stron
componenttext: So we were very pleased with our 28-nanometer growth in the quarter. So new products are growing, including data center this quarter. So we had good contribution from the new product category. It's really some of the older stuff that wasn't quite as strong as we then had anticipated in some of the sub-applications. So I would say, we saw some -- I don't really know the details of all the subsegments that Broadcom were in, but we did see strength in these new products. So as those build throughout the year, meaning the new programs and some of the customer differences, I think we'll see good growth in the wired market from new products continue throughout the year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Very helpful, Jon. And then as my follow-up, I'm curious what your views are on this potential combination of Intel and Altera. Is that -- if that were to happen, is that a net positive or neutral or does it present any kind of risk for you? And i
componenttext: Got it. Very helpful, Jon. And then as my follow-up, I'm curious what your views are on this potential combination of Intel and Altera. Is that -- if that were to happen, is that a net positive or neutral or does it present any kind of risk for you? And if that combination does happen, would you also need to take any steps towards consolidation?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, in the 15 minutes of fame for the programmable world, I'm sort of surprised that this was a third question and not the first, but thanks for asking it. And from our perspective, regardless of whether that happens or it doesn't happen, whether
componenttext: Okay. Well, in the 15 minutes of fame for the programmable world, I'm sort of surprised that this was a third question and not the first, but thanks for asking it. And from our perspective, regardless of whether that happens or it doesn't happen, whether it's a rumor or whether it's true or not, we're very confident. And the reason that we're very confident is that we continue to distance ourselves from the competition. And we believe we are poised to now deliver a three-peat. We've won at 28-nanometer. We believe we have huge leadership at 20-nanometer, and we are very confident in our position at 16-nanometer. We have leadership with our ASIC class tools and also the new tools, the software-defined environment are huge enablers for business expansion. If this rumor does come to pass and that this acquisition will happen, we believe that will be a net positive for us because it will give us the additional significant advantage of being the only vendor with this very service-oriented business, with the total focus, the best foundry, strategic relationship with ARM, leadership on the road map and generally, continuity of operation. So whether it happens or not, we don't know. But our position is very strong, and we are very confident in where we are. And we believe that this gap between us and the competition will just grow going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I know you discussed a little bit on the China dynamic in the communications market. Maybe you could also comment on what you're seeing in North America. I know you mentioned the softness in the March quarter, but
componenttext: This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. I know you discussed a little bit on the China dynamic in the communications market. Maybe you could also comment on what you're seeing in North America. I know you mentioned the softness in the March quarter, but maybe there's a little bit of stabilization in June. So any color on North America and maybe Europe and some of the other geographies as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gabriela. North America continues to be weak for us. I think we've had a couple of quarters of relatively weak transitions or weak revenue there. One of the bigger expansions that have been going on over the last year or so has been the Sprint deplo
componenttext: Sure, Gabriela. North America continues to be weak for us. I think we've had a couple of quarters of relatively weak transitions or weak revenue there. One of the bigger expansions that have been going on over the last year or so has been the Sprint deployment, and they slowed down substantially. There seems to be some CapEx spend financing things going on here and there, and that's been slower for us on a relative basis to how strong we are to the ultimate OEMs who won those contracts. We don't -- best as what we can tell, we don't think this is some sort of a permanent thing. Some of those things are getting worked out as we talk to our customers in that particular area. I mean, largely, the AT&T and Verizon businesses is add-ons and capacity extensions, nothing significant going on there quite frankly in terms of the CapEx spend. It's really around Sprint and T-Mobile. And we're well positioned there. But it has definitely decelerated over the last couple of quarters, but we don't expect that to continue for the full year. Europe, while there has been some sales into Europe, it's still a little early, and we don't have, I would say, a clear view nor are we counting on a big percentage of that business to come in until maybe very late in the fiscal year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, if I may, could you help us think through the implications  of the Alcatel-Lucent Nokia merger and maybe any context you can provide based on what happened in 2006, which I think the last time we saw customer consolidation?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, if I may, could you help us think through the implications  of the Alcatel-Lucent Nokia merger and maybe any context you can provide based on what happened in 2006, which I think the last time we saw customer consolidation?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So wireless generally is a market where, as you point out, has been consolidated for some period of time. And we fundamentally believe that the -- or at least, I believe that the catalyst for all of this is the emergence of the very strong players in Chin
componenttext: So wireless generally is a market where, as you point out, has been consolidated for some period of time. And we fundamentally believe that the -- or at least, I believe that the catalyst for all of this is the emergence of the very strong players in China. And that is forcing the other non-Chinese players to bulk up and strengthen up. And from our perspective, both of these companies are significant customers of ours. And as they merge, if they come out strengthened, that should improve our business. And we think that this will provide them with a better market position to compete against the other players who have been pulling ahead recently. So given our market position with these 2 players and the potential for growth with both of them, I think, as they merge, it will provide a growth path for us going forward, assuming the combined player will emerge stronger, as indeed they should. There does tend to be a little bit of confusion when it starts because these are 2 very large, very diverse companies with geographic footprints in different spaces. And I do believe that at least as they're doing the merger, there will be a little bit of a hiatus, but then it will -- as the merger is completed, they'll probably have renewed growth going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess first, Moshe, one on your side and still on that kind of comm infrastructure side of things. From as close as I can check, whether it was the end market or Xilinx specifically, you've had 3 quarters in a row of tough results. Can you talk a little
componenttext: I guess first, Moshe, one on your side and still on that kind of comm infrastructure side of things. From as close as I can check, whether it was the end market or Xilinx specifically, you've had 3 quarters in a row of tough results. Can you talk a little bit about what gives you the confidence that we're going to see a snapback in the back half of the year, especially on the wireline side where, I believe, on the last conference call, you talk about being relatively puzzled as to why design wins weren't turning into revenue for Xilinx?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the reason we're confident that this needs to reverse is, at some point, there is a mismatch between the infrastructure requirements to the drivers which --- basically, a lot of this is driven by consumer and business demand. And we think that on the w
componenttext: So the reason we're confident that this needs to reverse is, at some point, there is a mismatch between the infrastructure requirements to the drivers which --- basically, a lot of this is driven by consumer and business demand. And we think that on the wired side, that time is approaching and that our very strong product portfolio will enable us to capture that as it happens. There is an incessant need for an investment in the infrastructure, and I think that it has been shortchanged for too long. So you are right in pointing out that we've been disappointed and that this has taken longer. And actually, we have predicted this before, but at this point, what we're seeing is a lot of the designs that we reaped at the high end of the 28-nanometer are now moving to production. And those got delayed roughly by a year vis–à–vis our initial expectations. So between the market demand and the design wins we have at 28-nanometer, where we do have visibility in them now moving and hence, we made the comment on the growth of our Virtex-7 product offering. Those products are now starting to move into production, and we expect that to be a portion of this snapback. And then of course, on the wireless side, there is elements which we expect. As Jon elaborated on, we expect China to have that need. And it's only a question of when and that needs to start happening soon on the wireless infrastructure, too.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I guess as  my quick follow-up, one for you, Jon, on the OpEx side, great job controlling those expenses in the quarter and the guide. From your description of what's going on in lowering the full year by about 3%, it sounds like there's an aspect
componenttext: Great. I guess as  my quick follow-up, one for you, Jon, on the OpEx side, great job controlling those expenses in the quarter and the guide. From your description of what's going on in lowering the full year by about 3%, it sounds like there's an aspect of tightening the belt overall and then also some timing issues on OpEx. Are you expecting us to exit this year at the same sort of OpEx level that we would have before and therefore, fiscal '17 would kind of be the same as we would have thought before or is this truly a cut in OpEx levels longer term?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the whole origin of the restructuring in the first place was around driving efficiency and getting more focus in areas, particularly in the sales area to accelerate our wins at customers. And that was really the genesis for doing it. And we sat th
componenttext: Yes. So the whole origin of the restructuring in the first place was around driving efficiency and getting more focus in areas, particularly in the sales area to accelerate our wins at customers. And that was really the genesis for doing it. And we sat there in the March time frame in Investor Day, obviously, we knew we were doing restructuring, but we never comment in advance on that for a variety of reasons. And in the guide that we gave in March, there were certainly some things that weren't decided yet to our restructuring efforts even that early in March. As we got through to really dissecting the sales organization and changing the focus away from reps to direct selling, this is where we've garnered the biggest part of the dollar drop in the change in our guide since March. So it's really reflective of us figuring out how to put the right resources in the right places and sometimes that means you actually spend less when you have the right resources. And that's the primary driver of what the reduction -- the net reduction that we have going on. Now your question around the exit rate, as I said in my remarks, the first quarter is particularly low, and that's because we haven't ramped headcount back up. I do think that in the second quarter, we have a lot of more tape-outs going on, and that bounces around throughout the rest of the year. And our exit rate in -- out of Q4 will suggest some tick up in -- would suggest some tick up in FY '17, but -- oh, by the way, we're not there yet, so I'm not signaling that we are going to have a tick up in FY '17. So it will look like that the Q1's low and then Q2, Q3, Q4 will be more flattish throughout the year, but we certainly aren't making a statement yet about FY '17 spending.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ambrish Srivastava from BMO.

componenttext: And I'm sorry, collectively, we disappointed you with that question not being #1. I did have a follow-up on that, which is, when you heard, and if it's true that whatever price was offered and what was asked, did you fall off your chair or you said, "Okay, Intel gets it." The Street doesn't get it that there's this huge opportunity for PLDs in the data center. And I think Altera has quantified it as $1 billion in 2020. So any thoughts around that would be very helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you know it's a rumor and the prices are a rumor, and whether it's happening or not happening is a rumor, too. We're delighted with the attention this gets, and we think that, obviously, there's potential for growth. With regards to prices and all o
componenttext: Well, you know it's a rumor and the prices are a rumor, and whether it's happening or not happening is a rumor, too. We're delighted with the attention this gets, and we think that, obviously, there's potential for growth. With regards to prices and all of that, it shows the perceived value of programmable logic, which I'm a big believer in. So I'm delighted with that general trend. Hopefully, the entire world will see the light.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra from Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tristan Gerra from Baird.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you quantify the headwind from end-of-life products embedded in the June quarter guidance? And is that headwind done by end of the quarter?
componenttext: Could you quantify the headwind from end-of-life products embedded in the June quarter guidance? And is that headwind done by end of the quarter?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as we said in the Investor Day, there would be some residual shipments into some of these major programs at the very beginning of the fiscal year '16, but at a much diminished rate. So by the time we get to -- through the first half of our fiscal
componenttext: Yes, so as we said in the Investor Day, there would be some residual shipments into some of these major programs at the very beginning of the fiscal year '16, but at a much diminished rate. So by the time we get to -- through the first half of our fiscal year, which is the end of September, I would say a great deal of that will be away and the biggest piece of it will be in June. So I would say, by the end of June, it's largely gone, with some residual going on in the following quarters.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
