headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think I heard you guys saying you were trying to beef up the direct sales effort versus the distib reps. I'm curious which end markets do you feel like that's most important for, if any? And if it is the data center and try and target the cloud guys,
componenttext: So I think I heard you guys saying you were trying to beef up the direct sales effort versus the distib reps. I'm curious which end markets do you feel like that's most important for, if any? And if it is the data center and try and target the cloud guys, is that somewhere you feel like you have to catch up versus competition or is that the wrong read on this?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have now restructured our sales force to be tiered with 2 direct elements and the third element which goes through distib. We're managing that a little more closely than we have before. With the largest accounts, primarily in communications and data ce
componenttext: We have now restructured our sales force to be tiered with 2 direct elements and the third element which goes through distib. We're managing that a little more closely than we have before. With the largest accounts, primarily in communications and data center, we believe that we would benefit from a more direct interaction because fundamentally the level of engagement needs to be deeper than it was before. And are we doing this later than ideally we should have? We probably are. In retrospect, this would probably have benefited from making this transition a year or 2 ago.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think also, I mean, it's not just -- this is not only focused at one end market. There is going to be some transitions going on even in our aerospace and defense market coverage into more direct sales. And I know some of these don't -- some of these
componenttext: And I think also, I mean, it's not just -- this is not only focused at one end market. There is going to be some transitions going on even in our aerospace and defense market coverage into more direct sales. And I know some of these don't -- some of these kind of wins don't turn into immediate revenue. They're slower, but it does have both industrial, aerospace and defense, test and measurement, as well as the communication segments impacted. And we -- I do think it's a net positive for us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That explanation helps. And then also I know the China LTE carrier pause question has been asked a lot, but I just want to ask one out of the way. Anecdotally, what are your customers and your customers' customers telling you about why this g
componenttext: Okay, great. That explanation helps. And then also I know the China LTE carrier pause question has been asked a lot, but I just want to ask one out of the way. Anecdotally, what are your customers and your customers' customers telling you about why this group of buyers is pausing at this juncture? Is it macro? Is it concerns about LTE sub ramp? Or is it technical reasons in terms of Cloud RAN architecture feature? What do you think anecdotally?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: As best as we can tell, this is more about a CapEx China macro. I mean, I don't want to say macro, but China macro-related CapEx spend and the pace that they're getting funded internally to do things. And I don't know what else. Some of it is always the p
componenttext: As best as we can tell, this is more about a CapEx China macro. I mean, I don't want to say macro, but China macro-related CapEx spend and the pace that they're getting funded internally to do things. And I don't know what else. Some of it is always the politics between the FD standard and the TD standard. And it's hard to tell whether that's still causing delays in FD as a result of TD being -- trying to be and China Mobile trying to be more dominant, but I don't know that I'm qualified to comment on whether how much of that is true or not.

I'm not going to get into the real specifics, but the second half would be lower than the first half. But we're still confident in delivering our stated goal from Investor Day.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is a topic which is very sensitive. We have the capacity. You can tell by our track record that we do this very, very cautiously. The nature of our business is such that it has a unique element to it. So doing acquisitions for acquisitions' sake i
componenttext: So this is a topic which is very sensitive. We have the capacity. You can tell by our track record that we do this very, very cautiously. The nature of our business is such that it has a unique element to it. So doing acquisitions for acquisitions' sake is not trivial for us. So the answer is, we can do it. We know how to do it. At this point, if you look at where we are and what we've done, it's primarily been technology acquisitions as opposed to acquiring other companies that have a totally different business model and modus operandi.

componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Mike, and I will be your conference operator. I would like welcome everyone to the Xilinx First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha.. Thank you, Mr.  Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, our CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then open we'll open the call for questions. This quarter, we changed our revenue by product
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, our CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then open we'll open the call for questions. This quarter, we changed our revenue by product category classification. We make changes to this classification on a regular basis as products mature and new products are introduced. And they've been the product category to be more meaningful to investors. In addition, we consolidated the other end market category into the communications and data center end market. For comparative purposes, we have provided supplemental schedule on our website at www.investor.xilinx.com that presents results based on the previous category classification. 
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website. Let me now turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. The volume sales were $529 million, down 3% sequentially and within our guidance. Profitability remains strong during quarter with a better-than-expected gross margins continued to OpEx control and healthy cash flow generation. New produc
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. The volume sales were $529 million, down 3% sequentially and within our guidance. Profitability remains strong during quarter with a better-than-expected gross margins continued to OpEx control and healthy cash flow generation. New product sales decreased 10% in the quarter, almost entirely driven by 28-nanometer products, which were impacted by week sales awareness customers. Sales from 20-nanometer products exceeded $10 million during the quarter, doubling from the prior quarter. 
From an end market perspective, sales from communications and data center remained weak, decreasing 11% sequentially. The greater-than-forecasted decline was driven by wireless communications, which was weaker-than-anticipated due to continued declines from our broad base of customers, predominately serving the China and U.S. market. Wireless sales were as expected for the quarter, while shipments into the cable assess business were particularly strong, overall CapEx spending remains weak. Wireless communications was the largest end market contributor to 28-nanometer revenues in fiscal Q1. 
The industrial and aerospace and defense segment was better-than-forecasted driven by ISM and AMD. ISM sales were a record during the quarter. Sales from test declined as expected. 
Lastly, broadcast, consumer and automotive was essentially flat as expected. Although flat sequentially, sales from automotive are up nearly 50% from the same quarter a year ago and remain at a record 7% of total sales. Gross margin was 70.9% for the quarter, better than anticipated primarily as a result of product and customer mix, although we continue to be focused on driving improvements in profitability. Operating expenses, including $2 million in amortization were $211 million in line with expectations. Other income was a net expense of $11 million, slightly better-than-forecasted due to a long-term investment gains. Net income for the quarter was $148 million or $0.55 per diluted share. Operating cash flow for the June quarter was $183 million before $8 million in CapEx. Diluted shares for the quarter were $271 million. There was a $9 million share dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions relating to the dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.xilinx.com. 
We repurchased 2.2 million shares for $100 million during the quarter, and made a record $80 million payment in quarterly dividends. We returned nearly 100% of operating cash flow to shareholders during the quarter. 
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments were flat at $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion. Inventory dollars in Xilinx decreased $9 million sequentially. Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the September quarter of fiscal year '16. Our backlog heading into the quarter is down sequentially. Communications is forecasted to be flat. The wireless market continues to be challenging and is negatively impacting our previously-stated full year revenue estimates. While we do expect improvement in the second half of fiscal '16 from increased spending in China, North America and India, the rate of improvement remains difficult to forecast. Wired communications continues to be impacted by a weak CapEx environments, although we expected to continue to benefit throughout the year from revenue growth in new programs where we have displayed ASSPs, in addition to gaining share and traditional BGA sockets. The strength of these programs are in the areas of cable, infrastructure, access and OTN. We expect the industrial and aerospace and defense segment to be down substantially due to a decrease in A&D driven by the expected conclusion of a large program. Xilinx's 28-nanometer parts were recently designed in the subsystems to the next generation program that is expected to begin production in fiscal year '17. Although the aerospace and defense market has been characterized by quarterly volatility, this segment remains an important business for Xilinx. Our 28-nanometer revenues are growing at a rate much faster than previous new product introductions as we expand our presence in areas such as situational awareness, public safety and embedded vision systems. ISM is expected to be approximately flat during the quarter, and test is expected to decline. Lastly, we expect all comp on is broadcast, consumer and automotive category to be flat. We Expect strong growth in automotive and fiscal '16 as Zynq enters volume production at many large OEMs. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be down 2% to 6%, so down 2% to down 6% sequentially. The midpoint of this guidance is predicated on terms where approximately 51%. Gross margin expected approximately 59% to 70%. 
Operating expenses for the September quarter are expected to be approximately $217 million, including $2 million of amortization by acquisition-related intangibles. As I mentioned last quarter, Q1 OpEx would be the low point for the year. The increase in Q2 OpEx will be driven primarily by hiring in the sales force and increased tapeout expense related primarily to the 16-nanometer technology regeneration. Other income and expense for the September quarter will be a net expense of $10 million. The share count is expected to be approximately 268 million shares. The tax rate for September quarter is expected to be approximately 12%. The reset of our tax rate guidance to 12% is due to a change in the jurisdictional mix of earnings. Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. Though the June quarter was challenging from top-line perspective, we continued to be pleased with our focus on delivering sustained type profitability. Gross margin was 70.9%, better than expectations, drivi
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. Though the June quarter was challenging from top-line perspective, we continued to be pleased with our focus on delivering sustained type profitability. Gross margin was 70.9%, better than expectations, driving an operating margin of 32.5%. 28-nanometer decline as we anticipated driven by weakness in wireless communication. However, sales from our Zynq product family to industry first programmable SoCs increased more than 40%. The primary driver for this growth came from applications. Important industry growth driver ideally suited to benefit from the Zynq product families, innovative differentiated capabilities. We expect 28-nanometers sales to return to growth in the September quarter, driven by continued sales increase from the Zynq products, as well as an increase in wired communication. Additionally, we're focused in 28-nanometer revenue to grow for the balance of fiscal year 2016 driven by demand stabilization in communications, the continued strong adoption in automotive, ISM, test and aerospace and defense. We're also executing very well with our 20-nanometer UltraScale portfolio. Technology leadership at this node is very rapidly translation to sales leadership. We have now shipped 20-nanometer parts to more than 140 discrete customers in all of our major end-markets. 20-nanometer revenue in the June quarter is doubled sequentially, more than $10 million significant growth coming from Virtex UltraScale, the industry's only ASIC Class 20-nanometer high-end product offering. 
In the September quarter, we are forecasting 20-nanometer sales to exceed $50 million so experiencing a sales ramp that is more accelerated than our initial expectation. We estimate our share at this node to be approaching 82% [ph]. Confident our share of 20-nanometer will continue to exceed 65% market share, we have delivered at 28-nanometer. The 16-nanometer node, we take out the industry's first, all-programmable multi-processor SoC using TSMC, 16 SSS, FF+ process. This product family targets applications in embedded vision, including industrial Internet of Things and 5 and systems. During the June quarter, we also extended our world-class partnership with TSMC, the undisputed leader in the foundry industry with the announcement that we will leveraging TSMC's 7-nanometer process technology, 3D IC technologies for a next generation of all programmable FPGAs, 3D ICs, and MPSoCs. Technology represents the fourth consecutive generation where the 2 companies are partnered, plans process forward back into technology and will become TSMC's fourth generatean of FinFET technology. We anticipate the first, tapeout of 7-nanometer in calendar 2017. 
Finally, with regard to design software, earlier this week, we announced the public assets release of our SDSoCs development  environment to expand the user base of Zynq SoCs and MPSoCs to a broad community of systems and software engineers both existing and new markets. Despite weak global communication spending environment, I remain very confident in Xilinx's strong technology leadership and market expansion initiatives driven by Zynq, our new software-defined development  environment. We will continue to focus on maintaining high levels of profitability in any business environment with the overall goal of maximizing shareholder return. Let me now turn the call back to the operator for questions-and-answers.

componenttext: Moshe, a bigger picture question for you. Similar to what when asking linear tech. What is your view on what's going on with overall demand being weaker-than-expected, whether by geography, end market or whatever you believe the costs to be? And do you think that is more of a short-term pause or is something more that's a little more longer than duration?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We see the weakness primarily in wireless and it's being choppy and less predictable than we had thought it would be for some time now and as a result, we're very hesitant to call in the visibility will improve there. We do think the question of when, not
componenttext: We see the weakness primarily in wireless and it's being choppy and less predictable than we had thought it would be for some time now and as a result, we're very hesitant to call in the visibility will improve there. We do think the question of when, not a question of if, but has shrunk by significant amount. And if you compare where we were 1 year ago to where we are now. I think it's several lower. That's the major market or vertical where we're seeing issues. All of the other areas, I won't say that they're by to doing great, but they're sort of holding up for us. So that's the Xilinx perspective. Jon, do you concur?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do concur. I would also add to that our share position is, particularly in the wireless segment is still very strong. I think that helps bolster our confidence that when things do come back, we're going to be a strong participant of that. And as I
componenttext: Yes, I do concur. I would also add to that our share position is, particularly in the wireless segment is still very strong. I think that helps bolster our confidence that when things do come back, we're going to be a strong participant of that. And as I said, it's very hard to get exactly what that trajectory of the second half improvement is, and we see signs and positive statements out of from both customers and carriers, but we are living quarter-by-quarter right now in this particular end market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, well, this is part of the announced program where the joint strike -- it was specifically the Joint Strike Fighter where there's a very large set of purchases going on over a period of 1.5 years to 2 years. And this is just the -- essentially the end
componenttext: Oh, well, this is part of the announced program where the joint strike -- it was specifically the Joint Strike Fighter where there's a very large set of purchases going on over a period of 1.5 years to 2 years. And this is just the -- essentially the end of that particular procurement and they are redesigning some of the key elements in electronics inside the aircraft and as I said, we're winning all the redesigns that there's this gap between when the older designs materials being acquired versus the new periods. we're at the end of that particular program and we won't see any significant revenue shipped into the program for the remainder of this year. So I wouldn't associate it holy with any sort of on last time buy situation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then the follow-up is a much broader question. Competitively when you talk to customers, I'd love to hear about sort of positioning the company does relative to your competitor, soon likely to be owned by Intel, whether that changes the dynamic and ho
componenttext: And then the follow-up is a much broader question. Competitively when you talk to customers, I'd love to hear about sort of positioning the company does relative to your competitor, soon likely to be owned by Intel, whether that changes the dynamic and how so both on the relationship side and then the anticipated manufacturing change that might happen at that supplier?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, let me take it. So fundamentally, if you look at the markets we serve is there, i.e., diversified markets that look for their advanced technology and a significant level of support with a very long life cycle. And this is a market we have serv
componenttext: Okay. Well, let me take it. So fundamentally, if you look at the markets we serve is there, i.e., diversified markets that look for their advanced technology and a significant level of support with a very long life cycle. And this is a market we have serviced really well. We continue to service it well. We have delivered market share expansion of 28-nanometer. We're seeing that expand in a better position of 20. We believe we're ahead of the game now being this first, tapeout at the node to beyond that 16. And we are already working with SMC on the 7-nanometer, and we expect the tapeout in the 2017 timeframe. So on the silicon side, the customers are very sure that they will continue to have the same level of excellence in terms of technology leadership and timeliness and that's an opportunity for us. Now when you supplement that with the leadership we have in the softer and expansion within the new products, the SD Xcel and the SDSoC, which we now are broadly are making available to customers. And not only is it the best silicon, but it's the best software in the industry and the best support infrastructure in the industry. So we actually believe that this is an opportunity for us and we'd say that customers are reassured by that, and we know that we are the biggest and have been for the longest period of time, the leader in the bell weather player in this market. So we remain committed to it and together with our unique relationship with TSMC and, they will continue to get the best product around to serve their requirements. So as the market will evolve, and we don't know what will happen on the other side, I think generally speaking, this bodes well for us, and that's why we're in this -- continue to invest heavily to make sure we can exploit this opportunity.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Now that the think it's officially official, I guess, I can stop asking my hypothetical questions and ask some real questions. So are you seeing any reaction from your customers on that? And then Intel talked about a delay in 10 nanometers. I mean, how do you think that positions Altera versus yourselves?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I can add a lot more to what I said before. We're focused on delivering leadership on silicon, on software in terms of support and we are working with the TSMC and with ARM on the next generation of product. And we now have announced th
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I can add a lot more to what I said before. We're focused on delivering leadership on silicon, on software in terms of support and we are working with the TSMC and with ARM on the next generation of product. And we now have announced the 7-nanometer tapeout and TSMC announced that it will be available 2017, and we expect to tapeout to that point in time. So we're focused on execution and on of the uncertainty with regards to the Altera acquisition by Intel, I think that's generally an opportunity for us as long as we continued to execute and deliver. And since we've done that at 28 nanometer and the results speak to themselves, the results of 20 already demonstrate you need better market share for us first, 16 [ph] and working on 7. I think as we continue to execute there's upside for us from all of the uncertainty.

But we are around, we're open for business and we are committed to and continue to be committed to delivering the leadership, both on the technology and the support side.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Business Ryan for Sinai. I get another one for you. It's on with that kind of in the works, I'm curious if you see any need to maybe go out and get access through a partnership or maybe start working in-house, on accustomed arm core just to stay competiti
componenttext: Business Ryan for Sinai. I get another one for you. It's on with that kind of in the works, I'm curious if you see any need to maybe go out and get access through a partnership or maybe start working in-house, on accustomed arm core just to stay competitive in terms of potential integration advantages that Intel may have with Altera over time?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's a great question. And we were first, at 28 with Zynq, we were first at 16 with our MPSoC product, which actually has a very attractive performance level and we believe that for most of the markets that, we're addressing ARM is actually, by far,
componenttext: So that's a great question. And we were first, at 28 with Zynq, we were first at 16 with our MPSoC product, which actually has a very attractive performance level and we believe that for most of the markets that, we're addressing ARM is actually, by far, the best solution. You can say that the 1 potential exception to that is the data center market, but the data center market is likely to bifurcate into Intel in the rest of the world and to the rest of the world, we believe we're going to be the natural and best solution. So there's upside for us there. And we think we can do it with the ARM product roadmap and with the TSMC process and we've already demonstrated that. There's a lot of bluster about the leadership that Intel would deliver to Altera. In fact is we already had with regards to that note. So we believe that we're in good shape, both strategically and tactically and definitely the ARM roadmap will suffice. Now, if you're asking a very specific question, could there be markets where a fully optimized X86 which should provide some advantage. The answer to that is, yes. There are some markets, it tends to be a small subset of the overall market, and we think for most of the market, we will have a very adequate and competitive solution using our existing roadmap.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just want to follow up on the financial model. You had hinted the prepared comments that the wireless issues are kind of challenging your prior target for flat up 2% for the fiscal year. So just curious if there's anything out to ask
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just want to follow up on the financial model. You had hinted the prepared comments that the wireless issues are kind of challenging your prior target for flat up 2% for the fiscal year. So just curious if there's anything out to ask there if you were providing an actual update there? And also on the OpEx side too, I think you had a forecast out there just to be an update on how that tracking?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So at this time, we are going to go quarter by quarter. The wireless as I said in the previous answer as well, well, it's really hard to understand what the pace of the change of the trajectory is on China and in the U.S. Specifically, the Chinese ba
componenttext: Yes. So at this time, we are going to go quarter by quarter. The wireless as I said in the previous answer as well, well, it's really hard to understand what the pace of the change of the trajectory is on China and in the U.S. Specifically, the Chinese base station rollout and more specifically spend for us, which was one of our leading growth sectors in North America. I mean Verizon, AT&T were also involved but Sprint was certainty one of the leading growth factors there. So we are not giving a new number for the full year just because of the challenge of understanding, what that really means us. So meaning, how strong will come back? Will it come back in the second half? All those things, really hard for us to say. So we aren't putting out a new number. Spending, we revised spending, downward in our last call, vis-à-vis what we said at Investor Day, and we are changing that forecast at this time.

componenttext: A bit early at $10 million of revenue per quarter, but can you talk about 20-nanometers perhaps yields execution, volume ramps as it compared to 28-nanometers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Ian. So if you look at 28, it was a very, very, very broad node. You know that there's a low end, the midrange, high-end, there was the Zynq product line, which ended up with the large number of products. From our perspective, the
componenttext: That's a great question, Ian. So if you look at 28, it was a very, very, very broad node. You know that there's a low end, the midrange, high-end, there was the Zynq product line, which ended up with the large number of products. From our perspective, the 20 and 16, together, which are coming out relatively close -- closer than typical, should more or less be equivalent to 28. So 20 is not as big as 28, but neither did we expect to be and 20 is now benefiting from the fact that we have a high-end and midrange there, and that's what is generating this level of revenue. But there's no low end then there's no Zynq equivalent on the 20-nanometer. And hence overall, it's not as a vibrant as the 28 was, but on the other hand, it's doing better than we had expected. So we're quite pleased with the results so far in the pickup in terms of design wins, which are now rapidly turning into revenue is very encouraging from my perspective.

componenttext: Great. And for my follow-up, I mean, how much do you think Xilinx customers are seeing price increases year-to-date, whether it's deliberate value-based pricing or the strong dollar overseas? And what's the response been? I know app that as early as June so there's really no impact to the strong dollar. I just wanted to check in on that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I, certainly, are not seeing much impact to the stronger dollar, of course, there's a pullback a little bit now, but we really haven't. I thought I'd sense the pause in our industrial business in Europe a few quarters back but then it bounced back th
componenttext: Yes. I, certainly, are not seeing much impact to the stronger dollar, of course, there's a pullback a little bit now, but we really haven't. I thought I'd sense the pause in our industrial business in Europe a few quarters back but then it bounced back the next quarter, and it's stable now. I mean it's got growth -- some growth going on there, but -- so we really haven't seen anything. They're overall. So yes, generally I think things are not being impacted on a worldwide basis because of the currency strength for us.

componenttext: Okay. Well, we're very confident because we have design wins, and we have models that are going into production and I think there is already 12, and it could be that the number is slightly higher that are already 12 models that are going into production this point in time with our solution. We don't have the plurality of the market, it's the market which is emerging, but we believe that it's a great starting point for us, and it's helping to drive our business and for everyone who's looking for a differentiated solution as opposed to a cookie-cutter solution, which will give you -- which one give you an advantage, then we are trained to ride with that regard. We think more and more of the customers adult solution, I don't think we're going to have 50% market share this generation, but we are already garnering tremendous number of design wins with the MPSoC for the follow-on for that. So we're very pleased with the market share with our zn product offering, and we expect that to expand what the MPSoC, the market, which is it in its infancy and I think that it's still too early to assume that there is only going to be 1 winner. We expect to be a significant winner in this market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, I know back to the 16-nanometer tapeout, I know there's press release recently about taping out a program a little multiprocessors 16-nanometer chip. What else or what else are you close to taping out on 16-nanomet
componenttext: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, I know back to the 16-nanometer tapeout, I know there's press release recently about taping out a program a little multiprocessors 16-nanometer chip. What else or what else are you close to taping out on 16-nanometer and how should we think about the progression of products at that node? Will be high-end first and midrange, and then well, or how should we think about that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the 16-nanometer offering is quite broad, and it has a midrange, high-end and a very extensive processor roadmap. So that's the MPSoC. So it covers probably 80% -- or 70% to 80% of the total area that we tend to play in. It doesn't cover the very lo
componenttext: Well, the 16-nanometer offering is quite broad, and it has a midrange, high-end and a very extensive processor roadmap. So that's the MPSoC. So it covers probably 80% -- or 70% to 80% of the total area that we tend to play in. It doesn't cover the very low end. We will be -- we feel we have good coverage with the 28 and 45-nanometers solution at the low end. And we will be bolstering that low-end portfolio in the future with a new generation of technology. But that's what this is being the initial product is a relatively high-end product with an embedded processor, but it's not ultimate high-end. It's sort of just on the theme between the midrange and high-end of the product offering, and we're going to continue to expand going up and down and the first versions that has embedded CPU core, and that will be the first one that will come out will have. It's targeted to have the embedded CPU core and that has a tremendous level of interest in the market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And they'll be additional tapeout as we move into the year. And it is just the first tapeout as we've wound down our 20-nanometer tapeout of focus and getting all those are the market in 16 comes right behind it and they'll continue to have tapeout throug
componenttext: And they'll be additional tapeout as we move into the year. And it is just the first tapeout as we've wound down our 20-nanometer tapeout of focus and getting all those are the market in 16 comes right behind it and they'll continue to have tapeout throughout the remainder of this year and into the following fiscal year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, Patel for Ambrish. I have a question earlier you mentioned that you plan to introduce 7-nanometer product in 2017. It implies that your gap between tapeout for 15 and 7. Are you skipping 10-nanometer and is there any reason why you're skipping 10-nano
componenttext: Hi, Patel for Ambrish. I have a question earlier you mentioned that you plan to introduce 7-nanometer product in 2017. It implies that your gap between tapeout for 15 and 7. Are you skipping 10-nanometer and is there any reason why you're skipping 10-nanometer?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if you look at the sequence, there's 28, and then 20 and 16 came out in rapid succession. And those actually 2 flavors of 16, those 16 FF and the 16. So we after we did the 20, we decided to skip the 16 FF and go straight to the FF plus with the
componenttext: Okay. So if you look at the sequence, there's 28, and then 20 and 16 came out in rapid succession. And those actually 2 flavors of 16, those 16 FF and the 16. So we after we did the 20, we decided to skip the 16 FF and go straight to the FF plus with the gap between 7 and 10 at TSMC is actually is quite significant in terms of the capabilities of the 2 products. And from our perspective, our customers can only digest technology at a certain cadence. If we bring out technology every 3 months, that's not going to help them. So to some extent, somewhere between every 2 to 3 years to have a major technology refresh for the businesses we're in is the right cadence and what we decided to do is to shoot for the best technology, which will be available in that sort of timeframe and the 7-nanometer fit the bill and and it's all denser and actually high-performance, we felt it was better to do that than to split between the 10 and the 7. So that's sort of the of thinking and we're quite confident that this is the acquisition in terms of our customer requirements.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just want to dig into the wireless weakness. So been adding a lot of pool fibers. So was the real reason for the weakness is the excess inventory? Or you think customers are using more ASIC and a system than before? And what do you think will done as
componenttext: So I just want to dig into the wireless weakness. So been adding a lot of pool fibers. So was the real reason for the weakness is the excess inventory? Or you think customers are using more ASIC and a system than before? And what do you think will done as our own thing in the long?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answers are different by geography to that question. It really isn't the same trends. China, in general, has been stalled out, both because the SD standard deployment, which is one of the bigger things that we were counting on for this year to a
componenttext: Well, the answers are different by geography to that question. It really isn't the same trends. China, in general, has been stalled out, both because the SD standard deployment, which is one of the bigger things that we were counting on for this year to actually begin and be more robust as we move through the year. That was sold out originally by China Unicom and China Telecoms. The audits that they had relative to ethics and those kind of things that went on. There's been an overall slowdown of capital spend in China on infrastructure, which is more of a macro thing going on relative to the China issue. So I think that's been the biggest driver there. And there absolutely has been a buildup of basestation inventory and our product in the Chinese suppliers that is being led off as China Mobile continue to deploy in a much lower rate than the previous year but China Telecom and not as much. So if you -- people have told me that if you're in China, and you're using one of those the handset from the China Mobile Network, it's still a lot of coverage issues and a lot lots of things to bid on there's I'm not sure, sure it's driven by the subscriber pull. I think there's some the bigger issue is going on there. Relative to North America, it's kind of bifurcated into Sprint who is also having some financial issues in terms of funding other network so they slowed down the deployment of their network and they've gone through a rebidding process and the process is being completed as best as we can tell, and so again, we think that because of those milestones, we think things are going to start to turn around and grow for us in the second half of this year and into calendar 2016. AT&T and Verizon has a slowed down their cap spending in the first part of the year. There were Spectrum acquisitions. They also are starting to spend a little more money and there's going to be additional capacity of that network. So it's really is different by different carriers and geographies. The thought process about what's going to turn this around for us is just exactly the fact that subscriber and coverage is not uniformly sufficient and good in those geographies. And as much as we said earlier, it's a matter of when, it's not a matter of if for us. And again, we've seen positive the press coming out of carriers relative to some improvement in that. We've seen orders with respect to India, some growth there, we, so we have specific orders ahead of us on that. So we are starting to see some positive signs that would lead us to believe that the second half of fiscal year will be better.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I have one follow-up. So on the data center side, the accelerator opportunity, which the main reason why Intel acquired Altera. Can you talk about how big the market is for you? Is it still an area of focus and is Intel acquiring Altera promote opt
componenttext: Great. I have one follow-up. So on the data center side, the accelerator opportunity, which the main reason why Intel acquired Altera. Can you talk about how big the market is for you? Is it still an area of focus and is Intel acquiring Altera promote optimize product to the market? Can you just give us some color around the data center opportunity?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the various elements to the data center and there's element of focus on storage, elements of focus on networking and elements of focus on compute. So the storage and networking are largely impacted by this acquisition. The compute space, it's ver
componenttext: Okay. So the various elements to the data center and there's element of focus on storage, elements of focus on networking and elements of focus on compute. So the storage and networking are largely impacted by this acquisition. The compute space, it's very clear that FPGAs provide a viable, very attractive lower power solution, which significantly provides an improvement in the performance per watt what we are seeing is somewhere between 22 to 30X on -- in several applications vis-à-vis standalone, high-performance processor. And that's because these applications in the cloud tend to be massively parallel and these processors are inherently not parallel engines. They're very sequential, that's the way a CPU operates. And even if you have multiple CPU calls, you can only achieve a certain level of parallelism that they. So FPGA is actually kind of provide tremendous acceleration at the same platform or level of power consumption, just to make sure, or they can provide at a much lower level of power consumption, they cna deliver equivalent performance. Now we believe that when Intel consummates its acquisition, when that happens, then there will be some integration opportunities. The challenge there is that you're taking a very high power solution, which is an X86, and you're adding to it another high-power solution, which is a larger FPGA and to some extent if you try to integrate both of those in the silicon, you're limited with regards to what you can do. So we believe that, that market, the Intel as 86 will have an element, which will have an integrated solution and there will have an element which has these distributed solutions where the FPGA will be separate. We see a lot of the traditional data center customers having a strong interest in actually retaining autonomy and independence in that second mode. So they can decide how they designed their system and obviously would be a wonderful solution for them. So even in the Intel x86 a space we believe we have to play. Not to mention that everywhere where it's not Intel, and this is a market, which is emerging, so there's a lot of competing solutions, it will come to the market over the next few years. We will be the natural shoe in for that. So those solutions. So I would say there's upside for us definitely vis-a-vis beyond where we are today and we're committed to that market, and we expect to see business growth in that market. And we believe that, that market is in its very early stages of evolution and over time, we will have the stronger position in it than we definitely have now. So hopefully that answered your question. I apologize if it was more [indiscernible]. Next question.

componenttext: Just a quick follow-up to the data center question-and-answer that you just provided, which was very useful, how competitive do you said you are relative to Altera now with software which I believe was the reason for the delay initially in you getting in that end market?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, to be totally honest, we were not -- we did not recognize that market early. Hence, on the software side, we did have a product efficiency now based on what customers are telling us, not only are we not behind, but we're actually ahead of the competi
componenttext: Yes, to be totally honest, we were not -- we did not recognize that market early. Hence, on the software side, we did have a product efficiency now based on what customers are telling us, not only are we not behind, but we're actually ahead of the competition. So I think we've largely closed that gap and if anything, it is a competitive advantage for us. We believe that the very deep synthesis technology that we have now delivered as part of our product, that gives us a tremendous advantage over any other solution in the market today. As we've product-sized it, and we're now starting to broadly deliver it to customers, the feedback we're getting is that we are ahead in terms of technology. So the software is no longer the issue, if anything, it's working in our favor.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gabriella, it is certainly a challenge in any market where we have a very high concentration and there has -- in this particular situation, it seems to be more of a worldwide trend that's going on. And if you look at other sub-contractor companies that ha
componenttext: Gabriella, it is certainly a challenge in any market where we have a very high concentration and there has -- in this particular situation, it seems to be more of a worldwide trend that's going on. And if you look at other sub-contractor companies that has the same challenges as we do in this area. I don't think because we have such a diversified portfolio beyond just wireless and overall communication, I don't think that's going to cause us to change our desire to do a forecast, to do the best we possibly can. I think we're at a point here of certainly a multi-year historical low for us in terms of our revenue and in this segment and it is challenging. But I think we'll continue to try to push through and figure this out. Now, relative to the terms percentage number that I provided while it was quite a bit higher on a percentage basis, then our actual turns from the previous quarter, I think we've been relatively conservative on the wireless forecast that supports that. We had quite a bit of business booked early in the quarter, the previous quarter, and then moving into this current quarter that we just started, we're back to a more normal booking pattern and the actual dollars we need in terms on a weekly basis is not that much greater than the actual dollars per week we had in the previous quarter. So I think we're pretty well-balanced and to see how things go throughout the quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the color and maybe just a follow-up if I could on the gross margin profile of the business. Maybe if we think about the year-over-year how the gross margin profile of the company has changed, how was understand how much of that is mix sh
componenttext: I appreciate all the color and maybe just a follow-up if I could on the gross margin profile of the business. Maybe if we think about the year-over-year how the gross margin profile of the company has changed, how was understand how much of that is mix shift even between end-markets our between different product groups? And how much of it is structural initiatives that the company has been taken to improve the longer-term gross margin profile.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So at our Investor Day, we talked about it, a 68% to 70% range for this year. So if you look at the midpoint, that would be 69%. And we've been running at 70% and 71%. So all the cost reductions that we have -- that we had in that forecasted at Investor D
componenttext: So at our Investor Day, we talked about it, a 68% to 70% range for this year. So if you look at the midpoint, that would be 69%. And we've been running at 70% and 71%. So all the cost reductions that we have -- that we had in that forecasted at Investor Day that drove the 68% to 70% are on track and we're doing very well. So I would say if I compare it to our previous forecast, we are on track on all the cost reductions. There is a lot of mix issues going on. We do have a slightly stronger industrial, aerospace and defense profile than we thought at that point in time, and we had a substantially weaker communications business. And that mix would tend to push our gross margins to this very high elevated point that we are right now. So I think both product and customer mix is accounted for quite a bit. As is, I think in the absence a more normal -- normalized end market mix that we would've envisioned at the Investor Day, we'll be running in the 68% to 70%, probably pretty close to the center of that. So I guess the short answer to your question is, a lot of it is mix in and end market customer mix.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I'm looking at the roadmaps here. It turns out that my reckoning, in 2018, you guys are going to be ramping or very early ramping 7-nanometer, and if Altera chooses or if Intel chooses to be the provider of foundry services for Altera, there'll be
componenttext: Moshe, I'm looking at the roadmaps here. It turns out that my reckoning, in 2018, you guys are going to be ramping or very early ramping 7-nanometer, and if Altera chooses or if Intel chooses to be the provider of foundry services for Altera, there'll be a 10. Was there a competitive reason behind your decision to skip 10-nanometer besides that the cadence aspect of your customer's preference?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not really. That's a great question. We just looked at what the right solution and everything which was available to us and what would be the right solution and had their 10, and then we said, well, is there anything beyond that and they told of that they
componenttext: Not really. That's a great question. We just looked at what the right solution and everything which was available to us and what would be the right solution and had their 10, and then we said, well, is there anything beyond that and they told of that they were working on this future technology. TSMC is very committed driving technology and capacity leadership and when we saw what it is, we felt that we would be no compelling and we're just based on that. Now indirectly, we have no idea what Altera and Intel were going to do and Altera had said that they were looking at TSMC's road map and I would be surprised if TSMC did not show them the same things to to be honest, right? Probably would just make sense where TSMC to show if they have. So it wasn't -- we didn't know what was available at Intel, but we just decided that the right thing for our customer base was to go to the 7-nanometer, and that looks like a very compelling solution in particular as they are committed to delivering it in 2017, and that's when we need it.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It comes from a variety of sources, some of which are internal to us, some of which come from the customers provide and in some cases, it's a third-party, which provides them. So it's combination of both 3 -- just to sort of comment on that, what we're se
componenttext: It comes from a variety of sources, some of which are internal to us, some of which come from the customers provide and in some cases, it's a third-party, which provides them. So it's combination of both 3 -- just to sort of comment on that, what we're seeing and I said this in response to an early question, we're seeing customers look at a canned, non-differentiated ASSPs option versus a highly differentiated solution using our devices. And for the high-end, it's a no-brainer that they want the differentiated solution. And then as you look at the midrange, it's less clear and definitely the low end times, they just prepared to have their meat and potato solution as opposed to something which is more specialized. But interestingly, because this has become a platform play, then we're starting to see design wins where the customers are committing their entire product offering to our platform and as a result, they're pushing us hard to provide them with a lower end, and we typically would have provided or solution for that. And so that's a growth opportunity for us, and it's driven by this broad platform approach where the companies are set of saying we can't afford to have different solutions and because we want to have differentiation, they go with us across the board. And that's another reason that I believe that I are market share, which we're happy with the revenue at this point but is not high yet we believe that there's an opportunity to grow it going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Mike, and I will be your conference operator. I would like welcome everyone to the Xilinx First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Mu
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Mike, and I will be your conference operator. I would like welcome everyone to the Xilinx First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Rick Muscha.Thank you, Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. This quarter, we changed our revenue by product categor
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. 
This quarter, we changed our revenue by product category classification. We make changes to this classification on a regular basis as products mature and new products are introduced. And they have been the product categories to be more meaningful to investors. In addition, we consolidated the other end market category into the communications and data center end market. For comparative purposes, we have provided supplemental schedule on our website at www.investor.xilinx.com that presents results based on the previous category classification. 
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. 
We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website. 
Let me now turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. The volume sales were $549 million, down 3% sequentially and within our guidance. Profitability remained strong during the quarter with a better-than-expected gross margin, continued OpEx control and healthy cash flow generation.  New pro
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. The volume sales were $549 million, down 3% sequentially and within our guidance. Profitability remained strong during the quarter with a better-than-expected gross margin, continued OpEx control and healthy cash flow generation.  New product sales decreased 10% in the quarter, almost entirely driven by 28-nanometer products which were impacted by weak sales to wireless customers. Sales from 20-nanometer products exceeded $10 million during the quarter, doubling from the prior quarter. 
From an end market perspective, sales from communication and data center remained weak, decreasing 11% sequentially. The greater-than-forecasted decline was driven by wireless communications, which was weaker than anticipated due to continued decline from our broad base of customers predominantly serving the China and U.S. markets. Wired sales were as expected for the quarter. While shipments into the cable access business were particularly strong, overall CapEx spending remains weak. Wired communications was the largest end market contributor to 28-nanometer revenues in fiscal Q1. The industrial and aerospace and defense segment was better than forecasted, driven by ISM and A&D. ISM sales were a record during the quarter. Sales from test declined as expected. 
Lastly, broadcast, consumer and automotive was essentially flat as expected. Although flat sequentially, sales from automotive are up nearly 50% from the same quarter a year ago and remain at a record 7% of total sales. Gross margin was 70.9% for the quarter, better than anticipated, primarily as a result of product and customer mix, although we continued to be focused on driving improvements in profitability. 
Operating expenses, including $2 million in amortization, were $211 million, in line with expectations. 
Other income was a net expense of $11 million, slightly better than forecasted due to a long-term investment gains. 
Net income for the quarter was $148 million or $0.55 per diluted share. 
Operating cash flow for the June quarter was $183 million before $8 million in CapEx. 
Diluted shares for the quarter were $271 million. There was a $9 million share dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions relating to the dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.xilinx.com. 
We repurchased 2.2 million shares for $100 million during the quarter and made a record $80 million payment in quarterly dividends. We returned nearly 100% of operating cash flow to shareholders during the quarter. 
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments were flat at $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt, resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion. Inventory dollars at Xilinx decreased $9 million sequentially. 
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the September quarter of fiscal year '16. Our backlog heading into the quarter is down sequentially. Communications is forecasted to be flat. The wireless market continues to be challenging and is negatively impacting our previously stated full year revenue estimates. While we do expect improvement in the second half of fiscal '16 from increased spending in China, North America and India, the rate of improvement remains difficult to forecast. Wired communications continues to be impacted by a weak CapEx environment, although we expect to continue to benefit throughout the year from revenue growth in new programs where we have displayed the ASSPs in addition to gaining share in traditional and BGA sockets. The strength of these programs are in the areas of cable infrastructure, access and OTN. We expect the industrial and aerospace and defense segment to be down substantially due to a decrease in A&D, driven by the expected conclusion of a large program. 
Xilinx's 28-nanometer parts were recently designed into subsystems of the next-generation program that is expected to begin production in fiscal year '17. Although the aerospace and defense market has been characterized by quarterly volatility, this segment remains an important business for Xilinx. Our 28-nanometer revenues are growing at a rate much faster than previous new product introductions as we expand our presence in areas, such as situational awareness, public safety and embedded vision systems. ISM is expected to be approximately flat during the quarter, and test is expected to decline. 
Lastly, we expect all components of the broadcast, consumer and automotive category to be approximately flat. We expect strong growth in automotive in fiscal '16 as Zynq enters volume production at many large OEMs. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be down 2% to 6% -- so down 2% to down 6% sequentially. The midpoint of this guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 51%. 
Gross margin is expected to be approximately 69% to 70%. Operating expenses for the September quarter are expected to be approximately $217 million, including $2 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. 
As I mentioned last quarter, Q1 OpEx would be the low point for the year. The increase in Q2 OpEx will be driven primarily by hiring in the sales force and increased tapeout expense related primarily to the 16-nanometer technology generation. 
Other income and expense for the September quarter will be a net expense of $10 million. 
The share count is expected to be approximately 268 million shares. 
The tax rate for September quarter is expected to be approximately 12%. The reset of our tax rate guidance to 12% is due to a change in the jurisdictional mix of earnings. 
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. Though the June quarter was challenging from top line perspective, I continued to be pleased with our focus on delivering sustained type profitability. Gross margin was 70.9%, better than expectations, drivin
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. Though the June quarter was challenging from top line perspective, I continued to be pleased with our focus on delivering sustained type profitability. Gross margin was 70.9%, better than expectations, driving an operating margin of 32.5%. 28-nanometer decline, as we anticipated, driven by weakness in wireless communications. However, sales from our Zynq product family, the industries first all-programmable SoCs, increased more than 40%. The primary driver for this growth came from ADAS applications, important industry growth driver ideally suited to benefit from the Zynq product families, innovative and differentiated capabilities. We expect 28-nanometer sales to return to growth in the September quarter, driven by continued sales increase from the Zynq products, as well as an increase in wired communications. Additionally, we're forecasting 28-nanometer revenue to grow for the balance of fiscal year 2016, driven by demand stabilization in communications and continued strong adoption in automotive, ISM, test and aerospace and defense. We're also executing very well with our 20-nanometer UltraScale portfolio. Technology leadership at this node is very rapidly translating to sales leadership. We have now shipped 20-nanometer parts to more than 140 discrete customers in all of our major end markets. 20-nanometer revenue in the June quarter doubled sequentially to more than $10 million with significant growth coming from Virtex UltraScale, the industry's only ASIC class, 20-nanometer high-end product offering. 
In the September quarter, we are forecasting 20-nanometer sales to exceed $50 million, so experiencing a sales ramp that is more accelerated than our initial expectation. We estimate our share of this node to be approaching 82%, confident our share of 20-nanometer will continue to exceed 65% market share we have delivered at 28-nanometer. 
The 16-nanometer node, we taped out the industry's first All Programmable Multi-Processor SoC using TSMC's 16FF+ process. This product family targets applications in embedded vision, including ADAS, Industrial Internet of Things and 5G wireless systems. 
During the June quarter, we also extended our world-class partnership with TSMC, the undisputed leader in the foundry industry with the announcement that we will be leveraging TSMC's 7-nanometer process technology, 3D IC technology for our next generation of All Programmable FPGAs, 3D ICs and MPSoCs. The technology represents the fourth consecutive generation where the 2 companies are partnered, advanced process and CoWoS stacking technology and will become TSMC's fourth generation of FinFET technology. We anticipate the first tapeout of 7-nanometer in calendar 2017. 
Finally, with regard to design software, earlier this week, we announced the public access release of our SDSoC development  environment to expand the user base of Zynq SoCs and MPSoCs to a broad community of systems and software engineers, both existing in new markets. 
Despite weak global communication spending environment, I remain very confident in Xilinx's strong technology leadership and market expansion initiatives driven by Zynq, our new SDx software-designed development environment. We will continue to focus on maintaining high levels of profitability in any business environment with the overall goal of maximizing shareholder return [ph]. 
Let me now turn the call back to the operator for questions and answers.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
