componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, a bigger-picture question for you. Similar to what we've been asking Linear Tech. What is your view on what's going on with overall demand being weaker than expected, whether by geography, end market or whatever you believe the costs to be? And do
componenttext: Moshe, a bigger-picture question for you. Similar to what we've been asking Linear Tech. What is your view on what's going on with overall demand being weaker than expected, whether by geography, end market or whatever you believe the costs to be? And do you think that is more of a short-term pause or is something that's a little more longer in duration?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We see the weakness primarily in wireless, and it's being choppy and less predictable than we had thought it would be for some time now. And as a result, we're very hesitant to call in the visibility will improve there. We do think it's a question of when
componenttext: We see the weakness primarily in wireless, and it's being choppy and less predictable than we had thought it would be for some time now. And as a result, we're very hesitant to call in the visibility will improve there. We do think it's a question of when, not a question of if, but it has shrunk by significant amounts. And if you compare where we were a year ago to where we are now, I think it's several [indiscernible] percent lower. So that's the major market or vertical where we're seeing issues. All of the other areas, I won't say that they're buoyant and vibrant or doing great, but they're sort of holding up for us. So that's the Xilinx perspective. Jon, do you concur?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do concur. I would also add to that, that our share position is, and particularly in the wireless segment, is still very strong. And I think that helps bolster the -- our confidence that when these things do come back, we're going to be a strong pa
componenttext: Yes, I do concur. I would also add to that, that our share position is, and particularly in the wireless segment, is still very strong. And I think that helps bolster the -- our confidence that when these things do come back, we're going to be a strong participant of that. And as I've said, it's very hard to get exactly what the trajectory of the second half improvement is, and then we see signs and positive statements out of -- from both customers and carriers, but we are living quarter-by-quarter right now in this particular end market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from William Stein with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: The next question is from William Stein with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The negative outlook in the industrial end market where you're citing ending of a program in aerospace and defense, was there a sort of last-time buy that was associated with that, that was going on recently? And then I have a follow-up, please.
componenttext: The negative outlook in the industrial end market where you're citing ending of a program in aerospace and defense, was there a sort of last-time buy that was associated with that, that was going on recently? And then I have a follow-up, please.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, well, this is part of the announced program where the joint strike -- it was specifically the Joint Strike Fighter, where there is a very large set of purchases going on over a period of 1.5 years to 2 years. And this is just the -- essentially the en
componenttext: Oh, well, this is part of the announced program where the joint strike -- it was specifically the Joint Strike Fighter, where there is a very large set of purchases going on over a period of 1.5 years to 2 years. And this is just the -- essentially the end of that particular procurement. And they are redesigning some of the key elements in electronics inside the aircraft. And as I've said, we're winning all the redesigns, it's just that there's this gap between when the older designs materials being acquired versus the new periods. So we're at the end of that particular program, and we won't see any significant revenue shipped into that program for the remainder of this year. So I wouldn't associate it holy with any sort of a last-time buy situation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then the follow-up is a much broader question. Competitively, when you talk to customers, I'd love to hear about the sort of positioning the company does relative to your competitor, soon likely to be owned by Intel, whether that changes the dynamic,
componenttext: And then the follow-up is a much broader question. Competitively, when you talk to customers, I'd love to hear about the sort of positioning the company does relative to your competitor, soon likely to be owned by Intel, whether that changes the dynamic, and how so, both on the relationship side and then the anticipated manufacturing change that might happen at that supplier.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, let me take it. So fundamentally, if you look at the markets we serve is there, i.e., diversified markets that look for very advanced technology and a significant level of support with a very long life cycle. And this is a market we have servi
componenttext: Okay. Well, let me take it. So fundamentally, if you look at the markets we serve is there, i.e., diversified markets that look for very advanced technology and a significant level of support with a very long life cycle. And this is a market we have serviced really well. We continue to service it well. We have delivered market share expansion of 28-nanometer. We're seeing that expand to a better position of 20. We believe we're ahead of the game now, being the first to tapeout at the node beyond that 16. And we are already working with TSMC on the 7-nanometer, and we expect to tapeout in the 2017 time frame. So on the silicon side, the customers are very assured that they will continue to have the same level of excellence in terms of technology, leadership and timeliness, and that's an opportunity for us. Now when you supplement that with the leadership we have in the software and the expansion with the new products, the FD Xcell and the SDSoC, which we now are broadly making available to customers. And not only is it the best silicon, but it's the best software in the industry and the best support infrastructure in the industry. So we actually believe that this is an opportunity for us, and we'd say that customers are reassured by that, and we know that we are the biggest and have been for the longest period of time the leader and the bellwether player in this market. So we remain committed to it. And together with our unique relationship with TSMC and ARM now, they will continue to get the best product around to serve their requirements. So as the market will evolve and we don't know what will happen on the other side, I think generally speaking, this bodes well for us. And that's why we're invest -- continue to invest heavily to make sure we can exploit this opportunity.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Chris Danely with Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Chris Danely with Citi.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Now that the Altera, Intel thing is officially official, I guess I can stop asking my hypothetical questions and ask some real questions. So are you seeing any reaction from your customers on that? And then Intel talked about a delay in 10 nanometers. I m
componenttext: Now that the Altera, Intel thing is officially official, I guess I can stop asking my hypothetical questions and ask some real questions. So are you seeing any reaction from your customers on that? And then Intel talked about a delay in 10 nanometers. I mean, how do you think that positions Altera versus yourselves?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I can add a lot more to what I said before. We're focused on delivering leadership on silicon, on software, in terms of support. And we are working with TSMC and with ARM on the next generation of product, and we now have announced the
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I can add a lot more to what I said before. We're focused on delivering leadership on silicon, on software, in terms of support. And we are working with TSMC and with ARM on the next generation of product, and we now have announced the 7-nanometer tapeout. And TSMC announced it will be available 2017, and we expect to tapeout at that point in time. So we're focused on execution and all of the uncertainty with regards to the Altera acquisition by Intel. I think that's generally an opportunity for us as long as we continue to execute and deliver. And since we've done that at 28 and the results speak to themselves, the results of 20 already demonstrate you need a better market share for 16, and we're working on 7. I think as we continue to execute, there is upside for us from all of the uncertainty.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has there been any reaction from the customers?
componenttext: Has there been any reaction from the customers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: They -- customers are generally happy that they have a -- the bellwether and the largest company in the business continue to focus on this mode of business, right? And I think it's a wait and see for them with regards to see what will happen on the other
componenttext: They -- customers are generally happy that they have a -- the bellwether and the largest company in the business continue to focus on this mode of business, right? And I think it's a wait and see for them with regards to see what will happen on the other side, right? But we are around. We're open for business, and we are committed and continuing to be committed to delivering the leadership, both on the technology and the support side.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Srini Pajjuri with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question is from Srini Pajjuri with CLSA.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Goodman for Srini. I got another one for you on Intel and Altera. So now with that kind of in the works, I'm curious if you see any need to maybe go out and get access through a partnership or maybe start working in-house on a custom ARM core
componenttext: This is Ryan Goodman for Srini. I got another one for you on Intel and Altera. So now with that kind of in the works, I'm curious if you see any need to maybe go out and get access through a partnership or maybe start working in-house on a custom ARM core just to stay competitive in terms of potential integration advantages that Intel may have with Altera over time?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's a great question. And we were first at 28 with Zynq. We were first at 16 with our MPSoC product, which actually has a very attractive performance level. And we believe that for most of the markets that we're addressing, ARM is actually, by far,
componenttext: So that's a great question. And we were first at 28 with Zynq. We were first at 16 with our MPSoC product, which actually has a very attractive performance level. And we believe that for most of the markets that we're addressing, ARM is actually, by far, the best solution. You could say that the one potential exception to that is the data center market, but the data center market is likely to bifurcate into Intel and the rest of the world. And for the rest of the world, we believe we're going to be the natural and best solution. So there's upside for us there. And we think we can do it with the ARM product roadmap and with the TSMC process, and we've already demonstrated that. There's a lot of bluster about the leadership that Intel would deliver to Altera. The fact is we already had with regards to that note. So we believe that we're in good shape, both strategically and tactically, and definitely the ARM roadmap will suffice. Now if you're asking a very specific question, could there be markets where a fully optimized x86 should provide some advantage, the answer to that is yes. There are some markets. It tends to be a small subset of the overall market. And we think that for most of the market, we will have a very adequate and competitive solution using our existing roadmap.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just want to follow up on the financial model. You had hinted in the prepared comments that the wireless issues are kind of challenging your prior target for flat, up 2% for the fiscal year. So just curious if there's anything else t
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just want to follow up on the financial model. You had hinted in the prepared comments that the wireless issues are kind of challenging your prior target for flat, up 2% for the fiscal year. So just curious if there's anything else to add there, if you were providing an actual update there? And also on the OpEx side, too, I think you had a forecast out there, just maybe an update on how that's tracking.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So at this time, we are going to go quarter by quarter. The wireless, as I've said in the previous answer as well, the -- it's really hard to understand what the pace of the change of the trajectory is on China and the U.S., specifically the Chinese
componenttext: Yes. So at this time, we are going to go quarter by quarter. The wireless, as I've said in the previous answer as well, the -- it's really hard to understand what the pace of the change of the trajectory is on China and the U.S., specifically the Chinese base station rollout and more specifically Sprint for us, which was one of our leading growth sectors in North America. I mean, Verizon and AT&T were also involved, but Sprint was certainly one of the leading growth sectors there. So we are not giving a new number for the full year just because of the challenge of understanding what that really means to us. So meaning, how strong will it come back? Will it come back in the second half? All those things, really hard for us to say. So we aren't putting out a new number. Spending, we revised spending, downward in our last call, vis-à-vis what we said at Investor Day, and we aren't changing that forecast this time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ian Ing with MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question is from Ian Ing with MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A bit early at $10 million of revenue per quarter, but can you talk about 20-nanometers, perhaps yields, execution, volume ramps as it compares to 28-nanometers?
componenttext: A bit early at $10 million of revenue per quarter, but can you talk about 20-nanometers, perhaps yields, execution, volume ramps as it compares to 28-nanometers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Ian. So if you look at 28, it was a very, very, very broad node, and there is a low end, the midrange, high end. There was the Zynq product line, which ended up with the large number of products. From our perspective, the 20 and 1
componenttext: That's a great question, Ian. So if you look at 28, it was a very, very, very broad node, and there is a low end, the midrange, high end. There was the Zynq product line, which ended up with the large number of products. From our perspective, the 20 and 16 together, which are coming out relatively close, closer than typical should more or less be equivalent to 28. So 20 is not as big as 28, but neither did we expect it to be. And 20 is now benefiting from the fact that we have a high end and a midrange there. And that's what is generating this level of revenue. But there's no low end, then there's no Zynq equivalent on the 20-nanometer. And hence, overall, it's not as vibrant as the 28 was, but on the other hand, it's doing better than we had expected. So we're quite pleased with the results so far. And the pickup in terms of design wins, which are now rapidly turning into revenue, is very encouraging from my perspective.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And for my follow-up, I mean, how much do you think Xilinx customers are seeing price increases year-to-date, whether it's deliberate value-based pricing or the strong dollar overseas? And what's the response been? I know Avnet, as early as early J
componenttext: Great. And for my follow-up, I mean, how much do you think Xilinx customers are seeing price increases year-to-date, whether it's deliberate value-based pricing or the strong dollar overseas? And what's the response been? I know Avnet, as early as early June, said there's really no impact to the strong dollar. I just wanted to check in on that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I certainly am not seeing much impact to the stronger dollar. Of course, it's pulled back a little bit now. But we really haven't. We -- I thought I sensed a pause in our industrial business in Europe a few quarters back, but then it bounced back the
componenttext: Yes. I certainly am not seeing much impact to the stronger dollar. Of course, it's pulled back a little bit now. But we really haven't. We -- I thought I sensed a pause in our industrial business in Europe a few quarters back, but then it bounced back the next quarter, and it's stable now. I mean, it's got growth -- some growth going on there. But -- so we really haven't seen anything there overall. So yes, generally I think things are not being impacted on a worldwide basis because of the currency strength for us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Christopher Rolland with FBR Capital Markets and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Christopher Rolland with FBR Capital Markets and Company.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Joe on for Chris. So you've recently been promoting Zynq for ADAS and embedded vision. But there's one clear winner, and embedded vision appears they are using the ASIC approach. So what gives you confidence there that there will be a gravitation tow
componenttext: It's Joe on for Chris. So you've recently been promoting Zynq for ADAS and embedded vision. But there's one clear winner, and embedded vision appears they are using the ASIC approach. So what gives you confidence there that there will be a gravitation toward FPGAs? And who are your early design wins there?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, we're very confident because we have design wins, and we have models that are going into production. And I think there is already 12, and it could be that the number is slightly higher. There are already 12 models that are going into productio
componenttext: Okay. Well, we're very confident because we have design wins, and we have models that are going into production. And I think there is already 12, and it could be that the number is slightly higher. There are already 12 models that are going into production at this point in time with our solution. We don't have the plurality of the market. It's a market which is emerging, but we believe that it's a great starting point for us, and it's helping to drive our business and for everyone who's looking for a differentiated solution as opposed to a cookie-cutter solution, which will give you -- which won't give you an advantage, then we are trained to ride with that regard. And we've seen more and more of the customers adopt a solution. I don't think we're going to have 50% market share this generation, but we are already garnering a tremendous number of design wins with the MPSoC for the follow-on for that. So we're very pleased with the market share with our Zynq product offering, and we expect that to expand with the MPSoCs, the market which is in its infancy. And I think that it's still too early to assume that there is only going to be one winner. We expect to be a significant winner in this market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, I know -- back to the 16-nanometer tapeout, I know there is a press release recently about taping out a program, a little multiprocessor, 16-nanometer chip. What else or what else are you close to taping out on 16-
componenttext: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, I know -- back to the 16-nanometer tapeout, I know there is a press release recently about taping out a program, a little multiprocessor, 16-nanometer chip. What else or what else are you close to taping out on 16-nanometer? And how should we think about the progression of products at that node? Will it be high end first then midrange then low? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the 16-nanometer offering is quite broad. And it has a midrange, a high end and a very extensive processor roadmap. So that's the MPSoC. So it covers probably 80% or 70% to 80% of the total area that we tend to play in. It doesn't cover the very low
componenttext: Well, the 16-nanometer offering is quite broad. And it has a midrange, a high end and a very extensive processor roadmap. So that's the MPSoC. So it covers probably 80% or 70% to 80% of the total area that we tend to play in. It doesn't cover the very low end. We will be -- we feel we have good coverage with the 28 and the 45-nanometer solution at the low end. And we will be bolstering that low-end portfolio in the future with a new generation of technology. But that's what this is being taped out. The initial product is a relatively high-end product with an embedded processor, but it's not the ultimate high end. It's sort of just on the theme between the midrange and the high end of the product offering. And we're going to continue to expand going up and down. And the first version does have the embedded CPU core, and that will be the first one that will come out will have. It's targeted to have the embedded CPU core, and that has a tremendous level of interest in the market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: There will be additional tapeout as we move through the year. I'm mean, this is just the first tapeout as we've wound down our 20-nanometer tapeout focus and getting all those out the market, and 16 comes right behind it. And they'll continue to have tape
componenttext: There will be additional tapeout as we move through the year. I'm mean, this is just the first tapeout as we've wound down our 20-nanometer tapeout focus and getting all those out the market, and 16 comes right behind it. And they'll continue to have tapeouts throughout the rest -- remainder of this year and into the following fiscal year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kulin Patel for Ambrish. I have a question on -- earlier, you mentioned that you plan to introduce 7-nanometer product in 2017. It implies that there's a 2-year gap between the tapeouts of 15 and 7. Are you skipping 10-nanometer? And is there any reason w
componenttext: Kulin Patel for Ambrish. I have a question on -- earlier, you mentioned that you plan to introduce 7-nanometer product in 2017. It implies that there's a 2-year gap between the tapeouts of 15 and 7. Are you skipping 10-nanometer? And is there any reason why you're skipping 10-nanometer?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if you look at the sequence, there's 28 and then 20, and 16 came out in rapid succession. And there's actually 2 flavors of 16, those of 16FF and the 16FF+. So we -- after we did the 20, we decided to skip the 16FF and go straight to the FF+ with
componenttext: Okay. So if you look at the sequence, there's 28 and then 20, and 16 came out in rapid succession. And there's actually 2 flavors of 16, those of 16FF and the 16FF+. So we -- after we did the 20, we decided to skip the 16FF and go straight to the FF+ with -- the gap between 7 and 10 at TSMC actually is quite significant in terms of the capabilities of the 2 products. And from our perspective, our customers can only digest technology at a certain cadence. If we bring out technology every 3 months, that's not going to help them. So to some extent, the somewhere between every 2 to 3 years to have a major technology refresh for the businesses we're in is the right cadence. And what we decided to do is to shoot for the best technology, which will be available in that sort of time frame. And because the 7-nanometer fits the bill and it's lower power and denser and actually higher performance, we felt it was better to do that than to split between the 10 and the 7. So that's sort of the thinking. And we're quite confident that this is the right decision in terms of our customer requirements.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Vivek Arya with BofA.
componenttext: The next question is from Vivek Arya with BofA.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Shankar on behalf of Vivek. So I just want to dig into the wireless weakness. So if you go to China Mobile [ph], they've been adding a lot of [indiscernible] flavors. So is the real reason for the weakness is the excess inventory? Or you think cus
componenttext: This is Shankar on behalf of Vivek. So I just want to dig into the wireless weakness. So if you go to China Mobile [ph], they've been adding a lot of [indiscernible] flavors. So is the real reason for the weakness is the excess inventory? Or you think customers are using more ASICs and ASSPs more [indiscernible] than before? And what do you think will turn this around for you in the long run?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answers are different by geography. To that question, it really isn't the same trends or stuff. China, in general, has been stalled out, both the FD standard deployment, which is one of the bigger things that was -- we were counting on for this
componenttext: Well, the answers are different by geography. To that question, it really isn't the same trends or stuff. China, in general, has been stalled out, both the FD standard deployment, which is one of the bigger things that was -- we were counting on for this year to actually begin and be more robust as we move through the year. That was stalled out originally by China Unicom and China Telecoms, the audits that they had relative to ethics and those kinds of things that went on. There's been an overall slowdown of capital spend in China on infrastructure which is more of a macro thing going on relative to the China issue. So I think that's been the biggest driver there. And there absolutely has been a buildup of base station, inventory and our product in the Chinese suppliers that is being led off, as China Mobile continues to deploy at a much lower rate than the previous year. But China Unicom and China Telecom not as much. So if you -- people have told me that if you're in China and you're using one of those handsets from the China Mobile network, there's still a lot of coverage issues and a lot -- so there's lot of things are left to be done there. So I'm not so sure it's driven by the subscriber pool. I think there are some bigger issues going on there. Relative to North America, it's kind of bifurcated into Sprint who is also having some financial issues in terms of funding other networks. So they slowed down the deployment of their network. And they've gone through a rebidding process, and that process has been completed as best as we can tell. And so again, we think that because of those milestones, we think things are going to start to turn around and grow for us in the second half of this year and into calendar 2016. AT&T and Verizon has slowed down their cap spending in the first part of the year. There were Spectrum acquisitions. They also are starting to spend a little more money now, and there are going to be additional capacity utilization of that network. So it really is different by different carriers and geographies. The thought process about what's going to turn this around for us is just exactly the fact that subscriber and coverage is not uniformly sufficient and good in those geographies. And as Moshe said earlier, it's a matter of when, it's not a matter of if for us. And again, we've seen positive press coming out of carriers relative to some improvement in that. We've seen orders come with respect to India, some growth there. So we have some specific orders ahead of us on that. So we are starting to see some positive signs that would lead us to believe that the second half of the fiscal year will be better.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I have one follow-up. So on the data center side, the accelerator opportunity was the main [ph] reason why Intel acquired Altera. Can you talk about how big the market is for you? Is it still an area of focus? And if Intel acquiring Altera, are the
componenttext: Great. I have one follow-up. So on the data center side, the accelerator opportunity was the main [ph] reason why Intel acquired Altera. Can you talk about how big the market is for you? Is it still an area of focus? And if Intel acquiring Altera, are they somehow going to promote optimized product that can [indiscernible] to the market? Can you just give us some color around the data center opportunity?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the various elements to the data center and there is elements that focus on storage, elements that focus on networking and elements that focus on compute. So the storage and networking are largely unimpacted by this acquisition. And the compute s
componenttext: Okay. So the various elements to the data center and there is elements that focus on storage, elements that focus on networking and elements that focus on compute. So the storage and networking are largely unimpacted by this acquisition. And the compute space, it's very clear that FPGAs provide a viable, very attractive lower-power solution, which significantly provides an improvement in the performance per watt by -- what we are seeing is somewhere between 22 to 30X on -- in several applications, vis-à-vis stand-alone, high-performance processor. And that's because these applications in the cloud tend to be massively parallel, and these processors are inherently not parallel engines. They're very sequential. That's the way a CPU operates. And even if you have multiple CPU cords, you can achieve only a certain level of parallelism that way. So FPGAs actually can provide tremendous acceleration at the same power form or level of power consumption, just to make sure, or they can provide at a much lower level of power consumption. They can deliver equivalent performance. Now we believe that when Intel consummates its acquisition, when that happens, then there will be some integration opportunities. The challenge there is that you're taking a very high-power solution, which is an x86, and you're adding to it another high-power solution, which is a larger FPGA. And to some extent, if you try to integrate both of those on the same silicon, you're limited with regards to what you can do. So we believe that, that market, the Intel x86 will have an element which will have an integrated solution, and there will have an element which has these distributed solutions where the FPGA will be separate. We see a lot of the traditional data center customers having a strong interest in actually retaining autonomy and independence in that second mode. So they can decide how they design their system, and obviously would be a wonderful solution for them. So even in the Intel x86 space, we believe we have a play. Not to mention that everywhere where it's not Intel, and this is a market which is emerging, right? So there's a lot of competing solutions. It will come to the market over the next few years. We will be the natural shoo-in for that for those solutions. So I would say there is upside for us definitely vis-a-vis beyond where we are today. And we are committed to that market, and we expect to see business growth in that market. And we believe that, that market is in its very early stages of evolution. And over time, we will have a stronger position in it than we definitely have now. So hopefully that answered your question. I apologize if it was more than you wanted to hear or not.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Just as a quick follow-up to the data center question-and-answer that you just provided, which was very useful. How competitive do you said you are relative to Altera now with software and OpenCL, which I believe was the reason for the delay initially in you getting in that end market?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, to be totally honest, we were not -- we did not recognize that market early. Hence, on the software side, we did have a product efficiency. Now based on what customers are telling us, not only are we not behind, but we're actually ahead of the compet
componenttext: Yes, to be totally honest, we were not -- we did not recognize that market early. Hence, on the software side, we did have a product efficiency. Now based on what customers are telling us, not only are we not behind, but we're actually ahead of the competition. So I think we've largely closed that gap, and if anything, it is a competitive advantage for us. We believe that the very deep synthesis technology that we have now delivered as part of our divided product, that gives us a tremendous advantage over any other solution in the market today. And as we product-sized it and we're now starting to broadly deliver it to customers, the feedback we're getting is that we are ahead in terms of technology. So the software is no longer the issue. If anything, it's working in our favor.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's very useful. And then just a quick follow-up. Is there any end-of-life product headwind embedded in your September quarter guidance?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. Just wanted to follow up on all of the challenges that have been articulated in the wireless market. Curious if it's changing the way of thinking about providing quarter-to-quarter forecast as well and maybe handicapping
componenttext: Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. Just wanted to follow up on all of the challenges that have been articulated in the wireless market. Curious if it's changing the way of thinking about providing quarter-to-quarter forecast as well and maybe handicapping customer forecast more than normal? And I guess the other question would be how that reflects into the turns rate that's embedded in guidance, given that this was a transition towards distributors or distribution transition as well?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gabriella, it is certainly a challenge in, I will say, any market where we have a very high concentration. And there has -- in this particular situation, it seems to be more of a worldwide trend that's going on. And if you look at other subcontractor comp
componenttext: Gabriella, it is certainly a challenge in, I will say, any market where we have a very high concentration. And there has -- in this particular situation, it seems to be more of a worldwide trend that's going on. And if you look at other subcontractor companies of -- it has the same challenges as we do in this area. I don't think -- because we have such a diversified portfolio beyond just wireless and overall communications, I don't think that's going to cause us to change our -- at least our desire to try to do a forecast and do the best we possibly can. I think we're at a point here of certainly a multiyear historic low for us in terms of our revenue and in this segment, and it is challenging. But I think we'll continue to try to push through and figure this out. Now relative to the turns percentage number that I provided, while it was quite a bit higher on a percentage basis than our actual turns from the previous quarter, I think we've been relatively conservative on the wireless forecast that supports that. We had quite a bit of business booked early in the quarter, the previous quarter. And then moving into this current quarter that we just started, we're back to a more normal booking pattern, and the actual dollars we need in terms on a weekly basis is not that much greater than the actual dollars per week we had in the previous quarter. So I think we're pretty well balanced in to see how things go throughout the quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the color. And maybe just as a follow-up, if I could, on the gross margin profile of the business. Maybe if we think about year-over-year how the gross margin profile of the company has changed, help us understand how much of that is mix
componenttext: I appreciate all the color. And maybe just as a follow-up, if I could, on the gross margin profile of the business. Maybe if we think about year-over-year how the gross margin profile of the company has changed, help us understand how much of that is mix shift, either between end markets from between different product groups? And how much of it is structural initiatives that the company has been taken to improve the longer-term gross margin profile?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so at our Investor Day, we talked about a 68% to 70% range for this year. So if you look at the midpoint, that would be 69%. And we've been running at 70% and 71%. So all the cost reductions that we have -- that we had in that forecast at Investor Da
componenttext: Yes, so at our Investor Day, we talked about a 68% to 70% range for this year. So if you look at the midpoint, that would be 69%. And we've been running at 70% and 71%. So all the cost reductions that we have -- that we had in that forecast at Investor Day that drove the 68% to 70% are on track, and we're doing very well. So I would say if I compare it to our previous forecast, we are on track on all the cost reductions. There is a lot of mix issues going on. We do have a slightly stronger industrial, aerospace and defense profile than we thought at that point in time, and we had a substantially weaker communications business. And that would -- that mix would tend to push our gross margins to this very high elevated point that we are right now. So I think both product and customer mix is accounted for quite a bit. As is, I think in the absence of a more normal -- normalized end market mix that we would have envisioned at the Investor Day, we'll be running in the 68% to 70% range, probably pretty close to the center of that. So I guess the short answer to your question is a lot of it is product mix and end-market customer mix.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

I was just hoping you could talk a little more about industrial within this bucket. For example, what you're seeing with end demand, and then also, your view on inventory today and going forward into the back half of the year?

componenttext: Yes. Our industrial, as we stated, our industrial was a record quarterly revenue for us, have very strong contribution in North America and in Asia Pac to be very specific on that. We're starting to see growth of the Zynq microprocessor-based FPGA in our numbers and broadly, new applications and motor-control connected factories, industrial IoT kinds of areas. We're starting to see those designs that we've won over the last couple of years start to accumulate in revenue. So while I know there's been some challenging statements about the industrial market overall, we saw -- we started to see some of the positive things we've been talking about there over the last year or so start to mound up and be more significant within our numbers, in addition to our traditional areas.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I'm looking at the roadmaps here. It turns out that, by my reckoning, in 2018, you guys are going to be ramping or very early ramping 7-nanometer. And if Altera chooses or if Intel chooses to be the provider of foundry  services for Altera, there w
componenttext: Moshe, I'm looking at the roadmaps here. It turns out that, by my reckoning, in 2018, you guys are going to be ramping or very early ramping 7-nanometer. And if Altera chooses or if Intel chooses to be the provider of foundry  services for Altera, there will be a 10. Was there a competitive reason behind your decision to skip 10-nanometer besides that the cadence aspect of your customer's preference?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not really. That's a great question. We just looked at what the right solution. Everything was available to us and what would be the right solution, and TSMC had their 10. And then we said, "Well, is there anything beyond that?" And they told us that they
componenttext: Not really. That's a great question. We just looked at what the right solution. Everything was available to us and what would be the right solution, and TSMC had their 10. And then we said, "Well, is there anything beyond that?" And they told us that they were working on this future technology. TSMC is very committed to driving technology and capacity leadership. And when we saw what it is, we felt that we would be compelling and just based on that. Now indirectly, we have no idea what Altera and Intel were going to do. And Altera had said that they were looking at TSMC's road map, and I would be surprised if TSMC did not show them the same thing, too, to be honest, right? That probably just makes sense for TSMC to show that they have. So it wasn't -- we didn't know what was available at Intel, but we just decided that the right thing for our customer base was to go to the 7-nanometer. And that looks like a very compelling solution in particular as they are committed to delivering it in 2017, and that's when we need it, to be honest.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay, and if I could, a follow-on on the Zynq side. In the automotive models that you're in, are you -- do you know if you're in the front-facing cameras? Was Zynq being used in that kind of an application within a car?
componenttext: Right. Okay, and if I could, a follow-on on the Zynq side. In the automotive models that you're in, are you -- do you know if you're in the front-facing cameras? Was Zynq being used in that kind of an application within a car?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what image processing software -- do you provide that? Or is that a third party?
componenttext: Okay. And what image processing software -- do you provide that? Or is that a third party?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It comes from a variety of sources, some of which are internal to us, some of which come from the customers provide, and in some cases, it's a third party which provides them. So it's a combination of all 3. The -- just to sort of comment on that, what we
componenttext: It comes from a variety of sources, some of which are internal to us, some of which come from the customers provide, and in some cases, it's a third party which provides them. So it's a combination of all 3. The -- just to sort of comment on that, what we're seeing -- and I said this in response to an early question, we're seeing customers look at a canned, non-differentiated ASSPs solution versus a highly differentiated solution using our devices. And for the high end, it's a no-brainer that they want a differentiated solution. And then as you look at the midrange, it's less clear and definitely at the low-end times. They just are prepared to have a meat-and-potato solution as opposed to something which is more specialized. But interestingly, because this has become a platform play, then we are starting to see design wins where the customers are committing their entire product offering to our platform. And as a result, they're pushing us hard to provide them with a lower end, and we typically would have provided a solution for that. And so that's a growth opportunity for us, and it's driven by this broad platform-oriented approach where the companies are sort of saying, "We can't afford to have different solutions," and because we want to have differentiation, they go with us across the board. And that's another reason that I believe that our market share, which we're happy with the revenue at this point, but our market share is not high yet. We believe that there is an opportunity to grow it going forward.

This quarter, we will be presenting at the Pacific Coast -- Pacific Crest Global Technology Forum in Vail on August 10 and the 2015 Citi Global Technology Conference in New York City on September 9. 
This completes our call. Thank you very much for your participation.
