headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. This quarter, we changed our revenue by product categor
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the June quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions. 
This quarter, we changed our revenue by product category classification. We make changes to this classification on a regular basis as products mature and new products are introduced. And they have been the product categories to be more meaningful to investors. In addition, we consolidated the other end market category into the communications and data center end market. For comparative purposes, we have provided supplemental schedule on our website at www.investor.xilinx.com that presents results based on the previous category classification. 
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. 
We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx Investor Relations website. 
Let me now turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Xilinx sales were $549 million, down 3% sequentially and within our guidance. Profitability remained strong during the quarter with a better-than-expected gross margin, continued OpEx control and healthy cash flow generation.  New product
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Xilinx sales were $549 million, down 3% sequentially and within our guidance. Profitability remained strong during the quarter with a better-than-expected gross margin, continued OpEx control and healthy cash flow generation.  New product sales decreased 10% in the quarter, almost entirely driven by 28-nanometer products which were impacted by weak sales to wireless customers. Sales from 20-nanometer products exceeded $10 million during the quarter, doubling from the prior quarter. 
From an end market perspective, sales from communication and data center remained weak, decreasing 11% sequentially. The greater-than-forecasted decline was driven by wireless communications, which was weaker than anticipated due to continued decline from our broad base of customers predominantly serving the China and U.S. markets. Wired sales were as expected for the quarter. While shipments into the cable access business were particularly strong, overall CapEx spending remains weak. Wired communications was the largest end market contributor to 28-nanometer revenues in fiscal Q1. The industrial and aerospace and defense segment was better than forecasted, driven by ISM and A&D. ISM sales were a record during the quarter. Sales from test declined as expected. 
Lastly, broadcast, consumer and automotive was essentially flat as expected. Although flat sequentially, sales from automotive are up nearly 50% from the same quarter a year ago and remain at a record 7% of total sales. Gross margin was 70.9% for the quarter, better than anticipated, primarily as a result of product and customer mix, although we continued to be focused on driving improvements in profitability. 
Operating expenses, including $2 million in amortization, were $211 million, in line with expectations. 
Other income was a net expense of $11 million, slightly better than forecasted due to a long-term investment gains. 
Net income for the quarter was $148 million or $0.55 per diluted share. 
Operating cash flow for the June quarter was $183 million before $8 million in CapEx. 
Diluted shares for the quarter were $271 million. There was a $9 million share dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions relating to the dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.xilinx.com. 
We repurchased 2.2 million shares for $100 million during the quarter and made a record $80 million payment in quarterly dividends. We returned nearly 100% of operating cash flow to shareholders during the quarter. 
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments were flat at $3.6 billion. We have $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt, resulting in a net cash position of approximately $2 billion. Inventory dollars at Xilinx decreased $9 million sequentially. 
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the September quarter of fiscal year '16. Our backlog heading into the quarter is down sequentially. Communications is forecasted to be flat. The wireless market continues to be challenging and is negatively impacting our previously stated full year revenue estimates. While we do expect improvement in the second half of fiscal '16 from increased spending in China, North America and India, the rate of improvement remains difficult to forecast. Wired communications continues to be impacted by a weak CapEx environment, although we expect to continue to benefit throughout the year from revenue growth in new programs where we have displayed the ASSPs in addition to gaining share in traditional and BGA sockets. The strength of these programs are in the areas of cable infrastructure, access and OTN. We expect the industrial and aerospace and defense segment to be down substantially due to a decrease in A&D, driven by the expected conclusion of a large program. 
Xilinx's 28-nanometer parts were recently designed into subsystems of the next-generation program that is expected to begin production in fiscal year '17. Although the aerospace and defense market has been characterized by quarterly volatility, this segment remains an important business for Xilinx. Our 28-nanometer revenues are growing at a rate much faster than previous new product introductions as we expand our presence in areas, such as situational awareness, public safety and embedded vision systems. ISM is expected to be approximately flat during the quarter, and test is expected to decline. 
Lastly, we expect all components of the broadcast, consumer and automotive category to be approximately flat. We expect strong growth in automotive in fiscal '16 as Zynq enters volume production at many large OEMs. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be down 2% to 6% -- so down 2% to down 6% sequentially. The midpoint of this guidance is predicated on a turns rate of approximately 51%. 
Gross margin is expected to be approximately 69% to 70%. Operating expenses for the September quarter are expected to be approximately $217 million, including $2 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. 
As I mentioned last quarter, Q1 OpEx would be the low point for the year. The increase in Q2 OpEx will be driven primarily by hiring in the sales force and increased tapeout expense related primarily to the 16-nanometer technology generation. 
Other income and expense for the September quarter will be a net expense of $10 million. 
The share count is expected to be approximately 268 million shares. 
The tax rate for September quarter is expected to be approximately 12%. The reset of our tax rate guidance to 12% is due to a change in the jurisdictional mix of earnings. 
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. Though the June quarter was challenging from top line perspective, I continued to be pleased with our focus on delivering sustained type profitability. Gross margin was 70.9%, better than expectations, drivin
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon to you all. Though the June quarter was challenging from top line perspective, I continued to be pleased with our focus on delivering sustained type profitability. Gross margin was 70.9%, better than expectations, driving an operating margin of 32.5%. 28-nanometer revenue declined, as we anticipated, driven by weakness in wireless communications. However, sales from our Zynq product family, the industries first all-programmable SoCs, increased more than 40%. The primary driver for this growth came from ADAS applications, important industry growth driver ideally suited to benefit from the Zynq product families, innovative and differentiated capabilities. We expect 28-nanometer sales to return to growth in the September quarter, driven by continued sales increase from the Zynq products, as well as an increase in wired communications. Additionally, we're forecasting 28-nanometer revenue to grow for the balance of fiscal year 2016, driven by demand stabilization in communications and continued strong adoption in automotive, ISM, test and aerospace and defense. We're also executing very well with our 20-nanometer UltraScale portfolio. Technology leadership at this node is very rapidly translating to sales leadership. We have now shipped 20-nanometer parts to more than 140 discrete customers in all of our major end markets. 20-nanometer revenue in the June quarter doubled sequentially to more than $10 million with significant growth coming from Virtex UltraScale, the industry's only ASIC class, 20-nanometer high-end product offering. 
In the September quarter, we are forecasting 20-nanometer sales to exceed $50 million, so experiencing a sales ramp that is more accelerated than our initial expectation. We estimate our share of this node to be approaching 82%, confident our share of 20-nanometer will continue to exceed 65% market share we have delivered at 28-nanometer. 
The 16-nanometer node, we taped out the industry's first All Programmable Multi-Processor SoC using TSMC's 16FF+ process. This product family targets applications in embedded vision, including ADAS, Industrial Internet of Things and 5G wireless systems. 
During the June quarter, we also extended our world-class partnership with TSMC, the undisputed leader in the foundry industry with the announcement that we will be leveraging TSMC's 7-nanometer process technology, 3D IC technology for our next generation of All Programmable FPGAs, 3D ICs and MPSoCs. The technology represents the fourth consecutive generation where the 2 companies are partnered, advanced process and CoWoS stacking technology and will become TSMC's fourth generation of FinFET technology. We anticipate the first tapeout of 7-nanometer in calendar 2017. 
Finally, with regard to design software, earlier this week, we announced the public access release of our SDSoC development  environment to expand the user base of Zynq SoCs and MPSoCs to a broad community of systems and software engineers, both existing and new markets. 
Despite weak global communication spending environment, I remain very confident in Xilinx's strong technology leadership and market expansion initiatives driven by Zynq, our new SDx software-designed development environment. We will continue to focus on maintaining high levels of profitability in any business environment with the overall goal of maximizing shareholder return [ph]. 
Let me now turn the call back to the operator for questions and answers.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, a bigger-picture question for you. Similar to what we've been asking Linear Tech. What is your view on what's going on with overall demand being weaker than expected, whether by geography, end market or whatever you believe the cause to be? And do
componenttext: Moshe, a bigger-picture question for you. Similar to what we've been asking Linear Tech. What is your view on what's going on with overall demand being weaker than expected, whether by geography, end market or whatever you believe the cause to be? And do you think that is more of a short-term pause or is something that's a little more longer in duration?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We see the weakness primarily in wireless, and it's being choppy and less predictable than we had thought it would be for some time now. And as a result, we're very hesitant to call when the visibility will improve there. We do think it's a question of wh
componenttext: We see the weakness primarily in wireless, and it's being choppy and less predictable than we had thought it would be for some time now. And as a result, we're very hesitant to call when the visibility will improve there. We do think it's a question of when, not a question of if, but it has shrunk by significant amounts. And if you compare where we were a year ago to where we are now, I think it's several tens of percent lower. So that's the major market or vertical where we're seeing issues. All of the other areas, I won't say that they're buoyant and vibrant or doing great, but they're sort of holding up for us. So that's the Xilinx perspective. Jon, do you concur?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do concur. I would also add to that, that our share position is, and particularly in the wireless segment, is still very strong. And I think that helps bolster the -- our confidence that when these things do come back, we're going to be a strong pa
componenttext: Yes, I do concur. I would also add to that, that our share position is, and particularly in the wireless segment, is still very strong. And I think that helps bolster the -- our confidence that when these things do come back, we're going to be a strong participant of that. And as I've said, it's very hard to get exactly what the trajectory of the second half improvement is, and then we see signs and positive statements out of -- from both customers and carriers, but we are living quarter-by-quarter right now in this particular end market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from William Stein with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: The next question is from William Stein with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The negative outlook in the industrial end market where you're citing ending of a program in aerospace and defense, was there a sort of last-time buy that was associated with that, that was going on recently? And then I have a follow-up, please.
componenttext: The negative outlook in the industrial end market where you're citing ending of a program in aerospace and defense, was there a sort of last-time buy that was associated with that, that was going on recently? And then I have a follow-up, please.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, well, this is part of the announced program where the joint strike -- it was specifically the Joint Strike Fighter, where there is a very large set of purchases going on over a period of 1.5 years to 2 years. And this is just the -- essentially the en
componenttext: Oh, well, this is part of the announced program where the joint strike -- it was specifically the Joint Strike Fighter, where there is a very large set of purchases going on over a period of 1.5 years to 2 years. And this is just the -- essentially the end of that particular procurement. And they are redesigning some of the key elements in electronics inside the aircraft. And as I've said, we're winning all the redesigns, it's just that there's this gap between when the older designs materials being acquired versus the new periods. So we're at the end of that particular program, and we won't see any significant revenue shipped into that program for the remainder of this year. So I wouldn't associate it wholly with any sort of a last-time buy situation.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then the follow-up is a much broader question. Competitively, when you talk to customers, I'd love to hear about the sort of positioning the company does relative to your competitor, soon likely to be owned by Intel, whether that changes the dynamic,
componenttext: And then the follow-up is a much broader question. Competitively, when you talk to customers, I'd love to hear about the sort of positioning the company does relative to your competitor, soon likely to be owned by Intel, whether that changes the dynamic, and how so, both on the relationship side and then the anticipated manufacturing change that might happen at that supplier.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, let me take it. So fundamentally, if you look at the markets we service they're highly diversified markets that look for very advanced technology and a significant level of support with a very long life cycle. And this is a market we have serv
componenttext: Okay. Well, let me take it. So fundamentally, if you look at the markets we service they're highly diversified markets that look for very advanced technology and a significant level of support with a very long life cycle. And this is a market we have serviced really well. We continue to service it well. We have delivered market share expansion of 28-nanometer. We're seeing that expand to a better position of 20. We believe we're ahead of the game now, being the first to tapeout at the node beyond that 16. And we are already working with TSMC on the 7-nanometer, and we expect to tapeout in the 2017 time frame. So on the silicon side, the customers are very assured that they will continue to have the same level of excellence in terms of technology, leadership and timeliness, and that's an opportunity for us. Now when you supplement that with the leadership we have in the software and the expansion with the new products, the FD Xcell and the SDSoC, which we now are broadly making available to customers. And not only is it the best silicon, but it's the best software in the industry and the best support infrastructure in the industry. So we actually believe that this is an opportunity for us, and we'd say that customers are reassured by that, and we know that we are the biggest and have been for the longest period of time the leader and the bellwether player in this market. So we remain committed to it. And together with our unique relationship with TSMC and ARM now, they will continue to get the best product around to serve their requirements. So as the market will evolve and we don't know what will happen on the other side, I think generally speaking, this bodes well for us. And that's why we're invest -- continue to invest heavily to make sure we can exploit this opportunity.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Chris Danely with Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Chris Danely with Citi.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Now that the Altera, Intel thing is officially official, I guess I can stop asking my hypothetical questions and ask some real questions. So are you seeing any reaction from your customers on that? And then Intel talked about a delay in 10 nanometers. I m
componenttext: Now that the Altera, Intel thing is officially official, I guess I can stop asking my hypothetical questions and ask some real questions. So are you seeing any reaction from your customers on that? And then Intel talked about a delay in 10 nanometers. I mean, how do you think that positions Altera versus yourselves?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I can add a lot more to what I said before. We're focused on delivering leadership on silicon, on software, in terms of support. And we are working with TSMC and with ARM on the next generation of product, and we now have announced the
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I can add a lot more to what I said before. We're focused on delivering leadership on silicon, on software, in terms of support. And we are working with TSMC and with ARM on the next generation of product, and we now have announced the 7-nanometer tapeout. And TSMC announced it will be available 2017, and we expect to tapeout at that point in time. So we're focused on execution and all of the uncertainty with regards to the Altera acquisition by Intel. I think that's generally an opportunity for us as long as we continue to execute and deliver. And since we've done that at 28 and the results speak to themselves, the results of 20 already demonstrate you need a better market share for 16, and we're working on 7. I think as we continue to execute, there is upside for us from all of the uncertainty.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Has there been any reaction from the customers?
componenttext: Has there been any reaction from the customers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: They -- customers are generally happy that they have a -- the bellwether and the largest company in the business continue to focus on this mode of business, right? And I think it's a wait and see for them with regards to see what will happen on the other
componenttext: They -- customers are generally happy that they have a -- the bellwether and the largest company in the business continue to focus on this mode of business, right? And I think it's a wait and see for them with regards to see what will happen on the other side, right? But we are around. We're open for business, and we are committed and continuing to be committed to delivering the leadership, both on the technology and the support side.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Srini Pajjuri with CLSA.
componenttext: The next question is from Srini Pajjuri with CLSA.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Goodman for Srini. I got another one for you on Intel and Altera. So now with that kind of in the works, I'm curious if you see any need to maybe go out and get access through a partnership or maybe start working in-house on a custom ARM core
componenttext: This is Ryan Goodman for Srini. I got another one for you on Intel and Altera. So now with that kind of in the works, I'm curious if you see any need to maybe go out and get access through a partnership or maybe start working in-house on a custom ARM core just to stay competitive in terms of potential integration advantages that Intel may have with Altera over time?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's a great question. And we were first at 28 with Zynq. We were first at 16 with our MPSoC product, which actually has a very attractive performance level. And we believe that for most of the markets that we're addressing, ARM is actually, by far,
componenttext: So that's a great question. And we were first at 28 with Zynq. We were first at 16 with our MPSoC product, which actually has a very attractive performance level. And we believe that for most of the markets that we're addressing, ARM is actually, by far, the best solution. You could say that the one potential exception to that is the data center market, but the data center market is likely to bifurcate into Intel and the rest of the world. And for the rest of the world, we believe we're going to be the natural and best solution. So there's upside for us there. And we think we can do it with the ARM product roadmap and with the TSMC process, and we've already demonstrated that. There's a lot of bluster about the leadership that Intel would deliver to Altera. The fact is we already had with regards to that node. So we believe that we're in good shape, both strategically and tactically, and definitely the ARM roadmap will suffice. Now if you're asking a very specific question, could there be markets where a fully optimized x86 should provide some advantage, the answer to that is yes. There are some markets. It tends to be a small subset of the overall market. And we think that for most of the market, we will have a very adequate and competitive solution using our existing roadmap.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just want to follow up on the financial model. You had hinted in the prepared comments that the wireless issues are kind of challenging your prior target for flat, up 2% for the fiscal year. So just curious if there's anything else t
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just want to follow up on the financial model. You had hinted in the prepared comments that the wireless issues are kind of challenging your prior target for flat, up 2% for the fiscal year. So just curious if there's anything else to add there, if you were providing an actual update there? And also on the OpEx side, too, I think you had a forecast out there, just maybe an update on how that's tracking.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So at this time, we are going to go quarter by quarter. The wireless, as I've said in the previous answer as well, the -- it's really hard to understand what the pace of the change of the trajectory is on China and the U.S., specifically the Chinese
componenttext: Yes. So at this time, we are going to go quarter by quarter. The wireless, as I've said in the previous answer as well, the -- it's really hard to understand what the pace of the change of the trajectory is on China and the U.S., specifically the Chinese base station rollout and more specifically Sprint for us, which was one of our leading growth vectors in North America. I mean, Verizon and AT&T were also involved, but Sprint was certainly one of the leading growth vectors there. So we are not giving a new number for the full year just because of the challenge of understanding what that really means to us. So meaning, how strong will it come back? Will it come back in the second half? All those things, really hard for us to say. So we aren't putting out a new number. Spending, we revised spending, downward in our last call, vis-à-vis what we said at Investor Day, and we aren't changing that forecast this time.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ian Ing with MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question is from Ian Ing with MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A bit early at $10 million of revenue per quarter, but can you talk about 20-nanometers, perhaps yields, execution, volume ramps as it compares to 28-nanometers?
componenttext: A bit early at $10 million of revenue per quarter, but can you talk about 20-nanometers, perhaps yields, execution, volume ramps as it compares to 28-nanometers?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Ian. So if you look at 28, it was a very, very, very broad node, and there is a low end, the midrange, high end. There was the Zynq product line, which ended up with the large number of products. From our perspective, the 20 and 1
componenttext: That's a great question, Ian. So if you look at 28, it was a very, very, very broad node, and there is a low end, the midrange, high end. There was the Zynq product line, which ended up with the large number of products. From our perspective, the 20 and 16 together, which are coming out relatively close, closer than typical should more or less be equivalent to 28. So 20 is not as big as 28, but neither did we expect it to be. And 20 is now benefiting from the fact that we have a high end and a midrange there. And that's what is generating this level of revenue. But there's no low end, then there's no Zynq equivalent on the 20-nanometer. And hence, overall, it's not as vibrant as the 28 was, but on the other hand, it's doing better than we had expected. So we're quite pleased with the results so far. And the pickup in terms of design wins, which are now rapidly turning into revenue, is very encouraging from my perspective.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And for my follow-up, I mean, how much do you think Xilinx customers are seeing price increases year-to-date, whether it's deliberate value-based pricing or the strong dollar overseas? And what's the response been? I know Avnet, as early as early J
componenttext: Great. And for my follow-up, I mean, how much do you think Xilinx customers are seeing price increases year-to-date, whether it's deliberate value-based pricing or the strong dollar overseas? And what's the response been? I know Avnet, as early as early June, said there's really no impact to the strong dollar. I just wanted to check in on that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I certainly am not seeing much impact to the stronger dollar. Of course, it's pulled back a little bit now. But we really haven't. We -- I thought I sensed a pause in our industrial business in Europe a few quarters back, but then it bounced back the
componenttext: Yes. I certainly am not seeing much impact to the stronger dollar. Of course, it's pulled back a little bit now. But we really haven't. We -- I thought I sensed a pause in our industrial business in Europe a few quarters back, but then it bounced back the next quarter, and it's stable now. I mean, it's got growth -- some growth going on there. But -- so we really haven't seen anything there overall. So yes, generally I think things are not being impacted on a worldwide basis because of the currency strength for us.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Christopher Rolland with FBR Capital Markets and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Christopher Rolland with FBR Capital Markets and Company.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Joe on for Chris. So you've recently been promoting Zynq for ADAS and embedded vision. But there's one clear winner in embedded vision appears they are using the ASIC approach. So what gives you confidence there that there will be a gravitation towar
componenttext: It's Joe on for Chris. So you've recently been promoting Zynq for ADAS and embedded vision. But there's one clear winner in embedded vision appears they are using the ASIC approach. So what gives you confidence there that there will be a gravitation toward FPGAs? And who are your early design wins there?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, we're very confident because we have design wins, and we have models that are going into production. And I think there is already 12, and it could be that the number is slightly higher. There are already 12 models that are going into productio
componenttext: Okay. Well, we're very confident because we have design wins, and we have models that are going into production. And I think there is already 12, and it could be that the number is slightly higher. There are already 12 models that are going into production at this point in time with our solution. We don't have the plurality of the market. It's a market which is emerging, but we believe that it's a great starting point for us, and it's helping to drive our business and for everyone who's looking for a differentiated solution as opposed to a cookie-cutter solution, which will give you -- which won't give you an advantage, then we are trained to ride with that regard. And we've seen more and more of the customers adopt a solution. I don't think we're going to have 50% market share this generation, but we are already garnering a tremendous number of design wins with the MPSoC for the follow-on for that. So we're very pleased with the market share with our Zynq product offering, and we expect that to expand with the MPSoCs, the market which is in its infancy. And I think that it's still too early to assume that there is only going to be one winner. We expect to be a significant winner in this market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, I know -- back to the 16-nanometer tapeout, I know there is a press release recently about taping out a program, a little multiprocessor, 16-nanometer chip. What else or what else are you close to taping out on 16-
componenttext: That's helpful. And then as a follow-up, I know -- back to the 16-nanometer tapeout, I know there is a press release recently about taping out a program, a little multiprocessor, 16-nanometer chip. What else or what else are you close to taping out on 16-nanometer? And how should we think about the progression of products at that node? Will it be high end first then midrange then low? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the 16-nanometer offering is quite broad. And it has a midrange, a high end and a very extensive processor roadmap. So that's the MPSoC. So it covers probably 80% or 70% to 80% of the total area that we tend to play in. It doesn't cover the very low
componenttext: Well, the 16-nanometer offering is quite broad. And it has a midrange, a high end and a very extensive processor roadmap. So that's the MPSoC. So it covers probably 80% or 70% to 80% of the total area that we tend to play in. It doesn't cover the very low end. We will be -- we feel we have good coverage with the 28 and the 45-nanometer solution at the low end. And we will be bolstering that low-end portfolio in the future with a new generation of technology. But that's what this is being taped out. The initial product is a relatively high-end product with an embedded processor, but it's not the ultimate high end. It's sort of just on the theme between the midrange and the high end of the product offering. And we're going to continue to expand going up and down. And the first version does have the embedded CPU core, and that will be the first one that will come out we'll have. It's targeted to have the embedded CPU core, and that has a tremendous level of interest in the market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: There will be additional tapeout as we move through the year. I'm mean, this is just the first tapeout as we've wound down our 20-nanometer tapeout focus and getting all those out the market, and 16 comes right behind it. And they'll continue to have tape
componenttext: There will be additional tapeout as we move through the year. I'm mean, this is just the first tapeout as we've wound down our 20-nanometer tapeout focus and getting all those out the market, and 16 comes right behind it. And they'll continue to have tapeouts throughout the rest -- remainder of this year and into the following fiscal year.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kulin Patel for Ambrish. I have a question on -- earlier, you mentioned that you plan to introduce 7-nanometer product in 2017. It implies that there's a 2-year gap between the tapeouts of 15 and 7. Are you skipping 10-nanometer? And is there any reason w
componenttext: Kulin Patel for Ambrish. I have a question on -- earlier, you mentioned that you plan to introduce 7-nanometer product in 2017. It implies that there's a 2-year gap between the tapeouts of 15 and 7. Are you skipping 10-nanometer? And is there any reason why you're skipping 10-nanometer?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if you look at the sequence, there's 28 and then 20, and 16 came out in rapid succession. And there's actually 2 flavors of 16, those of 16FF and the 16FF+. So we -- after we did the 20, we decided to skip the 16FF and go straight to the FF+ with
componenttext: Okay. So if you look at the sequence, there's 28 and then 20, and 16 came out in rapid succession. And there's actually 2 flavors of 16, those of 16FF and the 16FF+. So we -- after we did the 20, we decided to skip the 16FF and go straight to the FF+ with -- the gap between 7 and 10 at TSMC actually is quite significant in terms of the capabilities of the 2 products. And from our perspective, our customers can only digest technology at a certain cadence. If we bring out technology every 3 months, that's not going to help them. So to some extent, the somewhere between every 2 to 3 years to have a major technology refresh for the businesses we're in is the right cadence. And what we decided to do is to shoot for the best technology, which will be available in that sort of time frame. And because the 7-nanometer fits the bill and it's lower power and denser and actually higher performance, we felt it was better to do that than to split between the 10 and the 7. So that's sort of the thinking. And we're quite confident that this is the right decision in terms of our customer requirements.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Vivek Arya with BofA.
componenttext: The next question is from Vivek Arya with BofA.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Shankar on behalf of Vivek. So I just want to dig into the wireless weakness. So if you go to China Mobile [ph], they've been adding a lot of [indiscernible] flavors. So is the real reason for the weakness is the excess inventory? Or you think cus
componenttext: This is Shankar on behalf of Vivek. So I just want to dig into the wireless weakness. So if you go to China Mobile [ph], they've been adding a lot of [indiscernible] flavors. So is the real reason for the weakness is the excess inventory? Or you think customers are using more ASICs and ASSPs more [indiscernible] than before? And what do you think will turn this around for you in the long run?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answers are different by geography. To that question, it really isn't the same trends or stuff. China, in general, has been stalled out, both the FD standard deployment, which is one of the bigger things that was -- we were counting on for this
componenttext: Well, the answers are different by geography. To that question, it really isn't the same trends or stuff. China, in general, has been stalled out, both the FD standard deployment, which is one of the bigger things that was -- we were counting on for this year to actually begin and be more robust as we move through the year. That was stalled out originally by China Unicom and China Telecoms, the audits that they had relative to ethics and those kinds of things that went on. There's been an overall slowdown of capital spend in China on infrastructure which is more of a macro thing going on relative to the China issue. So I think that's been the biggest driver there. And there absolutely has been a buildup of base station, inventory and our product in the Chinese suppliers that is being led off, as China Mobile continues to deploy at a much lower rate than the previous year. But China Unicom and China Telecom not as much. So if you -- people have told me that if you're in China and you're using one of those handsets from the China Mobile network, there's still a lot of coverage issues and a lot -- so there's lot of things are left to be done there. So I'm not so sure it's driven by the subscriber pool. I think there are some bigger issues going on there. Relative to North America, it's kind of bifurcated into Sprint who is also having some financial issues in terms of funding their networks. So they slowed down the deployment of their network. And they've gone through a rebidding process, and that process has been completed as best as we can tell. And so again, we think that because of those milestones, we think things are going to start to turn around and grow for us in the second half of this year and into calendar 2016. AT&T and Verizon has slowed down their cap spending in the first part of the year. There were Spectrum acquisitions. They also are starting to spend a little more money now, and there are going to be additional capacity utilization of that network. So it really is different by different carriers and geographies. The thought process about what's going to turn this around for us is just exactly the fact that subscriber and coverage is not uniformly sufficient and good in those geographies. And as Moshe said earlier, it's a matter of when, it's not a matter of if for us. And again, we've seen positive press coming out of carriers relative to some improvement in that. We've seen orders come with respect to India, some growth there. So we have some specific orders ahead of us on that. So we are starting to see some positive signs that would lead us to believe that the second half of the fiscal year will be better.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I have one follow-up. So on the data center side, the accelerator opportunity was the prime reason why Intel acquired Altera. Can you talk about how big the market is for you? Is it still an area of focus? And if Intel acquiring Altera, are they so
componenttext: Great. I have one follow-up. So on the data center side, the accelerator opportunity was the prime reason why Intel acquired Altera. Can you talk about how big the market is for you? Is it still an area of focus? And if Intel acquiring Altera, are they somehow going to promote optimized product that can [indiscernible] out of the market? Can you just give us some color around the data center opportunity?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the various elements to the data center and there is elements that focus on storage, elements that focus on networking and elements that focus on compute. So the storage and networking are largely unimpacted by this acquisition. And the compute s
componenttext: Okay. So the various elements to the data center and there is elements that focus on storage, elements that focus on networking and elements that focus on compute. So the storage and networking are largely unimpacted by this acquisition. And the compute space, it's very clear that FPGAs provide a viable, very attractive lower-power solution, which significantly provides an improvement in the performance per watt by -- what we are seeing is somewhere between 20 to 30x on -- in several applications, vis-à-vis stand-alone, high-performance processor. And that's because these applications in the cloud tend to be massively parallel, and these processors are inherently not parallel engines. They're very sequential. That's the way a CPU operates. And even if you have multiple CPU cords, you can achieve only a certain level of parallelism that way. So FPGAs actually can provide tremendous acceleration at the same power form or level of power consumption, just to make sure, or they can provide at a much lower level of power consumption. They can deliver equivalent performance. Now we believe that when Intel consummates its acquisition, when that happens, then there will be some integration opportunities. The challenge there is that you're taking a very high-power solution, which is an x86, and you're adding to it another high-power solution, which is a larger FPGA. And to some extent, if you try to integrate both of those on the same silicon, you're limited with regards to what you can do. So we believe that, that market, the Intel x86 will have an element which will have an integrated solution, and there will have an element which has these distributed solutions where the FPGA will be separate. We see a lot of the traditional data center customers having a strong interest in actually retaining autonomy and independence in that second mode. So they can decide how they design their system, and obviously would be a wonderful solution for them. So even in the Intel x86 space, we believe we have a play. Not to mention that everywhere where it's not Intel, and this is a market which is emerging, right? So there's a lot of competing solutions. It will come to the market over the next few years. We will be the natural shoo-in for that for those solutions. So I would say there is upside for us definitely vis-a-vis beyond where we are today. And we are committed to that market, and we expect to see business growth in that market. And we believe that, that market is in its very early stages of evolution. And over time, we will have a stronger position in it than we definitely have now. So hopefully that answered your question. I apologize if it was more than you wanted to hear or not.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Just as a quick follow-up to the data center question-and-answer that you just provided, which was very useful. How competitive do you said you are relative to Altera now with software and OpenCL, which I believe was the reason for the delay initially in you getting in that end market?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, to be totally honest, we were not -- we did not recognize that market early. Hence, on the software side, we did have a product efficiency. Now based on what customers are telling us, not only are we not behind, but we're actually ahead of the compet
componenttext: Yes, to be totally honest, we were not -- we did not recognize that market early. Hence, on the software side, we did have a product efficiency. Now based on what customers are telling us, not only are we not behind, but we're actually ahead of the competition. So I think we've largely closed that gap, and if anything, it is a competitive advantage for us. We believe that the very deep synthesis technology that we have now delivered as part of our divided product, that gives us a tremendous advantage over any other solution in the market today. And as we product-sized it and we're now starting to broadly deliver it to customers, the feedback we're getting is that we are ahead in terms of technology. So the software is no longer the issue. If anything, it's working in our favor.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. Just wanted to follow up on all of the challenges that have been articulated in the wireless market. Curious if it's changing the way of thinking about providing quarter-to-quarter forecast as well and maybe handicapping
componenttext: Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. Just wanted to follow up on all of the challenges that have been articulated in the wireless market. Curious if it's changing the way of thinking about providing quarter-to-quarter forecast as well and maybe handicapping customer forecast more than normal? And I guess the other question would be how that reflects into the turns rate that's embedded in guidance, given that this was a transition towards distributors or distribution transition as well?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gabriella, it is certainly a challenge in, I will say, any market where we have a very high concentration. And there has -- in this particular situation, it seems to be more of a worldwide trend that's going on. And if you look at other subcontractor comp
componenttext: Gabriella, it is certainly a challenge in, I will say, any market where we have a very high concentration. And there has -- in this particular situation, it seems to be more of a worldwide trend that's going on. And if you look at other subcontractor companies of -- it has the same challenges as we do in this area. I don't think -- because we have such a diversified portfolio beyond just wireless and overall communications, I don't think that's going to cause us to change our -- at least our desire to try to do a forecast and do the best we possibly can. I think we're at a point here of certainly a multiyear historic low for us in terms of our revenue and in this segment, and it is challenging. But I think we'll continue to try to push through and figure this out. Now relative to the turns percentage number that I provided, while it was quite a bit higher on a percentage basis than our actual turns from the previous quarter, I think we've been relatively conservative on the wireless forecast that supports that. We had quite a bit of business booked early in the quarter, the previous quarter. And then moving into this current quarter that we just started, we're back to a more normal booking pattern, and the actual dollars we need in terms on a weekly basis is not that much greater than the actual dollars per week we had in the previous quarter. So I think we're pretty well balanced in to see how things go throughout the quarter.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the color. And maybe just as a follow-up, if I could, on the gross margin profile of the business. Maybe if we think about year-over-year how the gross margin profile of the company has changed, help us understand how much of that is mix
componenttext: I appreciate all the color. And maybe just as a follow-up, if I could, on the gross margin profile of the business. Maybe if we think about year-over-year how the gross margin profile of the company has changed, help us understand how much of that is mix shift, either between end markets from between different product groups? And how much of it is structural initiatives that the company has been taken to improve the longer-term gross margin profile?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so at our Investor Day, we talked about a 68% to 70% range for this year. So if you look at the midpoint, that would be 69%. And we've been running at 70% and 71%. So all the cost reductions that we have -- that we had in that forecast at Investor Da
componenttext: Yes, so at our Investor Day, we talked about a 68% to 70% range for this year. So if you look at the midpoint, that would be 69%. And we've been running at 70% and 71%. So all the cost reductions that we have -- that we had in that forecast at Investor Day that drove the 68% to 70% are on track, and we're doing very well. So I would say if I compare it to our previous forecast, we are on track on all the cost reductions. There is a lot of mix issues going on. We do have a slightly stronger industrial, aerospace and defense profile than we thought at that point in time, and we had a substantially weaker communications business. And that would -- that mix would tend to push our gross margins to this very high elevated point that we are right now. So I think both product and customer mix is accounted for quite a bit. As is, I think in the absence of a more normal -- normalized end market mix that we would have envisioned at the Investor Day, we'll be running in the 68% to 70% range, probably pretty close to the center of that. So I guess the short answer to your question is a lot of it is product mix and end-market customer mix.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

I was just hoping you could talk a little more about industrial within this bucket. For example, what you're seeing with end demand, and then also, your view on inventory today and going forward into the back half of the year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our industrial, as we stated, our industrial was a record quarterly revenue for us, have very strong contribution in North America and in Asia Pac to be very specific on that. We're starting to see growth of the Zynq microprocessor-based FPGA in our
componenttext: Yes. Our industrial, as we stated, our industrial was a record quarterly revenue for us, have very strong contribution in North America and in Asia Pac to be very specific on that. We're starting to see growth of the Zynq microprocessor-based FPGA in our numbers and broadly, new applications and motor-control connected factories, industrial IoT kinds of areas. We're starting to see those designs that we've won over the last couple of years start to accumulate in revenue. So while I know there's been some challenging statements about the industrial market overall, we saw -- we started to see some of the positive things we've been talking about there over the last year or so start to mount up and be more significant within our numbers, in addition to our traditional areas.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question is from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I'm looking at the roadmaps here. It turns out that, by my reckoning, in 2018, you guys are going to be ramping or very early ramping 7-nanometer. And if Altera chooses or if Intel chooses to be the provider of foundry  services for Altera, there w
componenttext: Moshe, I'm looking at the roadmaps here. It turns out that, by my reckoning, in 2018, you guys are going to be ramping or very early ramping 7-nanometer. And if Altera chooses or if Intel chooses to be the provider of foundry  services for Altera, there will be a 10. Was there a competitive reason behind your decision to skip 10-nanometer besides that the cadence aspect of your customer's preference?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not really. That's a great question. We just looked at what the right solution. Everything was available to us and what would be the right solution, and TSMC had their 10. And then we said, "Well, is there anything beyond that?" And they told us that they
componenttext: Not really. That's a great question. We just looked at what the right solution. Everything was available to us and what would be the right solution, and TSMC had their 10. And then we said, "Well, is there anything beyond that?" And they told us that they were working on this future technology. TSMC is very committed to driving technology and capacity leadership. And when we saw what it is, we felt that we would be compelling and just based on that. Now indirectly, we have no idea what Altera and Intel were going to do. And Altera had said that they were looking at TSMC's road map, and I would be surprised if TSMC did not show them the same thing, too, to be honest, right? That would just makes sense for TSMC to show that they have. So it wasn't -- we didn't know what was available at Intel, but we just decided that the right thing for our customer base was to go to the 7-nanometer. And that looks like a very compelling solution in particular as they are committed to delivering it in 2017, and that's when we need it, to be honest.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay, and if I could, a follow-on on the Zynq side. In the automotive models that you're in, are you -- do you know if you're in the front-facing cameras? Was Zynq being used in that kind of an application within a car?
componenttext: Right. Okay, and if I could, a follow-on on the Zynq side. In the automotive models that you're in, are you -- do you know if you're in the front-facing cameras? Was Zynq being used in that kind of an application within a car?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what image processing software -- do you provide that? Or is that a third party?
componenttext: Okay. And what image processing software -- do you provide that? Or is that a third party?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It comes from a variety of sources, some of which are internal to us, some of which come from the customers provide, and in some cases, it's a third party which provides them. So it's a combination of all 3. The -- just to sort of comment on that, what we
componenttext: It comes from a variety of sources, some of which are internal to us, some of which come from the customers provide, and in some cases, it's a third party which provides them. So it's a combination of all 3. The -- just to sort of comment on that, what we're seeing -- and I said this in response to an early question, we're seeing customers look at a canned, non-differentiated ASSPs solution versus a highly differentiated solution using our devices. And for the high end, it's a no-brainer that they want a differentiated solution. And then as you look at the midrange, it's less clear and definitely at the low-end times. They just are prepared to have a meat-and-potato solution as opposed to something which is more specialized. But interestingly, because this has become a platform play, then we are starting to see design wins where the customers are committing their entire product offering to our platform. And as a result, they're pushing us hard to provide them with a lower end, and we typically would have provided a solution for that. And so that's a growth opportunity for us, and it's driven by this broad platform-oriented approach where the companies are sort of saying, "We can't afford to have different solutions," and because we want to have differentiation, they go with us across the board. And that's another reason that I believe that our market share, which we're happy with the revenue at this point, but our market share is not high yet. We believe that there is an opportunity to grow it going forward.

componenttext:
Great. Thanks for joining us today. We have a playback of this call beginning at 5 p.m Pacific time, 8 p.m. Eastern Time today. For a copy of our earnings release, please visit our IR website. 
This quarter, we will be presenting at the Pacific Coast -- Pacific Crest Global Technology Forum in Vail on August 10 and the 2015 Citi Global Technology Conference in New York City on September 9. 
This completes our call. Thank you very much for your participation.

Thank you, Mr. Muscha, you may begin your conference.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the September quarter, and then open the call for questions. Let me remind everyone that during our conference call tod
componenttext: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the September quarter, and then open the call for questions. Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially to our projections or forward-looking statements. This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx's Investor Relations website. Let me now turn the call over to John.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Xilinx's sales were $528 million, down 4% sequentially and within our guidance. We experienced strong new product growth and strong profitability during the quarter, as well as a modest recovery in communications. New product sales increa
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Xilinx's sales were $528 million, down 4% sequentially and within our guidance. We experienced strong new product growth and strong profitability during the quarter, as well as a modest recovery in communications. New product sales increased 11% in the quarter with increases from 7- series, Smart and product families and our 20-nanometer UltraScale family, which exceeded $15 million in quarterly sales. Zynq adoption continues to be strong across a broad base of end markets including automotive, wireless, industrial and consumer applications. From an end market perspective, sales from communications and data center increased 5% driven by a modest recovery in Asia and North America. Wired communications sales were driven by data center access and enterprise applications. For the second quarter in a row, wired communications represented the largest contributor of our 28-nanometer sales. The industrial and aerospace and defense segment declined 12% sequentially with expected decreases from defense. The combination of industrial scientific and medical test and measurement declined sequentially was somewhat weaker than anticipated ISM business towards of the end of the quarter. 
Lastly, the broadcast consumer and automotive category was down slightly driven primarily by decreases in broadcast. 
Gross margin was 70.1% for the quarter, at the high end of our guidance driven primarily by customer mix. Operating expenses, including $2 million of amortization expense, were $217 million, in line with expectations. Other income was a net expense of $9 million. Net income for the quarter was $127 million or $0.48 per diluted share. Operating cash flow for the September quarter was $137 million before $5 million in CapEx. Cash flow for the quarter was impacted by higher receivables primarily associated with the timing of end-of-the-quarter shipments to our primary distributor partner who had an extra fiscal week during the quarter. Diluted shares for the quarter were 266 million shares. There was a $6.5 million share dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions relating to the dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.Xilinx.com. We repurchased 2.4 million shares for $100 million during the quarter, and paid $80 million in dividends. As a result, we returned over 130% of operating cash flow to the shareholders during the quarter, putting us well on track to continue to return over 100% of operating cash flow to shareholders in fiscal year '16. 
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments were $3.5 billion [ph] . We had $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt resulting in a cash -- net cash position of approximately $1.9 billion. Inventory dollars at Xilinx decreased by $9 million sequentially. 
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the December quarter of fiscal year '16. The guidance I provide will be inclusive of the extra fiscal week in our quarter, which we disclosed in our 10-K filing, as well as in today's earnings release. Our backlog heading into the December quarter is up sequentially, both wired and wireless communications are forecasted to be up. We believe our key wireless customers have reduced levels of inventory and as a result, we expect continued improvement from China driven by FT LTE deployment activity. Wired communications continues to be impacted by weak CapEx environment, but we are expecting growth during the quarter from OTN and cable infrastructure businesses. We expect our industrial and aerospace and defense segment to be up sequentially driven by a return to growth in our space and defense. 
Lastly, we expect all components to the broadcast consumer and automotive category to be approximately flat. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be up 3% to 7% sequentially. In the midpoint of this guidance is predicated on rate of approximately 48%. Gross margin is expected to be approximately 69%. Operating expenses for the December quarter are expected to be approximately $230 million, including $2 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. Other income and expense for the December quarter will be a net expense of $7 million. The share count is expected to be approximately 265 million shares. There will be an adjustment to our full year forecast on CapEx. We are raising our forecast to approximately $40 million for the year, up from previous guidance of $25 million as a result of building renovations on our San Jose campus. The tax rate for the December quarter is expected to be 12%. Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good afternoon. Despite the anticipated challenges in the September quarter revenue, I'm pleased that Xilinx continue to deliver strong profitability. Gross margin was 70.1%, facilitating operating margin of [ph] 29%. This is a testam
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good afternoon. Despite the anticipated challenges in the September quarter revenue, I'm pleased that Xilinx continue to deliver strong profitability. Gross margin was 70.1%, facilitating operating margin of [ph] 29%. This is a testament to the strength of our business model , the diversity of the markets we serve, the impact of several corporate initiatives focusing on productivity improvement. 
Revenue from our new product category, which delivered a robust 11% sequential increase is expected to further accelerate in the December quarter. This gives us growing confidence in the September quarter represents bottom of the current cycle for Xilinx. As forecasted, last quarter 28-nanometer revenue growth was driven largely by increases in wired communications, industrial applications and defense. A special mention is due to our Zynq product, the industry's first programmable SOC, which increased sequentially by nearly 40% repeating a similar increase in the June quarter. Our overall 28-nanometer revenue is expected to grow significantly in the December quarter, sale driven by the majority of our end markets. These include communication, industrial, automotive, defense and test and measurement. 20-nanometer revenue in the September quarter comfortably exceeded a $15 million forecast. Majority of the growth continue to be driven by Virtex UltraScale, the industry's only ASIC class, 20-nanometer high-end product offering. In the December quarter, we're expecting 20-nanometer sales to again post strong growth and exceed $20 million led by wired communication and test and measurement applications. The 16-nanometer node we shipped, the industry's first all-programmable MPSoC. This product is already -- has been already delivered to customers. This is a quarter ahead of schedule, highlighting the third consecutive generation of product leadership enabled by stellar execution by a foundry partner at TSMC in conjunction with our engineering and operations teams. This exciting new family targets applications in embedded vision, including ADAS, Industrial Internet of Things, 5G wireless systems and will facilitate Xilinx's expansion into the domain of ASSPs. 
Finally, last week, we announced the strategic partnership with QUALCOMM to deliver interests -- industry-leading, heterogeneous computing solutions. These solutions will deliver new levels of efficiency and performance through FPGA-enabled dynamic workload acceleration on QUALCOMM's on-based platforms. As I mentioned at the beginning of my comments, top line 3% to 7% sales growth expected in the December quarter is again being driven from our new product category. This is forecasted to deliver another healthy double-digit percentage increase comprised by both our 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer leadership portfolios. We'll now turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015

componenttextpreview: This is Jon.  I don't know now about being overly optimistic or not, but because the way this is a holiday end of the year kind of thing and what the weeks work out, there would definitely kind of pounds of towards more of the holiday, which are typically
componenttext: This is Jon.  I don't know now about being overly optimistic or not, but because the way this is a holiday end of the year kind of thing and what the weeks work out, there would definitely kind of pounds of towards more of the holiday, which are typically not good production time period. So I mean the end of our quarter ends up being, I think, January 2 or something like that. So I mean we're now overlapping both Christmas and the New Year's time. So I don't think -- thinking about it from a 7% or as necessarily. The right way, however, there's obviously some more shipping days in the quarter as a result of it. And of course, we get a full weeks of expense no matter what.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then maybe I can just tackle the cyclical commentary. I think you were a pretty explicit that you feel September, Moshe, I think you said September marks the bottom in the cycle for Xilinx. Perhaps you can help us with the strength by end
componenttext: Understood. And then maybe I can just tackle the cyclical commentary. I think you were a pretty explicit that you feel September, Moshe, I think you said September marks the bottom in the cycle for Xilinx. Perhaps you can help us with the strength by end market when we look out to see what the next cycle -- what the upcoming -- what's the upturn should bring? Would you anticipate that the common infrastructure end market would be the greatest driver of that and are you seeing -- I missed whether you said you're seeing signs of life in wireless infrastructure in China, whether that's sort of -- whether those -- that spending has started to come back?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if you look at it market by market, it's -- there is some recovery in communications, not necessarily some huge snapback, in particular, node on wireless. So this does not assume there's a tremendous improvement in wireless. We are seeing improve
componenttext: Okay. So if you look at it market by market, it's -- there is some recovery in communications, not necessarily some huge snapback, in particular, node on wireless. So this does not assume there's a tremendous improvement in wireless. We are seeing improvement in wireless, it has come off the trough. The trough, I believe, was in the quarter before last, and it is improving slowly from that but there's no huge rebound. We're seeing a strength in wired communications is growing nicely and some of the other markets are growing at a nice level are driving this. It tends to be a little broad, if Jon, you want to share your specifics?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I thinks if you look at our new product growth rate of 11% and an expectation that we're going to have a nice growth in this next quarter as well on new products, I think what we're seeing is bouncing off the bottom. We're seeing some of the desig
componenttext: Yes, so I thinks if you look at our new product growth rate of 11% and an expectation that we're going to have a nice growth in this next quarter as well on new products, I think what we're seeing is bouncing off the bottom. We're seeing some of the designs that we've really started to grow pretty significantly in wired and across automotive and industrial, and we look at our Zynq product family starting to grow very significantly now, and that's a good sign. And the tier drag that we had going for us through the earlier part of this our calendar year was our aerospace and defense business declining from the standpoint of the joint strike fighter program, final shipments being done so that is essentially aerospace and defense essentially hitting bottom for us in this past quarter. And then the fact that inventory to be led off in China, and particularly and we believe our customers have reduced inventory levels of FPGAs that they had in their stores,and we're starting to see some signs of ordering and some more incremental deployments as Moshe said but not a joint snapback. So those are some of the factors that, I think, are -- contributed to our view in our confidence level that we're going to start moving back up now from the bottom. Next question, please.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, this is Gabriella Borges on behalf of Jen. Maybe just a follow-up on the earlier comments on inventory levels and the supply chain. I think it shows us any metric specifically on inventory at wireless OEM customers, and then to the extent you could
componenttext: Great, this is Gabriella Borges on behalf of Jen. Maybe just a follow-up on the earlier comments on inventory levels and the supply chain. I think it shows us any metric specifically on inventory at wireless OEM customers, and then to the extent you could talk about a return that's more broadly across end markets and whether its levels are to normal levels, that would be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think just as a general comments, inventories across most of our end markets are pretty lean and including in distribution despite the fact that we had a buildup in distribution right at the end of quarter, but then again, that was timing from when quar
componenttext: I think just as a general comments, inventories across most of our end markets are pretty lean and including in distribution despite the fact that we had a buildup in distribution right at the end of quarter, but then again, that was timing from when quarter ended because we add the 14 weeks last quarter which was after our -- a week after our quarter end. So there was some buildup there but that really isn't a sign of any sort of a long-term business situation, so I think in distribution we we're in pretty good shape. With respect to the specifically to wireless, it's always difficult to know the true story about what the status is because, I think, we've -- as we recall, we talked about this before, there are base stations that our customers have on loan to their carriers , there are base stations that there inventory completed, and then there were situations where we know FPGAs were built up in their factories. And what we can see the most, obviously, is the FPGA inventory, and that's where we feel we worked that down at major customers and the should be more of a demand pull of kind of a situation now on a go-forward basis, that's our view on that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next mission is from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next mission is from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk about the wireless infrastructure side, just conceptually as you look forward, I think you -- you said that it was down about 50% year-over-year a couple of quarters ago. If you think about where it could go in the future,
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk about the wireless infrastructure side, just conceptually as you look forward, I think you -- you said that it was down about 50% year-over-year a couple of quarters ago. If you think about where it could go in the future, do you think if that business for you could exceed the prior peaks or are there are some things that would limit it from ever reaching those peaks? Just conceptually trying to think if we're at the bottom, what does the next top look like and where does that compared to the prior?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you look at wireless, it's -- now there's various elements and there's 4G deployment and the major surge would be 5G deployment, which we are already designed into a lot of the prototypes, which will be demonstrated in the next 2 years, but the real
componenttext: So if you look at wireless, it's -- now there's various elements and there's 4G deployment and the major surge would be 5G deployment, which we are already designed into a lot of the prototypes, which will be demonstrated in the next 2 years, but the reality there's long time before, there is the massive growth in 5G. So now if you're looking for the short term , we do expect for it to grow. It's unlikely in the short term to get to the previous peak. That peak was driven by surge in China. What we're seeing now is deployment in India but that is viewed as a much smaller market. And then other markets are deploying at the low rate. So I don't see as returning to that previous peak, which I believe was in the March 2014 quarter anytime soon. I do expect us to see recovery from the trough, but the previous peak is going to take time and it will probably require a combination of elements to return to that level.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll just point out that previous peak that Moshe referred to was an artificial peak in retrospect meaning there's a lot of inventory builds being built up by our customers will also they're going to get a higher share. It was earlier in the China LTE and
componenttext: I'll just point out that previous peak that Moshe referred to was an artificial peak in retrospect meaning there's a lot of inventory builds being built up by our customers will also they're going to get a higher share. It was earlier in the China LTE and I think we've got a lot of -- we had many customers thinking very good to get a bigger share out of that. And so in retrospect, that's why I called it the artificial peak.
