componenttext: Yes. So we provided full year guidance for R&D and SG&A and we do still expect to be in that range and maybe SG&A a little bit towards the bottom end of that range quite frankly, but still a couple of puts and takes going on that, but we're very comfortable with the previous range. We can give those numbers if you need them. It's -- we have.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I have them, so yes, that's great. And then maybe for Moshe. You put out a couple of days ago on the QUALCOMM partnership. I guess one of the reasons that Intel has been talking about for acquiring I guess they want to integrate FPGA into the S86
componenttext: I think I have them, so yes, that's great. And then maybe for Moshe. You put out a couple of days ago on the QUALCOMM partnership. I guess one of the reasons that Intel has been talking about for acquiring I guess they want to integrate FPGA into the S86 die. I'm just curious if this partnership with QUALCOMM is firstly, is that exclusive to QUALCOMM? And then, I think you also mentioned that down the road, you plan to offer integrated solutions. Does that mean that QUALCOMM would be offering fully integrated single-die solutions with Xilinx FPGAs on it.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let me first answer with regards to QUALCOMM. So we will have a range of solutions, which could work on with QUALCOMM, start from cards, and then move to a higher level of integration. We haven't defined what those high levels of integration -- w
componenttext: Okay. So let me first answer with regards to QUALCOMM. So we will have a range of solutions, which could work on with QUALCOMM, start from cards, and then move to a higher level of integration. We haven't defined what those high levels of integration -- what those high levels of integration are, but we are working closely with them and this is a program that started 2 years ago and what we -- what was shown at the rollout was that the first server that they were providing to their software developers and to their customers as a development platform, and there was in parallel a board which had our device on it which connected with that and provided the 10 to 50x acceleration for certain sets of applications. And so that's exactly the situation there. We have a very tight relationship with QUALCOMM, it's not an exclusive relationship. One of the opportunities we have is we believe that the data center market is an emerging market. There are 3 elements to it , there's a networking part, there's a storage part and there's a acceleration part, which is the one which is getting the most press but isn't the only one. So the first 2 are, obviously, we're in a good position there. With regards to the third, what we're seeing is there's a lot of competitive architectures, X86 and others, which are pursuing that market at this point in time. Clearly, Intel has the highest market share, but it is expected to have more than one set of solutions that is driven by the customers who are very large independent companies and their desire to control their own destiny. So we do believe that, that will, over time, provide a interesting growth opportunity for us, and we have a strategy that enables us to participate at different levels of integration with the all of the players in that market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And when do you expect production revenues from this partnership, Moshe?
componenttext: That's great. And when do you expect production revenues from this partnership, Moshe?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, with the QUALCOMM, I can't tell you without disclosing when they're going to ship the product, hence, I am precluded from answering that. But other partners are in different stages of deployment. A few are a little further ahead, a few are further b
componenttext: Well, with the QUALCOMM, I can't tell you without disclosing when they're going to ship the product, hence, I am precluded from answering that. But other partners are in different stages of deployment. A few are a little further ahead, a few are further behind. And so over time, we do expect this to be a significant growth opportunity for us but this is not measured in months, this is couple of years out, the earliest before it starts becoming visible.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Chris Danely from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question is from Chris Danely from Citigroup.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one question on the market. So when you look at a spending patterns from the China carriers, it looks like it's a pretty strong the second half of this year. So how much of are you guys seeing? And then conversely, getting into next calendar year, it
componenttext: Just one question on the market. So when you look at a spending patterns from the China carriers, it looks like it's a pretty strong the second half of this year. So how much of are you guys seeing? And then conversely, getting into next calendar year, it looks like spending is down. So any thoughts you have on the market for next year would be appreciated as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, on the spending patterns out of China and is generally Asia, as we have been communicating here, we do see positive signs, but we don't really see -- we see the positioning that there could be brisker growth out there in the next 2 quarters for us,
componenttext: Chris, on the spending patterns out of China and is generally Asia, as we have been communicating here, we do see positive signs, but we don't really see -- we see the positioning that there could be brisker growth out there in the next 2 quarters for us, the rest of our fiscal year. But our customers are certainly not committing to that level at this point in time. So it's one of those situations again where you don't know there's a false signal that they're saying, hey, it could be bigger than this, it may not be bigger than this. So we put a number in, and we think is more of a center of likelihood there. And then relative to next years, it's very difficult to forecast for the whole year on the wireless segment. But I don't think we're looking at it based on how poor this year is, I don't think we're looking at it as a down year for us next year. That's about all I'll say on that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Gilmore from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question is from Gilmore from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: If we go back to the server acceleration business , can you talk about how big you think that opportunity ultimately can be? talked about it as $1 billion type of long-term opportunity and how focal point of the transaction. Do you agree that it could be
componenttext: If we go back to the server acceleration business , can you talk about how big you think that opportunity ultimately can be? talked about it as $1 billion type of long-term opportunity and how focal point of the transaction. Do you agree that it could be that big? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's an emerging market and it's a little too early to figure out how it will turn out, but it is clearly in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Could it be $1 billion, yes, it could be $1 billion but I think it's premature to sort of count on it b
componenttext: Well, it's an emerging market and it's a little too early to figure out how it will turn out, but it is clearly in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Could it be $1 billion, yes, it could be $1 billion but I think it's premature to sort of count on it being that big because it is an emerging market, and we expect it to be a very bifurcated market. Again, it's sort of important to look at the end customers and these are the big data center companies in North America, and then there's the big data center companies in China. Each of them has an ecosystem and in software environments that they totally control. And they tend to have an application, which their applications are different, and they tend to do it on their own way. So we do expect it to come out with a vast periphery of solutions, and we believe we'll be in a good position to provide that as opposed to dictate small number of solutions, which we believe will be competitive approach.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then following up on that, to the extent that you've talked about other architectures other than x86 in that market. Can you talk about your approach within X86? You sort of assume that the lion share of servers is going to remain an x86?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then following up on that, to the extent that you've talked about other architectures other than x86 in that market. Can you talk about your approach within X86? You sort of assume that the lion share of servers is going to remain an x86? What's your ability to compete how important is it that you're not in the co-package depart with the processor, how do you compete external to that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest challenge to integration is power. And if you look at this market, it tends to use a pretty high-performance processor and a relatively large FPGA. You need those in order to get the acceleration. If you look at those, those tend to be r
componenttext: Well, the biggest challenge to integration is power. And if you look at this market, it tends to use a pretty high-performance processor and a relatively large FPGA. You need those in order to get the acceleration. If you look at those, those tend to be relatively power-hungry devices. So there's a limit to what you can do by integrating them into 1 package. And so even if it's just interfacing to an Intel device, we believe that we will be able to provide a companion device which will enable the differentiated solution for several of the players in that market. So we do expect to play in that market too and definitely in any non-Intel market, we expect to be -- to have a very strong position with regards to servicing the requirements. It's the primary provider of FPGA solutions and the largest provider of FPGA solutions in the market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from David Long from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question is from David Long from Wells Fargo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you tell us a bit more about your plans for 16-nanometer? So you've got your first product, would that be a rollout of near future or will be this be spread of time?
componenttext: Can you tell us a bit more about your plans for 16-nanometer? So you've got your first product, would that be a rollout of near future or will be this be spread of time?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so we what's typically happens is we've rolled out the first device, then it got to link the evaluation phase. And as soon as we get to clear understanding of the level of functionality, we then do a rapid rollout of the follow-on devices. The functio
componenttext: And so we what's typically happens is we've rolled out the first device, then it got to link the evaluation phase. And as soon as we get to clear understanding of the level of functionality, we then do a rapid rollout of the follow-on devices. The function of this initial device has exceeded all expectations. We got it back faster and it operates much, much better and hence, we already shifted to customers just to sort of demonstrate the level of functionality. So I would expect the rollout of the next devices to be as fast as we can. We do need to complete the evaluation of the first device that takes significant amount of time. Typically, this process takes about a 1 year to 1.5 years from the first device until you have most of the family rolled out. And given the success in the fast turnaround we got from TSMC and the functionality both on the manufacturing aside, from the engineering side, we should do better than we have in any previous generation, and it is a very broad and deep product offering. It has very high-performance processor subsystem with significant number of embedded, dedicated accelerators and combination of those will enable us to take it and compete over time against aces piece in more and more markets. So it is -- we think this is a watershed moment for us in terms of the rollout.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question is from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question on one of the submarkets. You said that ISM was weaker-than-expected, especially at the end of the quarter? Perhaps what's driving that end is that continue into this quarter for some period?
componenttext: Question on one of the submarkets. You said that ISM was weaker-than-expected, especially at the end of the quarter? Perhaps what's driving that end is that continue into this quarter for some period?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. at this point in time, we don't think it's necessarily a bellwether to it, to any sort of a cycle, it just was, I'd say, consistent with maybe what we've seen in there's some of their components companies out a little softness in that market for a sh
componenttext: Yes. at this point in time, we don't think it's necessarily a bellwether to it, to any sort of a cycle, it just was, I'd say, consistent with maybe what we've seen in there's some of their components companies out a little softness in that market for a short time period. So it's a matter of returns profile. We still -- we are expecting continued strength on our new products in that particular area. Some of the older designs just for taking a pause, probably some inventory adjustments there with but the new products continue to be strong in that particular end market. So I think it was more -- it's just more of situation for, I think, by the end of the quarter than it is any sort of a forecast for the future.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yen, if I could just add color. It's a market that develops very, very slowly. And as a result, to the extent that there was a downturn, it was the older technologies, right? But what we have seen and this was driven by Zynq , is in 28-nanometer. We actua
componenttext: Yen, if I could just add color. It's a market that develops very, very slowly. And as a result, to the extent that there was a downturn, it was the older technologies, right? But what we have seen and this was driven by Zynq , is in 28-nanometer. We actually saw significant and vibrant growth. So and this is an expansion play for us because the Zynq product offering is different from anything we've had in the past. So we are now seeing that enable us to grow into new areas. And so we fully expect ISM , even if there are pullbacks from time to time, we expected to see that to be one of our more promising growth markets going forward, it's Zynq, and it's the MPSoC, given the nature of the design wins, some of those design wins even on 28-nanometer, 5 or 7 years old, and it just now starting to hit and become visible on the Zynq side, and that will grow to be a bigger part of our business going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, and then longer-term question here. I mean, how much manufacturing cross improvements is left I see you have now the second highest gross margins in all of semiconductors. I mean, do you eventually become like a linear, which is very high-margin bu
componenttext: Moshe, and then longer-term question here. I mean, how much manufacturing cross improvements is left I see you have now the second highest gross margins in all of semiconductors. I mean, do you eventually become like a linear, which is very high-margin but low growth? Or are you getting some cost improvements as you migrate said 20-nanometers and 16-nanometers, et cetera?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is a never-ending process and it's -- I've often heard the term that we have reached saturation in terms of our capability to improve interest in terms of density cost, et cetera. And as soon as I hear that, we set a new bar and surprisingly, we h
componenttext: So this is a never-ending process and it's -- I've often heard the term that we have reached saturation in terms of our capability to improve interest in terms of density cost, et cetera. And as soon as I hear that, we set a new bar and surprisingly, we hit the new saturation points. So I think the opportunity for improvement, while not trivial, is very significant, and we continue to do that on numerous fronts, and it requires a lot of engineering effort, both in-house, and together with our foundry partners. But I don't think you should sort of assume this is as good as it gets. Now with regards to moving to future nodes, the good news is that we are reaching the old historic so-called saturation densities within your notes, faster than we reached them with old nodes even though new nodes have significantly more complex and have more manufacturing layer. So I think, in particular, if you look at the some their ability to continue to improve and the volumes they run are very helpful to help us improve on those fronts, and we continue to push to achieve those regardless of the node, both on old node and new node, and it's something that we need to do. So the strategy is both to continue to improve in that regard, but also to provide markets growth center market growth comes through expanded product capability. And that's sort of I will admit that over the past few years, I have 2 years of not delivering that, but we are intent on delivering that going forward, for sure much better than we have in the past 2 years.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll just add 1 comment on. If there was a question behind your question around are we sacrificing growth to protect margins, and no, that's not what you're doing in this. We have here the situation where we have customer and end market mix, that's pretty
componenttext: I'll just add 1 comment on. If there was a question behind your question around are we sacrificing growth to protect margins, and no, that's not what you're doing in this. We have here the situation where we have customer and end market mix, that's pretty favorable for us. So we're at the high end of our 68% to 70% stated model for the current period in situation and there are -- we aren't tied by accepting deals that lower than that margin if we need to. We set a portfolio and a balance and we drive cost-reduction where we think volume is going to be, and we put more focus on that and I think, you're just seeing a disciplined efficient situation that we put in place here in the company and 110% agree with all that Moshe just said.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So with regards to data center and the acceleration, that subset of applications, as we're going through cloudification or whatever the appropriate word is and that's a major growth element. A significant portion of the CPUs that are being deployed
componenttext: Okay. So with regards to data center and the acceleration, that subset of applications, as we're going through cloudification or whatever the appropriate word is and that's a major growth element. A significant portion of the CPUs that are being deployed are now being deployed in these large data centers and the typical usage is very different from what the general purpose server did. As they build up these big data centers, in particular, when you look at the massive payers in that market, they tend to have very specific applications, and those applications tend to be massively parallel. So if you think of things like search, et cetera, you can see how =you could benefit from massively parallel solutions. And what sort of happens is, for better or for worse, if you go to just making the CPU faster, the return there is not significant and if you just go to multi-core CPU, there's a limit to what you can achieve there again without blowing the power and water or out of the data center. And so what has happened is the biggest limiter is power and the performance per power configuration that you get from an FPGA or programmable solution is superior for both of these applications and the factor that we have seen consistently is anywhere from 10 to 50, and it depends on what application and exactly -- and it can change even between in the same company as they shift things around. So there is, if you believe -- if you look at that, then that implies that the traditional ability to address the customer's requirements through selling them faster CPUs or more parallel CPUs is limited. Hence, the desire to have a programmable solution and combination is very beneficial for what is becoming a very large part the -- what used to be a traditional server market. And that's best we can tell, that's what the customers are telling us, that's why they're excited about. We do believe that the Intel acquisition of Altera was driven by a desire to control that and to make sure that the rollout is driven and not, in any way, compromised by the CPU power requirements and hence, the rationale for doing it and these same consumers tend to have a very independence desire to that show their destiny, which probably opens up opportunities for other non-x86 architectures for other players if there is a competitive x86 solution at the right point in time together with FPGAs. Now that may be more than you asked, but that's a comprehensive answer.

I think, in line answers or to one of the questions is really the drivers there, along with some wired business going on. Moshe talked about 5G prototyping, obviously, the Chinese manufacturers are involved in that as well and as well as the other Asian manufacturers as well. So we've been participating in all that. So we've seen really good new products and new development product, as well as some of the legacy LTE design that we've won become stronger. I would say industrial was solid or okay in for us in Asia as well, but not not knocking at other part. The North America phenomenon for us was more of the aerospace and defense declining. The design was really driven mostly by the tail end of shipping in the joint strike fighter and the rest of our business is there were good in fact the large business was even up a little bit in North America as well. headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very helpful, thank you. Just as a follow-up, you just mentioned India and Moshe mentioned it earlier, I think it was mentioned on the last call as well. Moshe, this time around, you said that it was a smaller market. Obviously, from a population standpoi
componenttext: Very helpful, thank you. Just as a follow-up, you just mentioned India and Moshe mentioned it earlier, I think it was mentioned on the last call as well. Moshe, this time around, you said that it was a smaller market. Obviously, from a population standpoint , they're just slightly behind China there. But how do we think about it here? I we think about India as the fewer base stations or fewer FPGA content per base station when compared to, let's say, a Chinese base stations? What are the moving parts here and why is it is so significantly smaller?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So sadly, it is smaller because we believe that -- if you look at the Chinese approach, they invest heavily in infrastructure and they did it on a broad level and they do it quickly and they try to make sure, may be not the same level you've seen in
componenttext: Okay. So sadly, it is smaller because we believe that -- if you look at the Chinese approach, they invest heavily in infrastructure and they did it on a broad level and they do it quickly and they try to make sure, may be not the same level you've seen in the, that there is good coverage. India, culturally, it's sort of incredibly cost-focused and the challenge that exists today in India is even though there's over 1 billion people there, and it's definitely a large country , the problem is that there are a lot of carriers, probably far too many, and I think, very few, if any of them, are making any money. So the approach is to do the minimum, right? And as a result, the deployments are likely to be in aggregate, quite a bit smaller than what has been done in China, and that's -- it is what it is. Maybe over time it will improve. But you go there, it is a still a very poor country with a still small middle class. And if you go to China, you can see the infrastructure, there's phenomenal in the middle class there, it's much larger. And so I believe that, that's the major driver for to difference between those 2 deployments.

So where we have more content at a given manufacturer, then we'll win the business in India then we'll participate. But there's nothing about the structural content of an Indian base station that's really different than any of the other rest of the world.

Or do you look at what's going on in the states and look at M&A and saying maybe we can think box have growth and do something unconventional, i.e., sort of being you turn out they say maybe there are some synergies that we can go out of the so just one of your thoughts on that? headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just at the high level on automotive business for this fiscal year, we're expecting a 30% year-on-year so full year FY -- fiscal year '16 versus full year fiscal '15, we're expecting 30% growth on our automotive business, and that's based on product persp
componenttext: Just at the high level on automotive business for this fiscal year, we're expecting a 30% year-on-year so full year FY -- fiscal year '16 versus full year fiscal '15, we're expecting 30% growth on our automotive business, and that's based on product perspective, it's based on our penetration of Zynq into a variety of applications led by the advanced driver assistance capability. Where we compete with Mobiline -- by the way, we do have other design wins that are immobilized oriented, they could be in radar distance center is things like that various different FPGAs in that, but relative to the direct competition with mobile, it's around forward-looking cameras. And so, again, our business is broader than forward-looking cameras but that's where we do with the head-on with Mobileye. Our strength that's been in the do will our stereo cameras were there to comers looking forward versus 1 mono-camera that's where we've got our original, and we're very confident about our ability to compete with Mobileye across a broad set of platforms. Some of our customers actually believe they are competitors to Mobileye because tyr during the full solution in trying to win the designs at a variety of platforms at various automobile manufacturers. So we sit here today looking about this year's growth over last year and next year's growth and the year after, we can articulate to ourselves pretty much every platform that we won in this regard, and can see the kind of growth level that is potentially ahead of us, again, continuing this double-digit growth on a go-forward basis because we know we won these designs and in the designs are very sticky for multiple car year model. So with that, I'll hand over the rest of it to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll try and respond to you over very big question because otherwise we won't get home for dinner tonight. But my perspective, and this is no longer in dispute, is that the semiconductor world is going through a significant number of change, and it's
componenttext: And I'll try and respond to you over very big question because otherwise we won't get home for dinner tonight. But my perspective, and this is no longer in dispute, is that the semiconductor world is going through a significant number of change, and it's going through economic and as a result, it's actually less and less players. I think, that, that is no longer a of contention. You just need to count and see how much smaller it is. It's definitely smaller. There's fewer and fewer to the point of almost none getting refreshed through the venture world. And the cost of moving forward from generation to generation is actually going up and there is fewer and fewer players who can do that. So if you step back and look at that trend, that clearly is an opportunity for companies who can move forward, and we are one of those companies, that's why we were first at 28 with TSMC, first with 20 with TSMC as a semiconductor player, and that's why we got the 16 out way ahead of the competition. The reason that we do that is not just for bragging rights, it's actually because once we have that leadership , we can expand markets that we address. If you look at what has happened to Xilinx over the past 10 years, the role of devices play and generally, the role FPGA devices play in the customers systems is changing and as a result, I will -- can see that the historic logic FPGA market is not growing. But what is happening, and you could argue that, that is reason not to invest, but what is growing is the TAM in terms of your markets we're addressing. If you sort of looked in our business you can see that even though this is not happening quite the rate we had hoped, we are displacing ASSPs. So if you look at the Zynq product offering that required new investment, big investment, but it's now starting to pay off. These past 2 quarters both grew by around 40% and this is just the beginning. And that enables us to play and -- in markets we have not played before. So that's the strategy we have. We believe that yes, the results are not there in terms of the overall numbers, but if you look at the change in the markets and the competition, then actually there is an opportunity and in order to do that, we are continuing to develop and be at the leading-edge. Having said that, we can still do it and deliver profitability, which was sort of in a higher echelon. So our strategy is to continue doing that because we believe that the opportunity is there, the markets are developing and unfolding, and it's just to take 1 example automotive was market, which is very, very low single-digit percent for us and now we expect for that to grow over the next few years. Industrial control, again, and others slow cadence market where we can displace a lot of solutions where in the past the consumers would go to Freescale and MTI, et cetera, into a large extent a lot of those historic players are no longer around. So that's the strategy we have and part of that strategy requires us to continue to provide leadership. Also -- it also requires us to invest heavily in tools so that our customers can exploit the opportunity that our silicon provides them, and that's an ongoing element and that's the strategy at this point in time. The challenge on the M&A side is that there's very few companies out there that we can buy that fit into our business model and actually augment our offering and hence, you're right in pointing out that we haven't done much there, but I do believe the investments we're making, while continuing to deliver best-in-class profitability will, over time, enable us to continue to grow.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Harlan, thanks for the question. So it has been very successful. There's tiers of products that we are providing. There's high level synthesis, which is something that we have had for close to 5 years and there's of the FDX families products that go
componenttext: Okay. Harlan, thanks for the question. So it has been very successful. There's tiers of products that we are providing. There's high level synthesis, which is something that we have had for close to 5 years and there's of the FDX families products that going out. They have xDSL, I believe, has thousands of users at this point in time. The SOC is starting to be used broadly. It's a big enabler to grow the population of users beyond the hard-core -- hardware FUD designer. So it is essential and technology is doing well and the market deployment is doing well. The reason that the financial implications aren't yet visible, in a big way, is that the initial targets for those markets were industrial control and automotive, and those 2 markets move at a slower cadence. With a new generation graduate expanding the number of markets we're addressing, and we expect to see increased adoption of them. So it is essential and it is something we need to do in order to displace ASSPs and to address the biggest TAM. So far in terms of technology and deployment, it's going according to plan.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the September quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.Let me remind everyone that during our conference c
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. With me are Moshe Gavrielov, CEO; and Jon Olson, CFO. We will provide a financial and business review of the September quarter, and then we'll open the call for questions.
Let me remind everyone that during our conference call today, we may make projections or other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions based on information that is currently available and that actual results may differ materially. We refer you to the documents the company files with the SEC, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and 8-Ks. These documents contain and identify important risk factors that could cause the actual results to differ materially from those contained in our projections or forward-looking statements.
This conference call is open to all and is being webcast live. It can be accessed from our Xilinx's Investor Relations website.
Let me now turn the call over to Jon.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rick. Xilinx' sales were $528 million, down 4% sequentially and within our guidance. We experienced strong new product growth and strong profitability during the quarter as well as a modest recovery in communications. New product sales increase
componenttext:
Thank you, Rick. Xilinx' sales were $528 million, down 4% sequentially and within our guidance. We experienced strong new product growth and strong profitability during the quarter as well as a modest recovery in communications. New product sales increased 11% in the quarter with increases from our 7 Series, Spartan-6 product families and our 20-nanometer UltraScale family, which exceeded $15 million in quarterly sales. Zynq adoption continues to be strong across a broad base of end markets including automotive, wireless, industrial and consumer applications.
From an end market perspective, sales from Communications & Data Center increased 5%, driven by a modest recovery in Asia and North America. Wired communications sales were driven by data center access and enterprise applications. For the second quarter in a row, wired communications represented the largest contributor of our 28-nanometer sales. The Industrial, Aerospace & Defense segment declined 12% sequentially with expected decreases from defense. The combination of industrial, scientific and medical test and measurement decline sequentially with somewhat weaker-than-anticipated ISM business towards of the end of the quarter. Lastly, the Broadcast, Consumer & Automotive category was down slightly, driven primarily by decreases in broadcast.
Gross margin was 70.1% for the quarter, at the high end of our guidance, driven primarily by customer mix. Operating expenses, including $2 million of amortization expense, were $217 million, in line with expectations. Other income was a net expense of $9 million. Net income for the quarter was $127 million or $0.48 per diluted share.
Operating cash flow for the September quarter was $137 million before $5 million in CapEx. Cash flow for the quarter was impacted by higher receivables primarily associated with the timing of end-of-the-quarter shipments to our primary distributor partner who had an extra fiscal week in the quarter.
Diluted shares for the quarter were 266 million shares. There was a 6.5 million share dilutive effect from our convertible notes. For questions relating to the dilution associated with our convertible debt, please visit our Investor Relations website at www.investor.xilinx.com.
We repurchased 2.4 million shares for $100 million during the quarter and paid $80 million in dividends. As a result, we returned over 130% of operating cash flow to the shareholders during the quarter, putting us well on track to continue to return over 100% of operating cash flow to shareholders in fiscal year '16.
Let me now comment on the balance sheet. Cash and investments were $3.5 billion. We had $600 million in convertible debt and $1 billion in fixed-rate debt, resulting in a cash -- net cash position of approximately $1.9 billion. Inventory dollars at Xilinx decreased by $9 million sequentially.
Let me now turn to a discussion of guidance for the December quarter of fiscal year '16. The guidance I provide will be inclusive of the extra fiscal week in our quarter, which we disclosed in our 10-K filing as well as in today's earnings release. Our backlog heading into the December quarter is up sequentially. Both wired and wireless communications are forecasted to be up. We believe our key wireless customers have reduced levels of inventory, and as a result, we expect continued improvement from China driven by FD-LTE deployment activity. Wired communications continues to be impacted by a weak CapEx environment, but we are expecting growth during the quarter from OTN and cable infrastructure businesses. We expect our Industrial, Aerospace & Defense segment to be up sequentially driven by a return to growth in aerospace and defense.
Lastly, we expect all components of the Broadcast, Consumer & Automotive category to be approximately flat. As a result, we are expecting total sales to be up 3% to 7% sequentially. And the midpoint of this guidance is predicated on turns rate of approximately 48%. 
Gross margin is expected to be approximately 69%. Operating expenses for the December quarter are expected to be approximately $230 million, including $2 million of amortization of acquisition-related intangibles. Other income and expense for the December quarter will be a net expense of $7 million. The share count is expected to be approximately 265 million shares. There will be an adjustment to our full year forecast on CapEx. We are raising our forecast to approximately $40 million for the year, up from previous guidance of $25 million as a result of building renovations on our San Jose campus. The tax rate for the December quarter is expected to be 12%.
Let me now turn the call over to Moshe.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon. Despite the anticipated challenges on the September quarter revenue, I'm pleased that Xilinx continued to deliver strong profitability. Gross margin was 70.1%, facilitating operating margin of 29%. This is a testament t
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon, and good afternoon. Despite the anticipated challenges on the September quarter revenue, I'm pleased that Xilinx continued to deliver strong profitability. Gross margin was 70.1%, facilitating operating margin of 29%. This is a testament to the strength of our business model, the diversity of the markets we serve, the impact of several corporate initiatives focusing on productivity improvement.
Revenue from our new product category, which delivered a robust 11% sequential increase, is expected to further accelerate in the December quarter. This gives us growing confidence that the September quarter represents the bottom of the current cycle for Xilinx.
As forecasted, last quarter, 28-nanometer revenue growth was driven largely by increases in wired communications, industrial applications and defense. A special mention is due to our Zynq product family, the industry's first all-programmable SoC, which increased sequentially by nearly 40%, repeating a similar increase in the June quarter. Our overall 28-nanometer revenue is expected to grow significantly in the December quarter, with sales driven by a majority of our end markets. These include communications, industrial, automotive, defense and test and measurement. 20-nanometer revenue in the September quarter comfortably exceeded the $15 million forecast. Majority of the growth continued to be driven by Virtex UltraScale, the industry's only ASIC class, 20-nanometer high-end product offering. In the December quarter, we're expecting 20-nanometer sales to again post strong growth and exceed $20 million led by wired communication and test and measurement applications.
For 16-nanometer node, we shipped the industry's first all-programmable MPSoC. This product is already -- has been already delivered to customers. This is a quarter ahead of schedule, highlighting the third consecutive generation of product leadership enabled by stellar execution by a foundry partner at TSMC in conjunction with our engineering and operations teams. This exciting new family targets applications in embedded vision including ADAS, industrial Internet of Things, 5G wireless systems and will facilitate Xilinx' expansion into the domain of ASSPs. 
Finally, last week, we announced the strategic partnership with Qualcomm to deliver interest -- industry-leading, heterogeneous computing solutions. These solutions will deliver new levels of efficiency and performance through FPGA-enabled dynamic workload acceleration on Qualcomm's ARM-based server platforms.
As I mentioned at the beginning of my comments, top line 3% to 7% sales growth expected in the December quarter is again being driven from our new product category. This is forecasted to deliver another healthy double-digit percentage increase comprised by both our 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer leadership portfolios.
We'll now turn the call back to the operator for Q&A.

componenttextpreview: Well, this is Jon. I don't know about being overly optimistic or not, but because the way this is a holiday end-of-the-year kind of thing and the way the weeks work out, there were definitely kind of piles up towards more of the day -- or the holiday, whi
componenttext: Well, this is Jon. I don't know about being overly optimistic or not, but because the way this is a holiday end-of-the-year kind of thing and the way the weeks work out, there were definitely kind of piles up towards more of the day -- or the holiday, which are typically not good production time period. So I mean, the end of our quarter ends up being, I think, like January 2 or something like that. So I mean, we're now overlapping both Christmas and the New Year's time. So I don't think -- thinking about it from a 7% or an arithmetic way is necessarily the right way. However, there's obviously some more shipping days in the quarter as a result of it. And of course, we get full weeks of expense no matter what.

And are you seeing -- I missed whether you said you're seeing signs of life in wireless infrastructure in China, whether that's sort of -- whether those -- that spending has started to come back.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if you look at it market by market, it's -- there is some recovery in communications, not necessarily some huge snapback, in particular, and not on wireless. So this does not assume there's a tremendous improvement in wireless. We are seeing impr
componenttext: Okay. So if you look at it market by market, it's -- there is some recovery in communications, not necessarily some huge snapback, in particular, and not on wireless. So this does not assume there's a tremendous improvement in wireless. We are seeing improvement in wireless. It has come off the trough. The trough, I believe, was in the quarter before last. And it is improving slowly from that, but there is no huge rebound. We are seeing strength in -- wired communications is growing nicely, and some of the other markets are growing at a nice level and are driving this. It tends to be a little broad, but Jon, you want to share your specifics?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think if you look at our new product growth rate of 11% and an expectation that we're going to have a nice growth in this next quarter as well on new products, I think what we're seeing is bouncing off the bottom. We're seeing some of the design
componenttext: Yes. So I think if you look at our new product growth rate of 11% and an expectation that we're going to have a nice growth in this next quarter as well on new products, I think what we're seeing is bouncing off the bottom. We're seeing some of the designs that we've really started to grow pretty significantly in wired and across automotive and industrial. When we look at our Zynq product family, it's starting to grow very significantly now, and that's a good sign. And the 2 drags that we had going for us through the earlier part of this our calendar year was our aerospace and defense business declining from the standpoint of the Joint Strike Fighter Program, final shipments being done, so that is essentially aerospace and defense essentially hitting bottom for us in this past quarter, and then the fact that inventory to be bled off in China particularly. And we believe our customers have reduced their inventory levels of FPGAs that they had in their stores, and we're starting to see some signs of more ordering and some more incremental deployments, as Moshe said, but not a giant snapback. So those are some of the factors that, I think, are -- contributed to our view in our confidence level that we're going to start moving back up now from the bottom.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. Maybe just a follow-up on the earlier comments on inventory levels and the supply chain. If you could share with us any metric, specifically on inventory at wireless OEM customers, and then to the extent yo
componenttext: Great. This is Gabriela Borges on behalf of Jim. Maybe just a follow-up on the earlier comments on inventory levels and the supply chain. If you could share with us any metric, specifically on inventory at wireless OEM customers, and then to the extent you could talk about inventory and distribution more broadly across the end markets and where those levels are compared to normal levels, that would be helpful.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think just as a general comment, inventories across most of our end markets are pretty lean and including in distribution despite the fact that we had a buildup in distribution right at the end of quarter. But then again, that was timing from when Avnet
componenttext: I think just as a general comment, inventories across most of our end markets are pretty lean and including in distribution despite the fact that we had a buildup in distribution right at the end of quarter. But then again, that was timing from when Avnet's quarter ended because they had the 14 weeks last quarter, which was after our -- a week after our quarter-end. So there was some buildup there, but that really isn't a sign of any sort of a long-term business situation. So I think in distribution, we're in pretty good shape. With respect specifically to wireless, it's always difficult to know the true story about what the status is because I think we've -- as you recall, we talked about this before, there are base stations that our customers have on loan to the carriers. There are base stations that were in inventory completed, and then there were situations where we know FPGAs were built up in their factories. And what we can see, the most, obviously, is the FPGA inventory, and that's where we feel we've worked that down at major customers. And there should be more of a demand pull of kind of a situation now on a go-forward basis. That's our view on that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next mission is from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next mission is from the line of Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk again on the wireless infrastructure side. Just conceptually as you look forward, I think you said that it was down about 50% year-over-year a couple of quarters ago. If you think about where it could go in the future, do y
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk again on the wireless infrastructure side. Just conceptually as you look forward, I think you said that it was down about 50% year-over-year a couple of quarters ago. If you think about where it could go in the future, do you think that, that business for you can exceed the prior peaks? Or are there some things that would limit it from ever reaching those peaks? Just conceptually trying to think if we're at the bottom, what does the next top look like and where does it compare to the prior?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if you look at wireless, it's -- now there's various elements and there's 4G deployment. And the next major surge will be 5G deployment, which were already designed into a lot of the prototypes, which will be demonstrated in the next few years. But the
componenttext: So if you look at wireless, it's -- now there's various elements and there's 4G deployment. And the next major surge will be 5G deployment, which were already designed into a lot of the prototypes, which will be demonstrated in the next few years. But the reality, there's a long time before there is the massive growth in 5G. So now if you're looking for the short term, we do expect for it to grow. It's unlikely in the short term to get to the previous peak. That peak was driven by a surge in China. What we're seeing now is deployment in India, but that is viewed as a much smaller market. And then other markets are deploying at the low rate. So I don't see us returning to that previous peak, which I believe was in the March 2014 quarter, any time soon. I do expect us to see a recovery from the trough, but the previous peak is going to take time and it will probably require a combination of elements to return to that level.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll just point out that, that previous peak that Moshe referred to was an artificial peak in retrospect, meaning there was a lot of inventory builds being built up by our customers who all thought they were going to get a higher share. It was earlier in
componenttext: I'll just point out that, that previous peak that Moshe referred to was an artificial peak in retrospect, meaning there was a lot of inventory builds being built up by our customers who all thought they were going to get a higher share. It was earlier in the China LTE rollout of TV, and I think we've got a lot of -- we had many customers thinking they were going to get a bigger share out of that. And so in retrospect, that's why I called it the artificial peak.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Srini Pajjuri with CLSA Securities.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Srini Pajjuri with CLSA Securities.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jon, just a question on OpEx and then I have a follow-up. So obviously, the extra week is, I think, impacting the OpEx in the December quarter. How should we think about it as we head into the March quarter and beyond?
componenttext: Jon, just a question on OpEx and then I have a follow-up. So obviously, the extra week is, I think, impacting the OpEx in the December quarter. How should we think about it as we head into the March quarter and beyond?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we provided full year guidance for R&D and SG&A, and we do still expect to be in that range and maybe SG&A a little bit towards the bottom end of that range, quite frankly, but still a couple of puts and takes going on, on that. But we're pretty -
componenttext: Yes. So we provided full year guidance for R&D and SG&A, and we do still expect to be in that range and maybe SG&A a little bit towards the bottom end of that range, quite frankly, but still a couple of puts and takes going on, on that. But we're pretty -- we're very comfortable with the previous range. We can get you those numbers if you need them. It's -- we have...

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I have them, so yes, that's great. And then maybe for Moshe. You put out a press release a couple of days ago on the Qualcomm partnership. I guess one of the reasons that Intel has been talking about for acquiring Altera is, I guess, they want to
componenttext: I think I have them, so yes, that's great. And then maybe for Moshe. You put out a press release a couple of days ago on the Qualcomm partnership. I guess one of the reasons that Intel has been talking about for acquiring Altera is, I guess, they want to integrate FPGA into the x86 die. I'm just curious if this partnership with Qualcomm is -- first, is it exclusive to Qualcomm? And then I think you also mentioned that down the road, you plan to offer integrated solutions. Does that mean that Qualcomm would be offering fully integrated single-die solutions with Xilinx' FPGAs on it?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let me first answer with regards to Qualcomm. So we will have a range of solutions that could work on with Qualcomm, start from cards and then move to higher level of integration. We haven't defined what those high level of integration -- what th
componenttext: Okay. So let me first answer with regards to Qualcomm. So we will have a range of solutions that could work on with Qualcomm, start from cards and then move to higher level of integration. We haven't defined what those high level of integration -- what those high levels of integration are, but we are working closely with them. And this is a program that started 2 years ago, and what we -- what was shown at the rollout was that the first server that they were providing to their software developers and to their customers as a development platform, and there was in parallel a board which had our device on it which connected with that and provided the 10 to 50x acceleration for certain sets of applications. And so that's the situation there. We have a very tight relationship with Qualcomm. It's not an exclusive relationship. One of the opportunities we have is we believe that the data center market is an emerging market. There are 3 elements to it. There's a networking part. There's a storage part. And there's a acceleration part, which is the one which is getting the most press but isn't the only one. So the first 2 are obviously -- we're in a good position there. With regards to the third, what we're seeing is there's a lot of competitive architectures, x86 and others, which are pursuing that market at this point in time. Clearly, Intel has the highest market share, but it is expected to have more than one set of solutions that is driven by the customers who are very large independent companies and their desire to control their own destiny. So we do believe that, that will, over time, provide a interesting growth opportunity for us, and we have a strategy that enables us to participate at different levels of integration with all of the players in that market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. And when do you expect production revenues from this partnership, Moshe?
componenttext: That's great. And when do you expect production revenues from this partnership, Moshe?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, with the Qualcomm, I can't tell you without disclosing when they're going to ship the product, hence, I am precluded from answering that. But other partners are in different stages of deployment. A few are a little further ahead. A few are further b
componenttext: Well, with the Qualcomm, I can't tell you without disclosing when they're going to ship the product, hence, I am precluded from answering that. But other partners are in different stages of deployment. A few are a little further ahead. A few are further behind. And so over time, we do expect this to be a significant growth opportunity for us. But this is not measured in months. This is couple of years out at the earliest before it starts becoming visible.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Chris Danely from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question is from Chris Danely from Citigroup.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one question on the comm end market. So when you look at the spending patterns from the China carriers, it looks like it's pretty strong in the second half of this year. So how much of this are you guys seeing? And then conversely, getting into next
componenttext: Just one question on the comm end market. So when you look at the spending patterns from the China carriers, it looks like it's pretty strong in the second half of this year. So how much of this are you guys seeing? And then conversely, getting into next calendar year, it looks like spending is down. So any thoughts you have on the market for next year would be appreciated as well.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Chris, on the spending patterns out of China and just generally Asia, as we have been communicating here, we do see positive signs, but we don't really see -- we see the positioning that there could be brisker growth out there in the next 2 quarters
componenttext: Yes. Chris, on the spending patterns out of China and just generally Asia, as we have been communicating here, we do see positive signs, but we don't really see -- we see the positioning that there could be brisker growth out there in the next 2 quarters for us, the rest of our fiscal year. But our customers are certainly not committing to that level at this point in time. So it's one of those situations again where you don't know whether it's a false signal that they're saying, hey, it could be bigger than this, it may not be bigger than this. So we put a number in that we think is more on the center of likelihood there. And relative to next years, it's very difficult to forecast for the whole year on the wireless segment. But I don't think we're looking at it based on how poor this year is. I don't think we're looking at it as a down year for us next year. That's about all I'll say on that.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Joe Moore from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question is from Joe Moore from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: If we go back to the server acceleration business, can you talk about how big you think that opportunity ultimately can be? Altera had talked about it as a $1 billion type of long-term opportunity. Intel made it the focal point of the transaction. Do you
componenttext: If we go back to the server acceleration business, can you talk about how big you think that opportunity ultimately can be? Altera had talked about it as a $1 billion type of long-term opportunity. Intel made it the focal point of the transaction. Do you agree that it could be that big? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's an emerging market, and it's a little too early to figure out how it will turn out. But it is clearly in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Could it be $1 billion? Yes, it could be $1 billion. But I think it's premature to sort of count on it
componenttext: Well, it's an emerging market, and it's a little too early to figure out how it will turn out. But it is clearly in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Could it be $1 billion? Yes, it could be $1 billion. But I think it's premature to sort of count on it being that big because it is an emerging market and we expect it to be a very bifurcated market. Again, it's sort of important to look at the end customers. And these are the big data center companies in North America, and then there's the big data center companies in China. Each of them has an ecosystem and an software environment that they totally control. And they tend to have an application, which -- their applications are different, and they tend to do it their own way. So we do expect it to come out with a vast peripheral of solutions, and we believe we'll be in a good position to provide that as opposed to dictate a small number of solutions, which we believe will be the competitive approach.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then following up on that, to the extent that you've talked about other architectures other than x86 in that market, can you talk about your approach within x86? Do you sort of assume that the lion's share of servers is going to remain on
componenttext: Okay, great. And then following up on that, to the extent that you've talked about other architectures other than x86 in that market, can you talk about your approach within x86? Do you sort of assume that the lion's share of servers is going to remain on x86? What's your ability to compete? How important is it that you're not in the co-package part with the processor? How do you compete external to that?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest challenge to integration is power. And if you look at this market, it tends to use a pretty high-performance processor and a relatively large FPGA. You need those in order to get the acceleration. If you look at those, those tend to be r
componenttext: Well, the biggest challenge to integration is power. And if you look at this market, it tends to use a pretty high-performance processor and a relatively large FPGA. You need those in order to get the acceleration. If you look at those, those tend to be relatively power-hungry devices. So there's a limit to what you can do by integrating them into one package. And so even if it's just interfacing to an Intel device, we believe that we will be able to provide a companion device, which will enable a differentiated solution for several of the players in that market. So we do expect to play in that market, too. And definitely in any non-Intel market, we expect to be -- to have a very strong position with regards to servicing the requirements. It's the primary provider of FPGA solutions and the largest provider of FPGA solutions in the market.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from David Wong from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question is from David Wong from Wells Fargo.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you tell us a bit more about your plans for 16-nanometer? So you've got your first product. Will there be a rollout of a large number of more products in the near future? Or will they be spread over time?
componenttext: Can you tell us a bit more about your plans for 16-nanometer? So you've got your first product. Will there be a rollout of a large number of more products in the near future? Or will they be spread over time?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so what's typically happens is when we roll out the first device, then it goes through a lengthy evaluation phase. And as soon as we get to clear understanding of the level of functionality, we then do a rapid rollout of the follow-on devices. The fun
componenttext: And so what's typically happens is when we roll out the first device, then it goes through a lengthy evaluation phase. And as soon as we get to clear understanding of the level of functionality, we then do a rapid rollout of the follow-on devices. The functionality of this initial device has exceeded all expectations. We got it back faster, and it operates much, much better. And hence, we already shipped it to customers just to sort of demonstrate the level of functionality. So I would expect the rollout of the next devices to be as fast as we can. We do need to complete the evaluation of the first device. That takes significant amount of time. Typically, this process takes about a year to 1.5 years from the first device until you have most of the family rolled out. And given the success and the fast turnaround we got from TSMC and the functionality both on the manufacturing aside, from the engineering side, we should do better than we have in any previous generation. And it is a very broad and deep product offering. It has a very high-performance processor subsystem with significant number of embedded, dedicated accelerators, and a combination of those will enable us to take it and compete over time against ASSPs in more and more markets. So it is -- we think this is a watershed moment for us in terms of the rollout.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question is from Ian Ing from MKM Partners.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question on one of the submarkets. You said that ISM was weaker than expected, especially at the end of the quarter. Perhaps what's driving that? And does that continue into this quarter for some period?
componenttext: Question on one of the submarkets. You said that ISM was weaker than expected, especially at the end of the quarter. Perhaps what's driving that? And does that continue into this quarter for some period?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. At this point in time, we don't think it's necessarily a bellwether to any sort of a cycle. It just was, I'd say, consistent with maybe what we've seen, and there's some other component companies of a little softness in that market for a short time p
componenttext: Yes. At this point in time, we don't think it's necessarily a bellwether to any sort of a cycle. It just was, I'd say, consistent with maybe what we've seen, and there's some other component companies of a little softness in that market for a short time period. So it's a matter of the turns profile. We still -- we are expecting continued strength on our new products in that particular area. Some of the older designs, just for taking a pause, probably some inventory adjustments there. But the new products continue to be strong in that particular end market. So I think it was more -- it's just more of a -- just a situation for how things played out at the end of the quarter than it is any sort of a forecast for the future.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again, if I can just add color. It's a market that develops very, very slowly. And as a result, to the extent there was a downturn, it was the older technologies, right? But what we have seen, and this was driven by Zynq, is in 28-nanometer, we actually s
componenttext: Again, if I can just add color. It's a market that develops very, very slowly. And as a result, to the extent there was a downturn, it was the older technologies, right? But what we have seen, and this was driven by Zynq, is in 28-nanometer, we actually saw significant and vibrant growth. And this is an expansion play for us because the Zynq product offering is different from anything we've had in the past. So we are now seeing that enable us to grow into new areas. And so we fully expect ISM -- even if there are pullbacks from time to time, we expected to see that to be one of our more promising growth markets going forward. And it's Zynq, and it's the MPSoC. Again, given the nature of the design wins, some of those design wins, even on 28-nanometer, 5 or 7 years old, and are just now starting to hit the -- and become visible on the Zynq side, and that will grow to be a bigger part of our business going forward.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then longer-term question here. I mean, how much manufacturing cost improvements is left? I see you have now the second highest gross margins in all of semiconductors. I mean, do you eventually become like a linear, which is very high margin but low g
componenttext: And then longer-term question here. I mean, how much manufacturing cost improvements is left? I see you have now the second highest gross margins in all of semiconductors. I mean, do you eventually become like a linear, which is very high margin but low growth? Or are you getting some cost improvements as you migrate to the 20-nanometers and 16-nanometers, et cetera?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is a never-ending process and it's -- I've often heard the term that we have reached saturation in terms of our capability to improve in terms of density, cost, et cetera. And as soon as I hear that, we set a new bar, and surprisingly, we hit the
componenttext: So this is a never-ending process and it's -- I've often heard the term that we have reached saturation in terms of our capability to improve in terms of density, cost, et cetera. And as soon as I hear that, we set a new bar, and surprisingly, we hit the new saturation point. So I think the opportunity for improvement, while not trivial, is very significant. And we continue to do that on numerous fronts, and it requires a lot of engineering effort, both in-house and together with our foundry partners. But I don't think you should sort of assume this is as good as it gets. Now with regards to moving to future nodes, the good news is that we are reaching the old historic so-called saturation densities with new nodes faster than we reach them with old nodes even though the new nodes are significantly more complex and have more manufacturing layers. So I think, in particular, if you look at TSMC, their ability to continue to improve and the volumes they run are very helpful to help us improve on those fronts. And we continue to push to achieve those regardless of the node, both on old node and new node, and it's something that we need to do. So the strategy is both to continue to improve in that regard but also to provide market growth, and the market growth comes through expanded product capability. And that's sort of -- I will admit that over the past few years, I have 2 years of not delivering that, but we are intent on delivering that going forward, for sure, much better than we have in the past 2 years.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll just add one comment on that. As we -- if there was a question behind your question around are we sacrificing growth to protect margins, and no, that's not what we're doing in this. What we have here is a situation where we have customer and end mark
componenttext: I'll just add one comment on that. As we -- if there was a question behind your question around are we sacrificing growth to protect margins, and no, that's not what we're doing in this. What we have here is a situation where we have customer and end market mix that's pretty favorable for us. So we're at the high end of our 68% to 70% stated model for the current period and situation. And there are -- we aren't tied by accepting deals at lower than that margin if we need to. We set a portfolio and a balance, and we drive cost reduction where we think volume is going to be, and we put more focus on that. And I think you're just seeing a disciplined, efficient situation that we put in place here in the company, and I 110% agree with all the things that Moshe just said.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question is from Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Moshe, I wanted to go back to the many solutions versus few solutions type of approach and your wording. Is it since -- are you getting questions and a sense of urgency from customers directly regarding that many solutions approach as a result of the Inte
componenttext: Moshe, I wanted to go back to the many solutions versus few solutions type of approach and your wording. Is it since -- are you getting questions and a sense of urgency from customers directly regarding that many solutions approach as a result of the Intel and Altera announcement earlier this year?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hans, just to clarify, you're asking generally or are you asking with data centers in particular?
componenttext: Hans, just to clarify, you're asking generally or are you asking with data centers in particular?

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, data centers' acceleration, that aspect of potentially why Intel may have wanted the Altera asset.
componenttext: Yes, data centers' acceleration, that aspect of potentially why Intel may have wanted the Altera asset.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So with regards to data center and the acceleration, that subset of applications, as we're going through cloudification or whatever the appropriate word is, and that's a major growth element. A significant portion of the CPUs that are being deployed
componenttext: Okay. So with regards to data center and the acceleration, that subset of applications, as we're going through cloudification or whatever the appropriate word is, and that's a major growth element. A significant portion of the CPUs that are being deployed are now being deployed in these large data centers, and the typical usage is very different from what the general purpose server did. As they build up these big data centers in particular, when you look at the massive players in that market, they tend to have very specific applications, and those applications tend to be massively parallel. All right. So if you think of things like search, et cetera, you can see how you could benefit from massively parallel solutions. And what sort of happens is for better or for worse, if you go to just making the CPU faster, the return there is not significant. And if you just go to multi-core CPU, there's a limit to what you can achieve there, again, without blowing the power envelope out of the water or out of the data center. And so what has happened is the biggest limiter is power, and the performance per power configuration that you get from an FPGA or a programmable solution is superior for most of these applications. And the factor that we have seen consistently is anywhere from 10 to 50, and it depends on what application and exactly -- and it can change even between -- in the same company as they shift things around. So there is, if you believe -- if you look at that, then that implies that the traditional ability to address the customer's requirements through selling them faster CPUs or more parallel CPUs is limited. Hence, the desire to have a programmable solution and combination is very beneficial for what is becoming a very large part of the -- what used to be a traditional server market. And that's -- best we can tell, that's what the customers are telling us, that's what they're excited about. We do believe that the Intel acquisition of Altera was driven by a desire to control that and to make sure that the rollout is driven and not, in any way, compromised by the CPU power requirements, and hence, the rationale for doing it. And these same consumers tend to have a very independent desire to control their destiny, which probably opens up opportunities for other non-x86 architectures for other players if there is a competitive x86 solution at the right point in time together with FPGAs. Now that may be more than you asked, but that's a comprehensive answer.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that was very good. Exactly what I was looking for.
componenttext: No, that was very good. Exactly what I was looking for.

headline: Xilinx Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 14, 2015
